Folk of the Brittany region in France, including Breton Celtic Folk Music and music in the regional Romance language, Gallo.
Movement in the Brittany region of France which translated Celtic Folk Music from Ireland and Scotland into the Celtic Breton language.
Breton style performed by bands featuring bagpipes, bombardes, and percussion.
French folk from Corsica, sung mainly in Corsican and sometimes in French.
Traditional A cappella Polyphonic Chant from Corsica consisting of three registers of vocalists singing in a semicircle.
French popular music which arose in 1880s Paris, performed with the traditional instruments musette, grelottière, and accordion.
Appeared in the 1930s in France, combination of Musette with Swing, mainly focusing on accordion playing.
Sung mainly in Occitan and sometimes in French.
Traditional Folk Music from Auvergne region.
French Folk Music from the Gascony cultural region in southwest France.
Traditional Folk Music of Germany.
Indigenous Maltese folk which consists of quatrains, ideally improvised, following a rhyme scheme of a-b-c-b, and sung to traditional tunes, usually accompanied by guitars.
Traditional Folk Music of the Hungarians.
Traditional Hungarian dance and music form characterized by tempo variations.
Traditional Folk Music of Istria.
Folk traditions of Italy.
Sung in the Neapolitan language by a male voice with instrumental accompaniment, originating in the Italian city of Naples and the surrounding regions.
Italian popular genre characterized by the fast execution of solo instruments such as clarinet, saxophone, or the accordion.
Italian folk poetry, generally improvised and handed down by street singers, carters or sellers.
Fast upbeat tempo, switching between major and minor modes while gradually increasing in speed.
Italian Folk dance and music from Apulia, belonging to the family of Tarantella.
Italian folk from Campania, belonging to the family of Tarantella.
Polyphonic Traditional Folk Music originating in the Ligurian region of Genoa, in northern Italy.
Emulates European Folk Music from the Middle Ages, originating in Germany in the 1980s.
Emulates music played by pagan people, particularly from pre-Christian Europe.
Folk of Nordic countries of Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden.
Folk of the Danish people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Faroe Islands.
Traditional Folk Music of the Finnish people.
Traditional Folk Music of Iceland, including a variety of styles like the rímur, the kvædaskapur and langspil instrumental music.
Traditional Sami singing style found in northern Finland, Sweden, Norway and Russia.
Meta-genre strongly related to Nordic Folk Music having less complex structures, easy rhythms, and melodic lines.
Traditional Nordic dance with a 3/4 rhythm.
Traditional Swedish dance with a 3/4 rhythm and an emphasis on the first beat.
Traditional Folk Music of Norway, primarily intended as accompaniment for dancing and coming in two main varieties, instrumental and vocal music.
Traditional music of the Swedish people, commonly incorporating fiddle, accordion, flute, nyckelharpa, and/or voice.
Traditional Swedish dance with a 3/4 rhythm and an emphasis on the first beat.
Lively style and corresponding dance originating in Central and Eastern Europe, featuring a 2/4 cut time beat and instruments which vary by region.
Traditional Folk Music from Portugal.
Traditional Portuguese Music based on vocal music from the Alentejo region.
Refers to a popular folkloric dance, of the Azores islands, as well as the accompanying music.
Tradition from Portugal originating in the first half of the 19th century, mainly consisting of melancholic songs accompanied by Portuguese guitars or classical guitars.
Fado variant originated in the city of Coimbra, known for its serenades.
Folk of the Portuguese province of Trás-os-Montes, notable for a greater Celtic influence than other parts of the country.
Traditional Folk Music of the Romanians.
Traditional Romanian music sung by women mourning at a funeral.
Christmas music from Romanian folklore with ritualistic and pagan roots.
Melancholic, lyrical folk song characterised by its free rhythm.
Strongly influenced by folk from Turkey, Russia, and Western Europe, and even by Byzantine Church music.
The Traditional Folk Music of Sardinia, an island in the Mediterranean Sea.
Traditional monophonic singing accompanied by a chittera sarda from the Mediterranean island of Sardinia.
Secular Polyphonic Chant from the Mediterranean island of Sardinia.
Traditional Folk Music native to Slavic peoples.
Eastern Slavic Folk Music, including traditional ceremonial, wedding, and harvest songs.
Traditional Folk Music of the Bosnians.
Polyphonic vocal music that developed in Bosnia in the 20th century, bearing connections to traditional Bosnian genres.
A melancholic folk song, originating from Bosnia and Herzegovina, typically love-themed and accompanied by instruments like guitar and accordion.
Consists of a variety of traditions and styles, with distinct sounds originating from current and historical regions such as Sofia, Dobrudzha, Macedonia and Thrace.
Traditional Folk Music of the Croats.
Traditional form characteristic of the Dalmatia region of Croatia rooted in littoral church singing.
Folk of the Czech people in central Europe.
Dissonant form of polyphonic singing from the regions of Herzegovina and Dalmatia.
Music of highlanders occupying Northern Carpathians (Gorals).
Music of indigenous highlanders native to the Western Beskids and the Podhale regions in Southern Poland.
Folk music of Macedonians, a South Slavic ethnic group who are primarily associated with the Republic of Macedonia.
Urban folk from Macedonia very popular in the 19th and 20th centuries performed by ensembles called Čalgii.
Traditional folk music of Montenegro.
Traditional Folk Music of the Moravian people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Poles.
Urban folk street band traditions of Polish cities.
Traditional urban poetry sung in the Warsaw dialect by buskers, and accompanied by street bands.
Traditional Folk Music of the Kashubian people of northwestern Poland.
Fast, syncopated, duple-time national dance of Poland.
Calm, triple-time national dance of Poland.
Traditional Folk Music of the Kurpian people of eastern Poland.
The fastest triple-time national dance of Poland.
Music of indigenous highlanders native to the Western Beskids and the Podhale regions in Southern Poland.
Eastern Slavic Folk Music native to the Russian people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Serbian people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Slovaks.
Traditional Folk Music of the Slovenian people.
Modernised form of Slovenian Folk Music from the Alpine region of Upper Carniola (Oberkrain).
Translated as "old city music", this is the urban traditional music of Macedonia and Serbia.
Urban folk from Macedonia very popular in the 19th and 20th centuries performed by ensembles called Čalgii.
Traditions of the people of Ukraine.
Type of Ukrainian sung epic poem.
Traditional Folk Music of the Hutsul people.
Traditional Folk Music of Spain, widely diverse due to the distinct culture and traditions of the country's different regions.
Flamenco of Andalusia in southern Spain, rooted in traditional music and dances and developed mostly after the 18th century by the Romani people of Andalusia (known locally as gitanos).
Traditional religious praise song that originated in Andalusia, Spain towards the end of the late Middle Ages.
Named after the city of Seville in Spain, typically rhythmic with a 3/4 beat and guitar accompaniment.
Traditional Folk Music of the Aragonese people.
Traditions of the Spanish province of Asturias.
Traditional folk of the Canary Islands.

Spanish variant of schottisch, a slow version of German Polka which developed through the incorporation of regional folk influences and an association with the local castizo culture in Madrid, the capital of Spain.
Evolved from Spanish theatrical styles like Cuplé and has strong links to Flamenco.
Originally developed in the 19th century as a blend of old theatre Spanish styles based in short monologues (jácara and tonadilla) and French Couplet.
Traditional music of the Galician people.
Mainly instrumental Spanish style primarily associated with bullfighting and popular celebrations, believed to originate from a double-time military march from France in the 18th century.
Traditional Folk Music of the Volga-Ural region in the European Russia.

Traditional folk of the Bashkir people, a Turkic ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Bashkortostan (Bashkiria), a federal subject of the Russian Federation, and its neighboring areas on both sides of the Ural mountains.
Traditional Folk Music of the Chuvash people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Komi people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Mari people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Mordvin people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Udmurt people inhabiting areas in the Volga-Ural region of Russia.
Traditional Folk Music of the Volga Tatar people native to republics of Tatarstan and Bashkortostan.
Traditional Folk Music of Wallonia, the mostly French-speaking southern region of Belgium which also includes a few Flemish and German minorities.
Traditional form of vocal music of Eastern European peoples.
Traditional folk developed in Ashkenazi Jewish communities, particularly those of Yiddish-speaking Eastern and Central Europe.
Folk music of the Hazara people, mainly native to central Afghanistan.
Encompasses many varieties of folk traditions from Hispanic America.
Follows a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature with non-percussive instrumentation, often melancholic in sound with bright guitars and a rich melodic base.
Percussive style from Puerto Rico, generally considered to be derived from West Africa.
Uruguayan popular music originating among Montevideo's Afro-Uruguayan population, based on three differently-sized drums.
Sung poetry traditional to Chile and transmitted orally from one generation to another.
Colombian folk music that originated in Boyacá province, best known for its wordplay and humorous lyrics.
Originated in northwest Argentina and southern Bolivia around 1850, typically in 6/8 and traditionally performed with instruments like the guitar, bombo legüero (traditional drum), and violin.
Traditional genre and dance from the Río de la Plata region (Argentina, Uruguay, and southern Brazil), featuring similar rhythms to Milonga and typically performed with the guitar and accordion.
Popular in Chile, Argentina, and Bolivia, accompanied by a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature and usually structured into 14 verses.
Traditional dance and music genre with Andean roots that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.
One of the most popular genres of Andean music in Bolivia, particularly present in the departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosí.
Fast and lively; mostly played in northwestern Argentina in the provinces of Jujuy, Salta, and Tucumán.
Traditions of the mountain-dwelling jibaro people that live primarily in Puerto Rico.
Incorporates elements of Creole music and the Venezuelan waltz.
Traditional musical accompaniment to the Venezuelan 'velorios de cruz de mayo' celebrations, played with the mandolin (as lead instrument), cuatro and guitar.
Traditional Folk Music of the Mexican people.
Overtly dramatic, and melancholic A cappella performed in the Comarca Lagunera region in northeast Mexico.
Usually dominated by violin with accompaniment mainly provided by guitars and tamboras, occasionally dancers will stomp over a platform.
Bold rhythmic structure, lively violin playing, and extensive use of falsetto.
Developed in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, traditionally played by guitar, requinto, marimba, and bajoquinto, usually played in 3/4 time.
Mexican Folk Music from the Gulf Coast Mexican state of Veracruz, with both Spanish and indigenous influences.
Heavily influenced by Cuban Music, freely embracing Bolero, clave and Bambuco.
Rioplatense genre characterized by a slow rhythm which usually appears with a guitar; generally considered a precursor to Tango.
Mestizo folk genre popular in the central Peruvian Andes, characterized by a pronounced, though sedate, rhythm; traces of Andean melody; and octosyllabic verses.
Combination of African, Spanish, and Andean influences that originated after the time of the arrival of Spanish colonists and African slaves to Peru.
Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

Backing to the fast-paced dance that originated in northern Peru in the region of Piura of the same name; bands consist of a singer, a small chorus, two guitarists, along with the cajón and sometimes a spoon player.

Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.
Folk genre from Puerto Rico played with hand drums called panderetas.
Fast-paced, percussive traditional genre created by the Afro-Bolivian people.
Folk music and dance from Panama dating back to the 17th century.
Developed by the indigenous peoples of eastern Bolivia, bringing in some elements of Hispanic Music, and featuring a syncopated rhythm.
Traditional folk from the Chilean countryside distinguished by its prominent melody.
Peruvian criollo-mestizo songs with recurring themes of sadness and unrequited love, usually in 6/8 meter.
Traditional genre and dance of 19th century Peru, sung in the minor mode and accompanied by a varying combination of guitar, vihuela, harp and cajón.
Folk dance that evolved out of Peruvian Zamacueca during the 19th century.
Meta-genre encompassing traditions attributed to the indigenous peoples of the Americas.
Fiddle playing of the Dene or "Athabaskan" people of modern-day Alaska, Yukon and the Northwest Territories.
Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.
Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.
Traditional Folk Music of the Mapuche people of Chile and Argentina.
Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.
Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on charangos and guitarillas, with a catchy, lively rhythm.
Ladino-language Traditional Folk Music tunes that were written and preserved by Sephardic Jews.
Traditional Folk Music of the Ob-Ugric people of West Siberia Plain.
Improvised poetry accompanied by a guitar that is tied to gaucho culture.
Folk of the Romani people, an ethnic group with origins in Northern India, but who have since the Middle Ages settled around Europe, principally Romania, Bulgaria, and Spain, and many other places.
Traditional Folk Music of the Samoyedic peoples.
Meta-genre which covers all the Traditional Folk Music forms from South Asia.
Traditional Folk Music of the Assamese people, a people group mostly from the Northeastern Indian state of Assam.
Traditions of the Bengali people found mainly in the Indian state of West Bengal and the country of Bangladesh.
Songs performed by the Bauls, a movement of mystic entertainers influenced by diverse spiritual traditions.
Traditions of the Bhojpuri people of India, originally from the states of Bihar and Uttar Pradesh.
Call-and-response style of folk music developed from the Ahir and neighboring castes of the Bhojpuri people.
Traditional, percussion-based form of music popular in the Maldives, usually following a crescendo structure.
Traditional Folk Music of the Burusho people of northern Pakistan.
Traditional Folk Music of the Gujarati people, who primarily live in the western Indian state of Gujarat.
Traditional Folk Music of the Kannada people, a large ethnolinguistic group who mainly inhabit the state of Karnataka in southwestern India.
Call-and-response chanting that involves the singing of devotional mantras and hymns in a bhakti devotional style, occasionally accompanied with traditional folk instrumentation.
Religious Sikh Hymns backed by specially selected ragas and taal.
Traditional Folk Music of Kerala, India primarily sung in the Malayalam language and known for its drumming and percussion.
Traditional Folk Music of the Marathi people, a large ethnic group who mainly inhabit the state of Maharashtra in western India.
Traditions of the Newa people, who live in Nepal, performed with mostly percussive instruments and some wind instruments.
Traditional Folk Music of the Odia, a large ethnic group who mainly inhabit the state of Odisha in eastern India.
Traditional Folk Music of the Pashtun people of southern Afghanistan and north-western Pakistan.
Traditional Folk Music of the Punjabi people, mostly from the Punjab regions of India and Pakistan, covering diverse styles often played with traditional instruments.
Traditions of the Rajasthani people of Western India - who now mostly live in the eponymous Rajasthan state - originated across the various castes that inhabit the region.
Folk of the Sinhalese people, the majority ethnic group of Sri Lanka.
Blend of Hindustani Classical Music with Sinhalese Folk Music.
Traditional Folk Music of the Tamil people.
Percussive ensemble native to the Tamil Nadu region, taking its name from the urumi drum.
Traditional Folk Music of the Telugu people, one of the largest ethnolinguistic groups of India, mainly living in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.
Meta-genre covering all folk forms from Southeast Asia, like Gondang, Hmong, Iban, Karen, Keroncong, Khmer, Lao, Lun Bawang, Molam, and Orang Ulu.
Folk originating in the Visayas islands of the Philippines; dialogue or debate in which a man and a woman compete at improvising romantic verses.
Traditional Folk Music of the majority ethnic group of Myanmar.
Traditional ensemble in Bataknese traditional music of North Sumatra, taking its name from its leading instrument - a unique set of toned drums.
Traditions of the various tribal ethnic groups residing in the hills of Mainland Southeast Asia and Southwest China, also known as the region of Zomia.
Folk traditions of the Hmong people, an ethnic group localized in Laos, Vietnam, China, and Thailand.
Folk of the Khmer people, who mainly reside in Cambodia.
Accompanies a traditional Javanese dance of the same name, featuring a stripped-back version of a Gamelan ensemble that removes softer instruments.
Traditional Filipino love songs usually sung in Tagalog.
Traditional Folk Music of the Lao people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Malay people, who are native to Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, northern Indonesia, and southern Thailand.
Traditional Folk Music of the Thai people.
Traditional performance music originating in northern Thailand consist of an ensemble with Piphat instruments and a pair of female choreographers.

Traditional Folk Music of West Asia, a region that covers much of what is commonly known in English as the Middle East (alternatively Southwestern Asia), includes the distinct but interconnected traditions of numerous ethnic groups.
Anatolian folk pioneered by Turkish poets and bards, connected to the Alevist heterodox Islamic tradition.
Traditional Folk Music of the Armenians, which is attested in historic Armenia since antiquity, with unique regional dialects unified by general melodic structure.
Dance-oriented Armenian American music with prominent presence of Anatolian instruments and folkloric melodies (often in the 10/8 meter) paired with novel lyrics relating to a variety of topics.

Folk of the Assyrian or Syriac people, who are indigenous to the Upper Mesopotamian region roughly corresponding to ancient Assyria (which includes modern-day northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, northeastern Syria, and southeastern Turkey).
Folk of the Jewish settlers of Eretz Yisra'el.

Traditional Folk Music of the Kurds, an Iranian people who traditionally inhabit the mountainous region of the Middle East comprising southeastern Turkey, northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, and northeastern Syria.
Traditional Folk Music of the Luri people of southwestern Iran.
Azerbaijani folk recitative genre.
Traditional Folk Music of the Persian people.
Traditional Folk Music of Turkish people combines the distinct cultural heritages and traditions of Anatolian civilisations and former Ottoman territories.

children.nodeName: Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Turkish people who inhabit the northern region by the Black Sea.
Semi-improvisational melodic structure in Turkish Folk Music.
Turkish Folk Music music and dance that originated with the Zeybek people during the Ottoman Empire period, with slow and asymmetrical rhythms.
Sung by laborers and prisoners while working in factories and fields.
Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.
Aboio that features rhyming verses.
Work song created by African-American slaves working on cotton plantations, which features an expressive vocal style to no strict rhythm.
Rhythmic call-and-response style song form that traditionally accompanied the production of tweed cloth through beating the material by hand to soften it after it came off the loom.
Songs originally sung by sailors to coordinate work on ships.
Work Songs sung by Chinese agricultural workers.
Vocal technique that arose in many cultures around the world as a form of calling and communication.
Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.
Originated in Toggenburg and Appenzell in Switzerland; deep vocal range, relaxed voice, free tempo, polyphony, elongated notes, improvisation, glissando, and use of syllabic sounds.
Emerged primarily on the United States east coast in African American communities in the late 1970s; emphasizes rhythmic beat patterns and a type of spoken vocal delivery known as rapping.
Uses much more abstract lyricism than what is considered conventional within the genre, typically through use of metaphors, symbolism, and cryptic meanings.
Emerged in the United Kingdom during the mid-2010s, incorporating influences from Dancehall, Afrobeats, Contemporary R&B, and a variety of West African Music.
Centered mostly in France, features production influenced by modern styles developed in West and Central Africa with Trap-styled vocal flows.
Emerged from Turkey in the late 2000s, based almost exclusively around Arabesk samples and featuring aggressive rap vocals.

Tanzanian genre originating in the mid-1990s in the Dar es Salaam area, combining the influence of Rhythm & Blues, Afrobeat, and Dancehall with native Tanzanian styles like Taarab and Muziki wa dansi.
Production style identified by an acoustic-sounding drum pattern of a kick drum on the downbeat followed by a cracking snare on the upbeat.
Developed in New Orleans in the early 1990s, initially defined by a slow to midtempo beat with a double-time hi-hat on top.
Sped-up vocal samples and slick soulful production.
Remixing technique pioneered by the late Houston producer DJ Screw in the 1990s, where tracks are slowed down and remixed with a skipping effect.
Employs lyrics with a pro-Christianity message to profess the performer's faith, and often to attract new attention from potential converts.
Emerged in the early 2010s, known for its relaxed, dream-like, and reverb-heavy production style, taking influence from Chillwave, and producers' obscure sample choices.
Hip Hop with the intent to be humorous, through the use of comedic lyrics, production, delivery, or another musical aspect.
Artists whose lyrics deal with social issues.
Combines the flow, production-emphasis, and demeanor of Hip Hop with the lyrical content and general approach of Country.
Originating from the southern United States and reliant on drum machines and synthesizer stabs to create an energetic, often dance-oriented sound.
Electropop influence and distinctive harsh vocals and screaming.

Developed in the late 2010s and characterized by frantic, bombastic, and glamourous production, usually derived from Trap, that serves to accompany highly melodious, auto-tuned, and hi-pitched vocal performances, often done with breathy voice singing and sing-rapping.
Originated in the Southern US during the mid-1990s, defined by a bouncy rhythm, fast-tempo snares, 808s, heavy bass, and often rapped in a rhythmic delivery consisting of explicit lyrics.
Most prevalent from 1979 to 1982, featuring MCs rapping over popular Disco breaks.
Stripped-down production style pioneered in the early 2010s and identified by a lack of drums or minimal, subtle percussion left untouched from the original sample or filtered out.
Highly influential style of Hip Hop that developed in New York City, particularly in the South Bronx, during the 1970s.
Moody, melancholic production combining atmospheric Cloud Rap, and Trap's typical drum programming, with sampling from Alternative Rock, Midwest Emo, Emo-Pop, and Pop Punk.
Incorporates experimental and eccentric elements considered unconventional or unorthodox compared to more traditional hip hop.
Experimental Hip Hop that uses Industrial Music beats and sounds.
Hip Hop originating from France, typically performed in the French language.
Combines elements of Dancehall with various traditions of Kenya.
Relaxed and organic sound featuring live instrumentation, use of P-Funk samples, and high-pitched synth lines.
Characterized by confrontation and aggression, whether in the lyricism, vocal delivery, hard beats, heavy production, or any combination thereof.
British Hardcore Hip Hop from the late 1980s and early 1990s featuring a fast style of beats and rapping.
Lyrics from a gangster's perspective, typically within the Hardcore Hip Hop sound.
Latin Rap with a Mexican twist.
Lyrical content and imagery focuses on the macabre and morbid, including such topics as Satanism and suicide, with production generally of a darker nature than is typically found in other Hip Hop.
Characterized by minimalistic half-time drum machine programming with droning bass, often paired with aggressive rapping and a double time flow.
Combines the dark production of Memphis Rap with the fantasy aesthetics and sound design of Dungeon Synth.
Based around heavy drum machine production sound.
Features loud, distorted 808s and basslines, as well as aggressive vocals that are usually yelled or screamed.
Fusion of Ghanaian Highlife with Hip Hop.
Hip hop mainly produced in the San Francisco Bay Area with a guttural vocal style; common themes include women and partying.

Sparse beats at a tempo geared towards the "jerkin'" dance, typically involving rapping about skinny jeans and other elements of the movement's fashion style, jerkin'/being a jerk, or sexually explicit topics.
Can take the form of instrumental versions of songs that normally feature rapping, or hip hop originally released and always intended to be instrumental.
Primarily features eclectic sampling and lush, jazzy beats, usually set to Trap rhythms with prominent influences of Memphis Rap.
Typically performed in the Japanese language; many of the lyrics deal with aspects of Japanese lifestyles.
Incorporates elements of Jazz through the use of samples or live instrumentation.
Club-oriented genre characterized by heavy 808-driven beats, imposing synthesized brasses and an uptempo rhythm.
Fast-paced; draws influence from Bounce, Miami Bass, Jersey Club and Dancehall.
Primarily done in Spanish; incorporates Hispanic American Music elements into its sound.
Latin Rap with a Mexican twist.
Relaxed, laid-back form of Hip Hop, typically instrumental and influenced by Jazz Rap and Downtempo.
Sustained Roland TR-808 kick drums and faster tempos, along with a distinct Electro influence.
Originated in Atlanta, slower tempos and a more melodic approach than Miami Bass.
Popularized in the late 90s, added Afro-Brazilian elements as the atabaque sound into the Miami Bass kick drums.
Minimal, stripped-down with an emphasis on low-frequency bass partitions.
San Francisco Bay Area production style building on slowed down Funk (often utilizing live elements).
Themes touch on such nerd mainstays as science, computers, and science fiction.
Characterized by a dark, sinister and menacing sound, heavy sub-basses, simple melodies and slow, sparse and slamming drums.
Developed in the 1980s; features explicitly political lyrics and themes.
Fuses Hip Hop's rapping and production traits with Pop elements such as melodious vocals and light, catchy tunes.
Grew out of the Chicago Drill scene in the early 2010s, characterized by autotuned vocals and upbeat synth melodies.
Playful, Snap-influenced and party-oriented.
Club-oriented Hip Hop pioneered by Mustard defined by a repeated synth melody and a sparse drum pattern often accompanied by a "hey" chant.
Prominent 808 bass and finger snaps, with lyrics primarily focused on nightclub topics (such as sex, drugs, and alcohol).
Hip Hop from artists based in the Southern region of the United States.
Originated in Atlanta in the early 2000s; distinctive fast hi-hat sound and heavy bass at moderate tempos.
Emerging in Michigan during the 2010s and incorporating upbeat 808 percussion derived from Trap music and dynamic, off-beat flows from rappers.
Originated in Chicago in the early 2010s, broadly characterized by complex, energetic rhythms, coupled with street-conscious and often violent rapping.

Characterized by bass-heavy, dense, and typically syncopated percussion, featuring ticking hi-hats and gunshot-like snare rolls, usually accompanied by menacing synth melodies and violent, gangsta lyricism.
Grew out of the Chicago Drill scene in the early 2010s, characterized by autotuned vocals and upbeat synth melodies.
Mixes Drill and Jersey Club production, characterized by an energetic sound and distinct syncopated rhythms.
UK Drill rhythms applied to more traditional Trap and Plugg percussion, using melodic and recognizable samples as the main compositional focus.
Deep bass and complex rhythm which denotes a Grime influence in the production.
Playful, Snap-influenced and party-oriented.
Defined by its usage of minimalistic, repetitive midtempo drum patterns, and simple, prominent 808s.
Use of sparse and minimalistic drum and hi-hat patterns, subby 808s and heavy low end, piano samples, airy pads, and icy synths.
Characterized by ominous, sinister synth pads and lead melodies, skittering hi-hats, and fast percussion and snare rolls.
Emphasizes more melodic and layered synth leads, denser and faster drum programming, and a lesser reliance on the laid-back, minimalistic atmosphere of earlier Plugg styles.
Dense PluggnB percussion in combination with airy bells, synth plucks, and soaring synthetic guitar leads.
Characterized by dense, buzzing synth work with repetitive chord progressions and melodic synth leads.
Primarily features eclectic sampling and lush, jazzy beats, usually set to Trap rhythms with prominent influences of Memphis Rap.
Dark and hyperactive production, featuring rapping laced with layers of effects.
Distinguished by its Reggaetón and Latin Rap roots, with smooth and moody production inspired by Alternative R&B and Contemporary R&B.
Features loud, distorted 808s and basslines, as well as aggressive vocals that are usually yelled or screamed.
Combining Trap percussion and rhythms with major influences of Egyptian Shaabi, especially Mahraganat.
Mixes passionate vocals derived from Contemporary R&B with laid-back, nocturnal and atmospheric Trap production.

High-tempo production, usually set around 160 to 190 BPM, icy synths, busy drum programming with distinctive 808 patterns, often implementing off-beat hi-hats in addition to trap's triplets and a fast style of lethargic rapping.
Manipulating and re-appropriating vinyl records using a turntable and DJ mixer in a hip hop context, developing from production techniques in the studio and on the stage.
Scene of the United Kingdom, influenced by American rap.
Artists who originate from the West Coast region of the United States.
Umbrella encompassing Industrial as well as later derivatives that combine its aesthetics with other styles and in more accessible directions which fall under Post-Industrial.

Emerged out of Punk and avant-garde art movements in the mid-1970s, often characterized by a bleak, mechanical atmosphere, the use of metallic percussion as well as other unconventional instruments, and extensive use of sampling influenced by Musique concrète.
Waves of feedback, screeching analog synthesizers, and harsh, screamed vocals.
Combines the abrasive textures of Noise and Industrial music with dark, brooding drones and atmospheres.
Umbrella group of genres that combine the dark, mechanical aesthetic of early Industrial music with more accessible genres, such as Rock and Electronic Dance Music.
Emphasizes an ominous, gloomy, and dissonant atmosphere.
Incorporates elements such as guitars, synthesizers, harsh or whispered vocals, raw production, or other elements associated with Black Metal and Dungeon Synth.
Dark, deep, disturbing, ritualistic, and occult atmosphere.
Emerged in the 2010s as the hybridization of diverse Electronic Dance Music genres with an abrasive Post-Industrial sound.
Melodic and beat-driven Electronic Dance Music take on Post-Industrial that developed in the 1980s.
Emerged in the early 1990s in Europe, combining EBM beats with the abrasiveness of old school Industrial but with a greater focus on a horror-inspired atmosphere and harsh, distorted vocals.
Based on the dark atmosphere of Dark Electro, typically characterized by more aggressive Hardcore [EDM]-influenced beats and harsh/distorted vocals.
Derivative of EBM, retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of Synthpop.
Underground dance music which originated in Belgium around 1987, tending to resemble slower, harder EBM.
Formed in the late 1980s and early 1990s; grew out of a combination of EBM and Industrial.
Emerged in the early 1990s in Europe, combining EBM beats with the abrasiveness of old school Industrial but with a greater focus on a horror-inspired atmosphere and harsh, distorted vocals.
Based on the dark atmosphere of Dark Electro, typically characterized by more aggressive Hardcore [EDM]-influenced beats and harsh/distorted vocals.
Defined by its Deconstructed Club sonic palette and its cinematic proportions.
Fuses the sonic palettes and aesthetics of Industrial Music with the intense rhythms of Gabber, Speedcore, Doomcore and other subsequent styles.
Experimental Hip Hop that uses Industrial Music beats and sounds.
Fuses Metal with elements from Industrial Music.
Originated around 1999, influenced by EBM and Aggrotech with more melodic and less repetitive riffs as well as harsh vocals.
Alternative Metal and Industrial Metal that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically Electronic Dance Music.
Hybrid of Rock and Industrial Music.
Harder, darker style of Techno which draws parallels with factories and the rhythm of machinery.
Characterized by cold, mechanical, and hypnotic tracks, typically lacking the harsher and noisier elements of later Industrial Techno.
Incorporates elements of traditional European military marches with Neoclassical Darkwave, Dark Ambient, Industrial Music, and Neofolk.
Post-Industrial that combines looped samples of Noise with Electronic rhythms.

Originating in African American communities in the Southern United States around the turn of the 20th century, building on New Orleans Brass Band ensemble and influences from Ragtime and Blues to become a very popular style by the emergence of Swing in the 1930s.
African-styled percussion and rhythms.
Blending of Arabic Music and Jazz.

Combines traditional or mainstream Jazz stylings with non-traditional techniques of avant-garde art music by experimenting with characteristics such as rhythm, harmony, structure, melody, and instrumentation.
Dispensing with traditional Jazz structures and Swing sounds, instead performing Avant-Garde Jazz and pushing the boundaries of the medium.
Attempts to break free from the conventions and patterns of earlier jazz subgenres through the use of elements such as dissonance or atonality.
Arose in Europe in the late 1960s and early 1970s, moving even further from the Jazz tradition by often dropping the swinging rhythm, taking liberties with the use of atonality and noise.
Coined in the early 1990s by a group of Polish Avant-Garde Jazz musicians to describe their cross-genre, often arrhythmic, improvised sound.
Fast tempos, improvisation, irregular melodic phrasing, and complex harmonies and chord structures.
Commonly associated with the golden era of Swing in the 1930s and 1940s, performed by a large ensemble including brass, woodwinds, and usually a rhythm section.
Dispensing with traditional Jazz structures and Swing sounds, instead performing Avant-Garde Jazz and pushing the boundaries of the medium.
Introduces Western Classical Music compositional techniques into Big Band.
Came from the dancehalls of the 1920s and 1930s, combining a British take on Jazz with the Music Hall tradition.
Emerged from the city of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe in the early 1950s, led by the alto sax and accompanied by ensembles.
Developed parallel to American Jazz in the early 20th century, named for its origin in Cape Town, South Africa.

Zany and uptempo; incorporated elements of Western Classical Music and Modern Classical into frantic Big Band arrangements, playfully chaotic to match the on-screen actions of cartoon characters and the beat of their movements.
Made by mostly small acoustic-based ensembles with emphasized improvisation and influenced by Neoclassicism and Traditional Folk Music.
Developed in the late 1940s alongside and in response to Bebop, featuring a more restrained, emotionally "cool" style.
Gritty, moody style that emerged in the mid-1950s to accompany film noir movies and hard-boiled detective/crime-themed TV shows.
Slow tempo and dark atmosphere, with influence from Film noir Film Scores and Dark Ambient.
Developed in New Orleans in the 1910s, incorporating influences from Ragtime and Blues into cacophonous, polyphonic arrangements with instruments trading places between accompaniment and soloist.
Primarily associated with ECM Records, combining elements of Jazz Fusion with the subdued atmosphere of Cool Jazz and the Western Classical Music bent of Third Stream.
Unique blend of traditional Ethiopic Music and Jazz.
Combination of Jazz with Flamenco nuevo, the contemporary style of Flamenco, which was pioneered in the late 1960s.

A continuation of Bebop that reintroduces more traditional African-American musical features, such as bluesy melodies, slow to medium tempos, and a more groove-oriented sound, while retaining the expressive improvisation.
Fuses the various musical traditions of the Indian subcontinent with jazzy musical structures.
Jazz highly influenced by Funk.

Near-universal usage of electric guitars and keyboards coupled with influences from genres such as Rock, Rhythm & Blues, Funk, and Traditional Folk Music, and a relative degree of harmonic simplicity.
Combines Jazz with several aspects of Romani Folk Music.
Emerged in the 1920s, incorporating the style and rhythms of Jazz as both art forms spread throughout African-American communities in the United States.
Used originally for Afro-Cuban Jazz but, due to its evolution, is now used for the fusion of jazz with Latin American rhythms, especially genres with African origin.
Combines Jazz with the rhythm of Afro-Cuban music like Habanera.
South African Jazz with origins in the 1920s and rooted in traditional South African music.
Influenced by Zulu music, characterized by its happy melodies, played by pennywhistle flutes and accompanied by a banjo or a guitar.
Emerged from the traditional Marabi Jazz and Swing as well as Kwela popular South African genres.
Utilizes musical modes as harmonic framework over traditionally used chord progressions.

Grew out of Hard Bop in the early to mid-1960s incorporating certain untraditional elements inspired largely in part from Avant-Garde Jazz, Modal Jazz and eventually, Free Jazz, such as non-diatonic chord progressions, irregular rhythms and amelodic forms.
Jazz genre from Brazil that incorporates Samba and/or Bossa nova elements.
Simple melodies and slick production influenced by Pop and R&B.
Appeared during the 1950s, when Gospel, Rhythm & Blues and later Soul started to influence the style of prolific jazz musicians.
Emerged in the 1960s, marked by a mixture of Jazz with approximations of ethnic styles, religious music of non-Christian traditions, and the ecstatic, transcendental aspects of Free Jazz.
Meant to evoke the action and drama of spy films.
Early form of Ragtime-derived Jazz with improvisational tendencies; named for the performers' left hand "striding" across the piano keyboard.
Distinctive rhythm and large backing rhythm section over which solos are performed.
1990s alternative take on swing music, incorporating elements from newer genres such as Rockabilly, Ska, and Punk Rock.
Blending of Jazz and Western Classical Music, with improvisation as a key element.
Focused on vocals, generally using a more traditional, poppy strong structure and reducing the role of improvisation.
Driving and distorted riffs, aggressive drumming, vigorous vocals, and an all-around show of brute force in its early days, since branching into dozens of subgenres.
Features alternation between harsh and melodic vocal styles, rhythmic drop-tuned mid-tempo riffage and influence from Alternative Rock, along with other non-traditional genres.
Melds Funk Rock grooves with slap basslines and metallic guitarwork.
Alternative Metal and Industrial Metal that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically Electronic Dance Music.
Emphasizes rhythm, using elements of Funk Metal and Hip Hop to create a cleaner, more groove-oriented sound.
Features rapped vocals, typically formed around heavy, mid-tempo, and groove-oriented playing in addition to elements of Hip Hop beats such as record scratching.
Often breaking the bounds of the genre through experimental structures and instrumentation, or by incorporating outside influences.

Typified by highly distorted, trebly, tremolo-picked guitars, blast beats, double kick drumming, shrieked vocals, and raw, underproduced sound that often favors atmosphere over technical skills and melody.
Focuses on the atmospheric element using slowly developing riffs, repetitive melodies, usually slow to medium tempos, and commonly synthesized ambient textures.
Melds tremolo-picked riffing, high-gain guitars, and harsh, often wailing, vocals with mellow, dreamy textures and melodic song structures.
Incorporates elements of Hard Rock, Glam Rock, and Heavy Metal.
Incorporates unconventional sounds with overpowering or constant Noise and Black Metal elements, often being heavily texture-oriented, abrasive, dissonant, atonal, or repetitive.

Characterized by lethargic atmospheres; usually repetitive song structures and slow-mid tempos; high-pitched wailing and gruff vocals; and usage of non-distorted instruments like keyboards and acoustic guitars.
Cleaner production, more diverse arrangements, and a stronger emphasis on melody than is typical for Black Metal.
Incorporates acoustic guitar and traditional instrument passages, cleanly sung vocals, folk songs' melodies, and paganistic themes.
Symphonic soundscapes, typically but not always synthesized.
Aggressive, chaotic, and heavily Death Metal-influenced.

Features distorted, commonly down-tuned guitars; palm-muted and tremolo-picked riffs; aggressive, double-kicked percussion that utilizes various blast beats techniques; abrupt changes in tempo and time signatures; and guttural vocal styles.
Emphasizes abrasiveness, chunky rhythmic atonal riffs, and low guttural vocals.
Focuses on slow or midtempo (as well as breakdown-style) sections built on chromatic, palm-muted riffs - so-called "slams".
Incorporates elements of Hard Rock, Heavy Metal, and Blues Rock while retaining the typical heavily distorted rhythm guitars and gruff vocals.
Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of Grindcore with the technicality and low guttural vocals of Death Metal.
Utilizes the guitar harmonies and melodic sound of Heavy Metal, while keeping the main characteristics of Death Metal.
Focuses on challenging, demanding songwriting and instrumental skill.
Emphasizes discordant, dense songwriting and utilizes pinch harmonics, scratchy guitar leads, and atonality.
Plodding tempos, repeated chords, and thick, distorted, down-tuned guitars in a style focused on foreboding, atmosphere, and tension.
Fuses down-tuned guitars, growled vocals, and aggressive, often double-kick drumming with a mournful, somber atmosphere and plodding tempos.
Features exceptionally slow, funeral dirge-like tempos, heavily distorted, sluggish guitars, mournful atmosphere, and distant, hushed growls and grunts.
Monotonous and heavy playing style; repetitive, rough, and sometimes atonal guitar riffs; a "rocking to sleep" bass; and influences from both Blues Rock and Psychedelic Rock.
Features an emphasis on Heavy Metal influence and theatrical vocals.
Composed with heavy repetitive drones, minimalist structure, and slow tempos.
Features influences from various types of Traditional Folk Music expressed through melodies and/or traditional instrumentation, notably having a large scene in Europe.
Features Celtic Folk Music elements.
Emerged as a metallic style in the mid-to-late 1990s from the German Neo-Medieval movement.
Features heavy, low-mid tempo riffs, somber, gloomy atmosphere accentuated by ethereal keyboards and synthesizer layers, and vocal styles ranging from raspy growls to female operatic singing.
Features shortened song structures and a diverse palette of intense techniques such as blast and skank beats, tremolo and down-picking, and various harsh vocal styles.
Standard conventions of Grindcore taken to an even more discordant and rapid-fire extreme, with added Electronic dimensions of computer-generated noises and drum machines.
Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of Grindcore with the technicality and low guttural vocals of Death Metal.
Death Metal-influenced riffs with rhythms ranging from very fast to slower mid-tempos correlated with pitch-shifted vocals, sloppy playing and production, and gore-themed aesthetics.
Combines and subverts Goregrind and Grindcore with brash Noise and even faster drum tempos.
Groovy, mid-tempo style known for its exaggerated bouncy rhythm and common pornographic themes.
Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.
Midtempo riffs influenced by Thrash Metal but with a greater focus on rhythmic syncopation and heaviness over speed.
Heavier outgrowth of Hard Rock featuring greater distortion and intensity along with lesser Blues influences.
Acronym for new wave of British Heavy Metal, which occurred in the late 1970s, taking some influence from Punk Rock.
Originating from the NWOBHM and influenced by the work of early heavy metal bands, being faster and somewhat more aggressive than heavy metal.

American style influenced by NWOBHM that features heavily distorted guitars paired with more aggressive riffs, mid-tempo Heavy Metal rhythms, and over-the-top theatrical vocals with fantasy or conceptual themes.
Fuses Metal with elements from Industrial Music.
Originated around 1999, influenced by EBM and Aggrotech with more melodic and less repetitive riffs as well as harsh vocals.
Alternative Metal and Industrial Metal that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically Electronic Dance Music.
Combination of Hardcore [Punk] and Metal that began to take shape during the mid 1990s, emphasizing breakdowns and greater use of dissonance.
Fusion of Death Metal and Metalcore.
Rhythmically complex, features unconventional time signatures, syncopated and dissonant riffs and erratic metric shifts.
Originated in the late 1990s when some metalcore bands infused elements of Melodic Death Metal into their sound to create a more metallic and melodic style.
Greatly influenced by Western Classical Music in its style of playing and composing.
Heavily utilizes timbre and texture to have enormous song build-ups and huge atmosphere.
Performed with an emphasis on atmospheric and textured riffs.
Developed from Heavy Metal and Speed Metal; characterized by its emphasis on speed, vocal melody and harmonized lead guitars.
Fuses amplified, guitar-driven sound with technical proficiency, virtuosity, complex compositions, innovative arrangements, eclecticism, and additional instrumentation.
Syncopated rhythmic structures, angular melodies, and dissonant chords.
Combines the slow, dark instrumentals and atmosphere of Doom Metal with the aggressive, harsh screams and shouts credited to Hardcore Punk.
Performed with an emphasis on atmospheric and textured riffs.
Blues-influenced style that primarily incorporates Sludge Metal and Stoner Metal with metallic Southern Rock riffs.
Heavier, more metallic form of Crust Punk drawing influence from Thrash Metal as well as Death Metal and Heavy Metal.
Combines elements of Doom Metal with elements of Psychedelic Rock and Blues Rock to create a melodic yet heavy sound.
Elements of symphonic and orchestral music.

Features fast tempos; rhythmically focused, frequently palm-muted riffs; shredding solos; aggressive, often double-kicked drumming; skank beats; and vocal styles ranging from shouts to melodic singing.
Fusion of Thrash Metal and Hardcore Punk which started in the 1980s.
Places great emphasis on complex songwriting and demanding instrumental parts.

Tempo between 130 and 160 BPM, played with keyboards and metal instrumentation, sung with harsh and aggressive vocals including many clean melodic styles; regularly uses elements of Melodic Death Metal, Symphonic Metal, and Electronic Dance Music.
Developed out of Black Metal and embodies an epic, Viking-like aesthetic.
Range of styles of theatre individually popular in the United States or in various countries in Europe, mostly from the 19th century to the mid-20th century.
English reaction to the Italian Opera styles with a satirical sense of humor and scores borrowing from Traditional Folk Music and popular music.
Entertainment featuring Comedy, song, dance, and theatre.
Originally developed in the 19th century as a blend of old theatre Spanish styles based in short monologues (jácara and tonadilla) and French Couplet.
Popular comedy form in the Netherlands which evolved out of traditional Cabaret in the 1890s.
Theatrical entertainment consisting of mixed elements of music, sketches, monologues, dialogues, lyric poetry and/or ballads.
Songs performed at the Tuluat Theaters of İstanbul in the late 19th century.
Popular song and entertainment tradition from the U.S. engendered in variety shows employing racist caricature and blackface.
Popular carnival music traditional in some cities of Spain and Hispanic America.
Variant originated in Montevideo that stands out for its rhythms, nasal vocals and choral arrangements.
British theatrical entertainment popular in the 19th and 20th centuries, featuring light and comedic popular songs.
Light opera interspersed with spoken dialogues, being usually satirical and/or humorous in nature and centered around romantic plots and dancing scenes.
A fusion of music from the highlands of Madagascar and western Operetta.
French Musical Theatre and Entertainment based on numbers and sketches inspired by the most relevant events of the year.
Style of musical theatre inspired by Rock.
Originally composed to forward the story or enhance the characters or other plot elements of Broadway productions and other stage music.
Professional whistlers on the Vaudeville and Music Hall circuits.
German form of Opera distinguished by the prominent usage of spoken dialogues mixed with lyrical or folklore arias/ballads.
Performed in American musical theaters typically as part of a lowbrow, often comedic variety performance.
Vaudeville incorporating heavy Blues elements.
Broad genre centered on peaceful, meditative melodies, using a wide variety of instrumentation.
Takes heavy influence from Indigenous Andean Music, emphasizing a peaceful and harmonious atmosphere and often using the flute.
Represented in its most known style by a mysterious blend of subliminal sounds, ambient beats, and angelic and ethereal female vocals.
Takes heavy influence from Indigenous North American Music, emphasizing a peaceful and harmonious atmosphere and utilizing chants, drumming, and flutes.
Strongly influenced by and sometimes also based upon early music and the Baroque Music or Classical Period.
American development of Kirtan, fusing it with New Age and Western music.
Incorporates perceived elements of Tibetan Music, particularly singing bowls.
Umbrella of popular styles closely tied to mass production and mass marketing, focusing on catchiness and accessibility through melody, rhythm, lyrics, and hooks.
Slow to midtempo with a light and soothing tone, emerged as a successful radio format in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
Originated in West Africa during the early 2010s and includes elements from Pop Rap, Contemporary R&B, and Dancehall.
Blends the easy-going, poppy, and melodic Afrobeats sound and rhythms with major Amapiano elements, like lush, jazzy, and laid-back atmospheres often featuring light piano chords.
Characterized by more subdued, atmospheric, minimalist, and eclectic production and vocal styles compared to earlier styles, as well as more socially conscious lyrics.

Emerged in the late 2000s and early 2010s, combines chart Pop conventions with alternative/indie genre sensibilities sometimes on a more minimal and contemplative atmosphere, often extracted from Alternative R&B.
Experimental and atmospheric, drawing on Dream Pop, Post-Rock, Synthpop, Neo-Psychedelia, and 1990s electronica.
Synthesis of Arabic Music with Western Pop melodies, almost always sung in Arabic and typically performed with Arabic instruments, alongside some Western instruments like the guitar.
Emerged in the 1970s as an alternative to Shaabi, taking influence from foreign Pop and incorporating rhythms of Reggae while retaining a distinctly Egyptian sound.

Artistic, inventive and singular presentation and performance, often featuring poetic or oblique lyricism, and frequently subverting and experimenting with various other genres and art forms while remaining fairly Pop-oriented and accessible.
Balkan popular music which blends Pop, Folk, and ethnic music.
Bulgarian blend of Contemporary Folk (Turkish, Bulgarian, Arabic & Romani) with Dance-Pop.
Mixture of Romanian Music with Turkish, Middle Eastern, Balkan, and Romani influences, usually electronic in production.
Laiki music mixed with popular Western music, most notably pop and dance.
Tradition in Albania consisting of light, commercial, amplified Albanian Folk Music usually professionally arranged and manufactured in recording studios alongside video clips.
Appeared in the 1980s, incorporating modern instruments and based on the model of Balkan Pop-Folk in neighboring countries.
Greek popular artists who used more Arabian elements; originally a derogatory term used to refer to a more decadent side of Laika.
Mixture of Romani, Greek, Turkish, Albanian, and Slavic music, which incorporates Dance-Pop elements, and is very popular in Albania and Kosovo.
Originated in Serbia during the 1980s, fusing traditional Western Balkan Folk Music with elements of contemporary popular music.
Incorporates elements of Western Classical Music, commonly featuring harpsichord or strings as well as the rhythmic flow and counterpoint of Baroque Music.
Fuses Bit Music with additional synths, beats, guitars and modern production values, emphasizing highly catchy melodies and relatively fast tempos.
Usually refers to a Pop or Pop Rock song that contains strong Gospel-like elements, primarily popularized by white American and British singers in the 1960s through the 1980s.
Male vocal groups often put together by talent managers or record producers.
Romantic vocals and lyrics, bubbly and sensual melodies and rhythms, horn sections and lush Caribbean-like guitar riffs over fast tempos.
Elaborate, polished, and typically melodramatic composition and arrangement associated with the songwriting teams at the Brill office building during the late 1950s and early 1960s.
Pop known for its upbeat, catchy simplicity and targeted at children and young teens; especially popular in the '60s and '70s.
Popular music produced in Cambodia or by Khmer people.
Cambodian pop with a slow melody that is similar to Luk thung.
Sentimental vocal music sung in Spanish with a focus on the chorus, originally developed in the first half of the 20th century from a variety of traditional Hispanic genres.
Latin American style stemming from both Canción melódica and the British Beat Music.
Chilean offshoot of Canción melódica that expresses a much more melancholic or nostalgic side.
Popular music focused on Christian spirituality and faith.
Christian music with lyrics focused on the greatness of God.
Wave of Japanese Pop intended to reflect urban life during the period of the country's booming economy in the 1970s and 1980s, featuring a contemporary Western sound and lush arrangements.
Takes specific Western Classical Music conventions and applies them into a straightfoward Pop context for mainstream appeal.
Combination of Country with Pop to appeal to a larger audience.
Originated in the 21st century and takes its cues from Hip Hop, Pop and Contemporary Country.
Emphasizes Pop-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of Country instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.
Melds country and Pop (best described as 70s L.A. soft pop), and sometimes leans towards Disco.
Commercialized pop performed by Chinese communities across China and Taiwan, alongside its large diaspora.
Cantonese-language Pop with its heyday in the 1980s and early 1990s.
C-Pop in which songs are performed in Mandarin.
Inspired by traditional elements of Chinese Music with lyrical themes constantly revolving around Chinese culture and tales.
Simple, yet catchy melodies and throbbing beats inspired initially by Disco and later various House styles.
Playful, childlike style with a Bubblegum-like atmosphere that often incorporates high-pitched, light-hearted, and usually female-fronted vocals.
Polish Dance-Pop, originally established from contemporary wedding / feast songs and Italo-Disco.
Electro-influenced; developed in Latino communities in New York and Miami in the 1980s, especially dominated by Latin Freestyle and its Latin influences.
Displays a heavy influence of Hispanic American Music alongside the Disco, Hip Hop, and Electro influences of Freestyle.
Derivative of Funk brasileiro in a Dance-Pop direction, originating in Rio de Janeiro.
Emerged in the second half of the 2000s in Romania, often featuring brass melodies and "staccato" pluck grooves.
Blend of the themes and singing style of Rumba flamenca with the most commercial forms of House, Techno, and Makina.
Synth-heavy Dance-Pop style popular in the South African townships in the 1980s and early 1990s.
Indonesian popular music with Indian and Arabian influences which emerged in the early 1970s.
Development of Javanese Dangdut which originated in Indonesia in the 1990s, featuring a faster tempo and influences from international styles like Pop, Rock, and Reggae.
Nordic form of Pop music growing out of the 1960s Pop Rock explosion, and incorporating influences from Swing, Schlager and sometimes Country into its repertoire.
Danish equivalent to Swedish Dansbandsmusik, German Volkstümliche Musik, and US Country; a coming together of folk and pop elements.

Underground Japanese Pop aiming to be bizarre yet catchy, using off-key vocals, strange or nonsensical lyrics, repetitive chants, onomatopoeia, frantic, "off-kilter" production, and "moe" vocals and aesthetics.
Typically instrumental, lush pop played by orchestras and big bands for light entertainment.
Decidedly ironic take on Lounge that emerged in the early 1990s.
Emerged in the early 1950s as the United States developed a fascination with Polynesia and the South Pacific, incorporating traditional and rhythms from these cultures into a Western Pop context.
Mainly British instrumentals designed to appeal to a wider audience.
Emerged in the United States during the 1950s, emphasizing a chilled-out atmosphere with light instrumentation and sometimes vocals indebted to Vocal Jazz.
Orchestra that plays covers of popular songs as well as famous classical compositions.
Easy listening inspired by the optimism of the Space Age of the 1950s and 1960s and its excitement about mankind's space exploration.
Dense, layered, and compressed production, usually coupled with a distinct fuzzy and "warm" low-frequency synthesizer style.
Emerged throughout mainland Europe in the early 1970s, referring to slick, highly commercial Pop songs that emphasize sugary melodies and light, bouncy instrumentation.
Originally developed in the mid 1960s, incorporated palos flamencos (Flamenco subgenres) and Copla into the format of feisty and lively Pop (particularly, Yé-yé).
Blends Contemporary Folk with a Pop sensibility, most popular in the late 1960s and early 1970s and featuring influence from the contemporary Folk Rock style.
Pop originating from France.
Combines elements of Rhythm & Blues, Rock & Roll, and Traditional Pop; typically performed by trios or quartets of female vocalists.
Incorporates elements of more experimental Electronic styles like IDM and Glitch.

Developed and took inspiration from Bubblegum Bass and popular 2000s-2010s Electropop, characterized by eclectic, unconventional, mechanical-sounding and dense production; and by manipulated, usually auto-tuned vocals.
Commonly based out of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh and almost always sung in Hindi, Urdu or Bengali, implements South Asian Music in context of American and European Pop and Rock music.
Back-to-basics Rock approach combining a less mainstream and DIY ethos with melodic, lighthearted and straightforward songwriting.
Named for solo producers and singer-songwriters from the 2010s onward who created intimate, "authentic" music in their own homes, outside of a traditional studio environment.
Distinctly ramshackle, often Twee Pop-infused combination of British Indie Rock and Jangle Pop.
Based on the smooth and melodic songwriting of Lounge and other Easy Listening, as well as the orchestration of Baroque Pop and the production styles of other 1960s pop genres.
Japanese term for a cross-section of Indie Pop and Jangle Pop with more prominent acoustic instrumentation and songwriting/arrangements that draw from Sophisti-Pop.
Sentimental and melancholic scene, influenced by Twee Pop, that emerged in the late 1980s in Donostia / San Sebastián, Spain.
Distinct Post-Punk background and often jangling guitars, defined by a cute aesthetic and lyrics combined with an indie/DIY attitude and a simplicity often indebted to Punk Rock.
Phenomenon lasting from the mid-1950s until the early 1980s, often performed a mixture of currently popular music and skits.
Romantic style developed in Italy in the late 1950s including various influences such as Chanson and Schlager.
Elements are derived from Canzone napoletana.
Pop that incorporates elements from Jazz.
Commercial Pop of Japan after the advent of the Heisei era (1989), differing from Kayōkyoku in both vocal and instrumental techniques.
Otaku inclined update of the style pioneered by the Shibuya-kei scene, mixed with J-Pop and often tied to Anime and video game music.
Japanese popular music prominent during the later period of the Shōwa era (early 1950s to late 1980s).
More Westernized and upbeat form of Kayōkyoku popular in the 1970s and 1980s which acted as a precursor to J-Pop.
Early form of Kayōkyoku dominant in the 1950s and 1960s, prominently influenced by American Jazz, Hispanic American Music, and Hawaiian Music.
Offshoot of 1980s Kayōkyoku and Idol kayō incorporating characteristics from Synthpop.
South Korean Pop from the 1980s to the early 90s taking influence from western Blues, Synthpop, Soul and Contemporary Folk.
Emerged in the late 1990s in South Korea, taking influence from more traditional forms of Korean Music.
Contemporary Pop scene in South Korea based on multiple mainstream influences such as Contemporary R&B, Dance-Pop, and Hip Hop.
Contemporary form of Trot which takes influences from modern K-Pop and recent Pop substyles.
Characterized by its usage of Latino clichés and frequently influenced by traditional Latin American styles, commonly borrowing from their instrumentation.
Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.
Subgenre of Colombian origin fusing Vallenato instrumentation into a Latin Pop context.
Created by local, rural artists from Papua New Guinea that incorporate some elements of Papuan Folk Music into Pop.
Upbeat, danceable Hungarian Pop that takes strong influence from Hungarian Folk Music and Romani Folk Music.
Dutch language Pop which originally arose in the 1970s to describe the style of the 1950s and 1960s, but would also later be used for 1980s artists who incorporated elements of Ska and Reggae.
Developed when Japanese Singer-Songwriters incorporated elements of Contemporary Folk and Pop Rock with Kayōkyoku songwriting.
UK pop cultural movement associated with the early 1980s and defined by a distinct, flamboyant fashion sense.
Style of pop balladry originating from the Philippines as a successor of the Manila Sound.
Combines Orthodox Jewish themes and prayer with Pop songwriting, usually sung in Hebrew.
Originating from Volendam in the Netherlands; harmonizing vocals and orchestrated arrangements.
Hybrid of Iranian and Persian-language popular music with Western instruments such as the guitar, drum kit, and synthesizer.
Combines Western genres of music and instrumentation with a typical Batak flair, like lyrics about Batak life and the use of some traditional Batak instruments.
Employs traditional Ghazal's verse, meter, and poetic inclinations in a pop form.
Combines Minangkabau traditions with Pop structures and instrumentation.
Fuses melodic sensibilities into the traditional Raï structure, with increased utilization of synthesizers, guitars, and drum machines.
Light, commercial form of Reggae designed to crossover and break through to a more mainstream Pop audience.
Standard verse-chorus Pop that can also be categorized under Rock for its use of guitars, drums, and propulsive rhythms.
Emerged in the early 1960s in the United Kingdom, drawing on Rock & Roll and the late 1950s Skiffle revival.

Combined elements of British Rhythm & Blues, Beat Music, and Pop Rock with the studio effects of Psychedelia - fuzztones, flanging, chorus - to create a style often seen as a British relative of American Garage Rock and Psychedelic Rock.
Japanese bands in the mid-to-late 1960s who began performing a style of Beat Music primarily in English.
1960s Brazilian youth-oriented Pop Rock, with romantic lyrics and influenced by Merseybeat and Rockabilly.
Light, highly melodic style of Beat Music popular in the UK during the early 1960s, named due to the abundance of bands from Liverpool beside the River Mersey.
Dutch answer to the UK Beat Music boom of the 1960s.
Rooted in Post-Punk, with anthemic songwriting and a bombastic, stadium-ready sound.
Emerged in the United Kingdom in the early 1990s, with a style hearkening back to the traditional guitar-driven songs and melodic hooks found in the British Pop Rock of the 1960s.
Chiming, "jangly" guitar sounds rooted in Post-Punk, blended with Pop-oriented melodies.
Distinctly ramshackle, often Twee Pop-infused combination of British Indie Rock and Jangle Pop.
Japanese term for a cross-section of Indie Pop and Jangle Pop with more prominent acoustic instrumentation and songwriting/arrangements that draw from Sophisti-Pop.
Philippine Pop Rock movement most prominent in the 1970s; served as a predecessor of OPM.
Based around the piano, as opposed to most traditional Rock, which is based around the guitar.

Emerged in the late 1990s as a Britpop expansion mainly characterized by acoustic-leaning instrumentation, lush string arrangements, and mid-tempo song structures, as well as less apparent lyrical concerns for Britain in favor of introspective, contemplative themes.
Heavier Pop Rock that combines strong Pop melodies with loud power chords, characterized by prominent electric guitars, clear vocals, crisp harmonies, and economical arrangements.
Light, melodic, radio-friendly Rock which gained huge commercial success in the 1970s.
Combines influences from Country Rock and Caribbean Music to create an acoustic and breezy "island" themed sound.
Slick Pop Rock influenced by smoother R&B styles, popular in the late 1970s and often associated with California.
Sentimental and melancholic scene, influenced by Twee Pop, that emerged in the late 1980s in Donostia / San Sebastián, Spain.
Burmese Pop Rock genre which emerged in the mid-1960s.
Distinct Post-Punk background and often jangling guitars, defined by a cute aesthetic and lyrics combined with an indie/DIY attitude and a simplicity often indebted to Punk Rock.
Appropriates the sounds of instrumental Surf Rock, combining surfing- and car-themed lyrics with a style that draws primarily from Doo-Wop and Rock & Roll.
Fusion of Pop and Soul; originated in the 1960s as an attempt to give soul crossover success.

Succinct, catchy song structures; complex arrangements; Gospel-influenced vocals; highly melodic and rhythmic bass lines; 4-4 drum patterns; often syncopated piano parts; regular use of horn and string sections; and historically a distinctive reverb and treble-heavy production.
Mixes Sundanese traditions with Pop structures and instrumentation.
Milder counterpart to Progressive Rock, emerging in the late 1960s and introducing complex songwriting and arrangements into a Pop context.
Bridges the elements of Psychedelic Rock, Psychedelic Folk, and Pop to bring them together.
Elements of Armenian folk in its instrumentation, oftentimes incorporating influences from Arabic and other West Asian forms on a background of synthesizer arrangements.
Dominant form of popular music in Bhutan which broke traditions to move towards a more Western and Indian approach.
Cheerful Catalan genre that takes influences from Rumba cubana, Andalusian Rumba flamenca, and Pop.
Divided into lyrical and criminal chanson, it is best described as narrative-driven popular music inspired by crime and prison.
Light, sentimental, melodic pop music common mainly in northern and central Europe.
Finnish music related to Jazz and the foxtrot.
Dutch genre that enjoyed widespread popularity in the pre-Rock & Roll era. with simple melody and rhythm and lyrics composed of couplets and refrains.
Light Pop with borrowings from German Folk Music (volksmusik), often misleadingly labeled as being volksmusik.
Hybrid of Brazilian Sertanejo with Pop production and aesthetics, made popular nationwide during the mid-to-late 1980s.
Third evolution of Sertanejo, sharing close sensibilities with national Brazilian Pop music and other regional styles.
Merged the Arrocha style with the younger audience creating a more energetic and more danceable rhythm.
Incorporates the rhythms, production, and idioms of Funk brasileiro into the universitário genre.

Eclectic scene emerging from the Shibuya district of Tokyo near the end of the 1980s; often borrows kitschy, retro-inspired aesthetics alongside diverse musical influences from Indie Pop, 1960s Pop and Easy Listening, Jazz, and Electronic styles.
Otaku inclined update of the style pioneered by the Shibuya-kei scene, mixed with J-Pop and often tied to Anime and video game music.
Originated in the early 2000s as an offshoot of the Japanese Shibuya-kei movement when artists introduced more prominent "bleepy" electronic elements and faster tempos.
Incorporates influences from Jazz, classic R&B and Soul along with a slick, polished production style while retaining elements from its New Wave roots.

Emerged in the USSR during the early 1930s, and encompassed the dominating popular music style composed by government-approved songwriters and the primary repertoire of professionally trained performers.
Retrospective term for a more cheerful or wistful style of Pop which emerged in the mid-1960s as "soft pop".
Led by a prominent, melodic synthesizer sound, often with reverberated drum machine patterns that create a distinct atmospheric feel commonly associated with the 1980s.
Derivative of EBM, retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of Synthpop.
Trot influenced by Synthpop.
Offshoot of 1980s Kayōkyoku and Idol kayō incorporating characteristics from Synthpop.
Oriented to teen audiences and almost always sung by teens.
Predominant form of Western commercial popular music in the pre-Rock & Roll era, particularly in the USA and starting with Tin Pan Alley; typically vocal-oriented with an orchestral arrangement.
Came from the dancehalls of the 1920s and 1930s, combining a British take on Jazz with the Music Hall tradition.
Early form of Kayōkyoku dominant in the 1950s and 1960s, prominently influenced by American Jazz, Hispanic American Music, and Hawaiian Music.
Expressive and poetic Romanian style, generally sung similar to a Chanson and composed for piano and guitar orchestral arrangements.
Traditional compositions originating from the 1910s and onward which have become widely known, performed, and recorded across the world.
Early era of popular song in the USA, broadly from the 1890s-1930s; influences include Ragtime, Vaudeville and parlour music.
Started in the late 1950s, when Turkish artists started to write their own lyrics to Western popular tunes.
Melodic, polished, Pop-like, and vocal-focused with around 120-145 BPM and frequent overlap with Progressive Trance, Uplifting Trance, and Euro-Trance.
Western-sounding pop with Vietnamese lyrics, or pop that borrows sounds from popular Vietnamese genres and re-imagines them with more accessible and/or upbeat structures.
Upbeat, trendy Pop that emerged in Southern Europe in the early 1960s, focusing on image and risqué lyrics.
Umbrella of styles intended to replicate or enhance the altered state of consciousness brought on by the use of psychedelic drugs, originating in the 1960s.
Developments in Psychedelia since the early 1980s, building on the drug-inspired styles developed in the 1960s.
Originating among 2000s underground artists referencing the sounds of 1970/1980s pop culture through hazy, low-fidelity production.
Emerged in Los Angeles in the early 1980s, featuring jangling guitars and the energy of Power Pop and New Wave adorned with retro Psychedelia.
Extracts elements of texture-based Rock music and other texture-based music into a brooding, mysterious, subtly malignant atmosphere reminiscent of the collective memory and popular media of Italy.
Type of Neo-Psychedelia that draws from the aesthetics and expansive sonic palette of Space Rock combined with the more minimal, back-to-basics approach of the Post-Punk era.
Acoustic forms that capture an atmosphere that is at turns dream-like, 'spaced-out', whimsical, haunting, mystical, and melancholic.
Offshoot of the New Weird America movement characterised by acoustic and eclectic instruments, peculiar vocal styles, romantic lyrics, and a childlike atmosphere.
Incorporates improvisation, repetition and extended song lengths.
Bridges the elements of Psychedelic Rock, Psychedelic Folk, and Pop to bring them together.
Rock which emerged in the mid-1960s that often attempts to emulate or enhance the effects of psychedelic drugs.
Heavier with an emphasis on instrumental jamming and "wah" guitar effects.

Developed in the late 1960s with influence from Blues Rock, such as heavy dependence on riffs and willingness to improvise, adding crushing levels of heaviness with thick fuzzy guitars to create a doomy and morose atmosphere.
Influenced by South Asian Music, featuring a droning compositional quality and commonly incorporating instruments like sitar, tambura, and tablas.
Heavy use of synthesizers and guitar effects to create dense atmospheric soundscapes intended to evoke images of outer space and science fiction scenarios.
Type of Neo-Psychedelia that draws from the aesthetics and expansive sonic palette of Space Rock combined with the more minimal, back-to-basics approach of the Post-Punk era.
Zambian 1970s Psychedelic Rock found mainly throughout the Copperbelt region.
Soul which incorporates the effects and instrumentation of Psychedelic Rock.
Psychedelic timbres, raw production, and stylistic influence from Doom Metal and Heavy Psych.

Brazilian counterculture art movement started in 1967 blending Psychedelic Rock, Psychedelic Pop, and Experimental production with contemporary Brazilian pop, with the lyrics being left wing-tinted abstract poetry.
Musical and cultural product of Punk Rock known for its simplistic, brash playstyle and anti-establishment themes.

Combines the stripped-down aggression of rudimentary Punk Rock with frequent experimentation ranging from instrumental interplay, noise, dissonance, and/or influences from other genres such as Jazz or Funk.
Mixes together Country Rock, Rockabilly, and Contemporary Folk with the familiar punk sound.
High-tempo fusion of Hardcore Punk and Electronic, combining harsh vocals and electric guitars of the former with electronic instruments.
Focuses on emotional lyrics, expressive vocals, melodic songwriting, and dynamic song structures.
Emerged primarily in Washington D.C. in 1985 as a reaction to the stagnant Hardcore Punk scene, with a less aggressive style that was more melodic and often featured emotional, introspective lyrics.
Mainstream derivative of Emo, puts more emphasis on the poppy sensibilities of Alternative Rock and Pop Punk.
Features the emotional and melodic style of Emo that usually alternates between loud and soft dynamics; off-key, strained vocals with little screaming; and arpeggiated guitar parts.
Began in the early 1990s, merging the emotional lyrics and melodicism of Emo with the intensity, aggression and speed of Hardcore Punk.
Volatile, aggressive sound of Screamo with slight Powerviolence undertones.
Influenced by various forms of Folk, including Traditional Folk Music as well as Contemporary Folk and Folk Rock.
Infuses the sounds of Celtic Folk Music into Punk Rock.
Strong Eastern European influences, especially various kinds of Romani Folk Music and Balkan Folk Music as well as Klezmer.
Broad genre which originated in the late 1970s; early work featured simple songs that took the punk formula and produced its most extreme result.
Combines the pop choruses, high-pitched vocals, and playful nature of pop punk with heavy, metallic breakdowns and occasional unclean vocals akin to Metalcore and Post-Hardcore.
Infuses melodic aspects of Metalcore and Post-Hardcore with various styles of Electronic Dance Music.
Features shortened song structures and a diverse palette of intense techniques such as blast and skank beats, tremolo and down-picking, and various harsh vocal styles.
