Standard conventions of Grindcore taken to an even more discordant and rapid-fire extreme, with added Electronic dimensions of computer-generated noises and drum machines.
Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of Grindcore with the technicality and low guttural vocals of Death Metal.
Death Metal-influenced riffs with rhythms ranging from very fast to slower mid-tempos correlated with pitch-shifted vocals, sloppy playing and production, and gore-themed aesthetics.
Combines and subverts Goregrind and Grindcore with brash Noise and even faster drum tempos.
Groovy, mid-tempo style known for its exaggerated bouncy rhythm and common pornographic themes.
Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.
Emerged in the late 1970s, often featuring extensive use of yelling or screaming, a stripped-down production style, and very short songs.
Slow, and heavy, with more breakdowns than typical Hardcore Punk.
Emphasis on delivering a very energetic and triumphant sound with flashy and soaring Metal solos, "melodramatic" or "uplifting" chord progressions, and singalong, over the top, harsh vocals.
Fusion of Thrash Metal and Hardcore Punk which started in the 1980s.
Metallic form of Hardcore Punk that grew out of the Anarcho-Punk movement in the mid-1980s.
Borrows heavily from Black Metal production, blast beats, tremolo guitar, and vocals, while retaining the core Crust Punk sound, lyrical themes, and aesthetic.
Melodic, dark, and atmospheric style that often incorporates influences from Sludge Metal, Post-Metal, Black Metal, and Screamo.
Heavier, more metallic form of Crust Punk drawing influence from Thrash Metal as well as Death Metal and Heavy Metal.
Early 1980s Hardcore Punk featuring Metal influences and a distinct drum style also known as the D-beat.
Frequently noisier and more abrasive than its Western counterpart.
Emerged in the USA in the early to mid-1980s, placing emphasis on melodic vocals and technical guitar riffs rather than raw aggression.
Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.
Hardcore Punk bands from New York City from the 1980s and onwards.
Originated in the late 1980s/early 1990s; takes the blueprints of Hardcore Punk and Grindcore, with the addition of wildly fluctuating tempos within a single song.
Fuses skank rhythms and frantic blasts of horns with hardcore intensity.
Fuses Skacore with elements of Crust Punk and sometimes Metal; coupled with anti-establishment lyrics.
Driven by Oi! style group vocals, catchy melodies, and aggressive songwriting akin to Punk Rock of the 1970s fused with Hardcore Punk of the 1980s.
Fast tempos, brief song structures, and the occasional use of blast beats.
UK scene that occurred during the early 1980s, consisting of developing hardcore styles such as early Street Punk and D-Beat bands.
Combination of Hardcore [Punk] and Metal that began to take shape during the mid 1990s, emphasizing breakdowns and greater use of dissonance.
Fusion of Death Metal and Metalcore.
Rhythmically complex, features unconventional time signatures, syncopated and dissonant riffs and erratic metric shifts.
Originated in the late 1990s when some metalcore bands infused elements of Melodic Death Metal into their sound to create a more metallic and melodic style.
Fuses Post-Hardcore and Metalcore influences with Chiptune instrumentation.
Short blasts of riff-less, Noise-driven music accompanied with chaotic drums and screamed vocals.
Emerged in the mid-1980s from Hardcore Punk that expanded on its aggression and dynamics through longer and more complex arrangements.
Emerged primarily in Washington D.C. in 1985 as a reaction to the stagnant Hardcore Punk scene, with a less aggressive style that was more melodic and often featured emotional, introspective lyrics.
Began in the early 1990s, merging the emotional lyrics and melodicism of Emo with the intensity, aggression and speed of Hardcore Punk.
Volatile, aggressive sound of Screamo with slight Powerviolence undertones.
High-register clean vocals and technical instrumentation drawn from Math Rock and Progressive Rock.
Emerged in the early 2000s; characterized by sassy vocal styles and chaotic, erratic instrumentals.
Late 1970s and early 1980s revival of Mod fashion and music, featuring influence from the nascent Punk Rock scene.

Emerged alongside the initial Punk Rock explosion in the mid-to-late 1970s, putting a greater emphasis on frequent experimentation, atmosphere, generally stripped-back instrumentation and, at times, angular-sounding guitars, throbbing bass lines, and interlocked drumming.
Originated in Europe in the late 1970s and early 1980s and is known for its generally dark, gloomy atmosphere and heavy reliance on synthesizers.
Mixes the energy of Punk Rock with the danceable rhythms of Funk and Disco.
Dark atmosphere and gothic imagery, featuring synthesizers and moderate use of chorus and echo effects.
More Punk-oriented offshoot of Gothic Rock that emphasizes energy and an effect-laden sound over pure atmosphere.

Emerged in New York City during the late 1970s; took the ethos of Punk Rock but discarded melody and catchiness, including instead extreme noise, distortion, feedback, angular rhythms, stream-of-consciousness lyrics, and more.
Incorporating the sounds and aesthetics of Post-Punk into Indie Rock, with jagged guitarwork, a dominant and danceable rhythm section, clean production, and poppy song structures.
Used to describe what influenced or in some way resembled Punk Rock before that genre's commercial breakthrough in 1976.
Fusion of the instrumentation and scales of Blues Rock with Punk.
Fast tempos, loud and distorted riffs, simple songs, frequent use of power chords, and shouted vocals, originating in the mid-1970s in response to commercial, sentimental, and complex Rock.

In part a reaction to the commercial breakthrough of Punk Rock in the late 1970s, with some artists adopting an intentionally rougher and sloppier sound combined with lyrical themes of anarchism and related issues that gave the genre its name.
Infuses the sounds of Celtic Folk Music into Punk Rock.
More Punk-oriented offshoot of Gothic Rock that emphasizes energy and an effect-laden sound over pure atmosphere.
Partly a reaction to the commercialization of the German movement Neue Deutsche Welle; characterized by extreme speed, consciously basic songwriting, crude musicianship, and radical leftism.
Combination of the raw fuzztones of the original Garage Rock bands of the 1960s with the tempo and attitude of the Punk Rock.
Contrasts a snotty, nihilistic, and combative attitude of punk with theatrics and flamboyance.
Emerged in the late 1970s, often featuring extensive use of yelling or screaming, a stripped-down production style, and very short songs.
Slow, and heavy, with more breakdowns than typical Hardcore Punk.
Emphasis on delivering a very energetic and triumphant sound with flashy and soaring Metal solos, "melodramatic" or "uplifting" chord progressions, and singalong, over the top, harsh vocals.
Fusion of Thrash Metal and Hardcore Punk which started in the 1980s.
Metallic form of Hardcore Punk that grew out of the Anarcho-Punk movement in the mid-1980s.
Borrows heavily from Black Metal production, blast beats, tremolo guitar, and vocals, while retaining the core Crust Punk sound, lyrical themes, and aesthetic.
Melodic, dark, and atmospheric style that often incorporates influences from Sludge Metal, Post-Metal, Black Metal, and Screamo.
Heavier, more metallic form of Crust Punk drawing influence from Thrash Metal as well as Death Metal and Heavy Metal.
Early 1980s Hardcore Punk featuring Metal influences and a distinct drum style also known as the D-beat.
Frequently noisier and more abrasive than its Western counterpart.
Emerged in the USA in the early to mid-1980s, placing emphasis on melodic vocals and technical guitar riffs rather than raw aggression.
Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.
Hardcore Punk bands from New York City from the 1980s and onwards.
Originated in the late 1980s/early 1990s; takes the blueprints of Hardcore Punk and Grindcore, with the addition of wildly fluctuating tempos within a single song.
Fuses skank rhythms and frantic blasts of horns with hardcore intensity.
Fuses Skacore with elements of Crust Punk and sometimes Metal; coupled with anti-establishment lyrics.
Driven by Oi! style group vocals, catchy melodies, and aggressive songwriting akin to Punk Rock of the 1970s fused with Hardcore Punk of the 1980s.
Fast tempos, brief song structures, and the occasional use of blast beats.
UK scene that occurred during the early 1980s, consisting of developing hardcore styles such as early Street Punk and D-Beat bands.
Horror movie-themed genre of Punk Rock.
Inspired by Post-Punk but with a more bizarre atmosphere with unusual or comic vocal techniques and a lyrical focus on the offensive and scatological.
Rejection to burgeoning Art Punk; a much simpler and more melodic style.
Blends the loud, fast-paced, and sometimes sloppy sound of Punk Rock with the catchy sound and songwriting of Pop.
Combines the pop choruses, high-pitched vocals, and playful nature of pop punk with heavy, metallic breakdowns and occasional unclean vocals akin to Metalcore and Post-Hardcore.
Cross-pollination of Punk Rock and Rockabilly.
Movement mainly distinguished by its lyrical content expressing the viewpoints of the LGBTQ+ community, as well as promoting queer pride and unity.
Underground feminist Punk Rock movement and related scene(s) which emerged in the United States in the early 1990s.
Combines Ska with the speed and aggression of Punk Rock.
Fuses skank rhythms and frantic blasts of horns with hardcore intensity.
Fuses Skacore with elements of Crust Punk and sometimes Metal; coupled with anti-establishment lyrics.
Combines the speed of Melodic Hardcore with the catchiness of Pop Punk, finding a middle ground between the two.
Punk Rock that incorporates elements of Surf Rock.
Incorporates influences from Nordic Folk Music and the imagery of Viking romanticism and Norse mythology.
Appropriates the harsh elements of Punk Rock but replaces the predominance of guitars with synthesizers and drum machines.
Includes the most popular forms of African American music from the late 1940s, when the term Rhythm & Blues first appeared, through to the Contemporary R&B of the 1980s forward.
Usually refers to a Pop or Pop Rock song that contains strong Gospel-like elements, primarily popularized by white American and British singers in the 1960s through the 1980s.
Continuation of the Disco sound with increased influence from Funk, Synth Funk, and R&B and a slower tempo, often featuring drum machines and filter modulated synthesizers.

Characterized by soulful, passionate and melismatic vocals originally derived from popular Soul and Disco, and by smooth, lush and often synthezised production variously influenced by Hip Hop, Funk, and related strands of Pop.
Deviating from the traditional styles of Contemporary R&B and featuring smooth, reverberated, Electronic-influenced production with heavy bass and often reverberated vocals.
Hip Hop-oriented style that evolved out of New Jack Swing in the early 1990s.
Mixes light Hip Hop & Funk production techniques with Contemporary R&B vocals and melodies as well as swinging and danceable drum grooves.
Mixes passionate vocals derived from Contemporary R&B with laid-back, nocturnal and atmospheric Trap production.
Emerged in the late 1980s and early 1990s; combines raw basslines and breakbeats with Contemporary R&B/Soul vocals.
Heavy emphasis on male four-part harmonies and light instrumentation; peaked in popularity in the 1950s.
Strong danceable grooves typically carried by bass guitar and drums, prominent use of extended chords, and a percussive guitar style using a wah pedal.
Eclectic mixture of influences from Jazz, Funk, Hip Hop, Soul, and House which rose to popularity in the 1990s.
Strongly mixed with traditional and more modern genres in sub-Saharan West Africa.
Variety of Funk born out of late 1970s British nightclubs.
Focuses more on grooves and rhythm than songwriting.
Dominated by drums and percussion (primarily congas) with heavily syncopated rhythms, bursts of horns, and call-and-response vocals.
Jazz highly influenced by Funk.
Funk combined with Hispanic American Music styles.
Features a "fat", monotonic drum sound, spaced-out synthesizers, "squelchy" basslines, tight, syncopated horns, and sometimes heavy guitars.
Primarily found in the soundtracks to Pornographic films of the 1970s.
Emerged in the late 1970s; replaces horns traditionally used in melodic segments with synthesizers, while often incorporating drum machines to augment the futuristic sound.

Emerged in late 1970s Minneapolis as a Synth Funk expansion characterized by glossy Contemporary R&B-influenced production techniques, angular New Wave-inspired rhythms, and a larger emphasis on electric guitar layers.
Increased rhythmic complexity with added focus on piano and horns.

Predominantly African American style that retains the defined backbeats, Blues chord progressions/melodies and passionate singing/shouting of Jump Blues, while appealing more to an urban audience with smaller bands and reduced Jazz influence.
A style infusing Rock and R&B that was hugely popular in the United Kingdom between 1963 and 1966.
Uniquely Cajun style of Rhythm & Blues distinguished by tripleted pianos and a slow Blues structure.
Simple, fast, and energetic dance popular in the early 1960s.

Originated in the African American culture of the 20th century, resulting from the combination of the ecstatic vocals of Gospel with the upbeat instrumentation of Rhythm & Blues, consisting of guitar, bass and percussion.
Combination of the hard, groove-oriented rhythms of Southern Soul and the sophisticated gloss of the Motown Sound which was developed in Chicago.
Combining the gritty horn-driven sound of Southern Soul with the textures and aesthetics of Country.
Draws on the typical Southern Soul groove and accentuates the Gospel and Blues influence, particularly Chicago Blues.
Soul combined with Hispanic American Music, such as Salsa and Mambo.
Emerged during the mid-to-late 1990s; defined by a combination of Soul with the rhythmic percussion and groove of Hip Hop.
Soul popular in northern England in the late 1960s and early 1970s, consisting primarily of lesser-known American artists in the mid-1960s copying the Motown Sound.
Defined by lush arrangements, often borrowing upon the orchestral instrumentation seen on productions from the 1960s, with the commercial atmosphere exemplified by Pop Soul and the Motown Sound.
Fusion of Pop and Soul; originated in the 1960s as an attempt to give soul crossover success.

Succinct, catchy song structures; complex arrangements; Gospel-influenced vocals; highly melodic and rhythmic bass lines; 4-4 drum patterns; often syncopated piano parts; regular use of horn and string sections; and historically a distinctive reverb and treble-heavy production.
Soul which incorporates the effects and instrumentation of Psychedelic Rock.
Slow tempo ballads with silky, often sensual, vocals and light, polished arrangements, creating an intimate, romantic atmosphere.
Soul primarily from the American South that was popular in the 1960s and 1970s, with a gritty and raw sound that places an emphasis on the groove, making it highly danceable.
Music of regional cultural traditions, that is or was predominantly played and produced in these regions.
All forms with roots in Africa.
Indigenous music of Africa that is passed down orally from generation to generation, the authors of the songs are usually unknown.
African Folk Music developed by the Yabassi people of Cameroon.
Yoruba Music developed by Muslims during the late 1930s and early 1940s in the Ijebu region of Yorubaland, the current Ogun state.
Tradition from Cape Verde, unusual among the islands' music due to its lack of polyphonic singing and its usage of polyrhythms.
Music of the Dagomba people of northern Ghana.
Mixture of Sub-Saharan African, Arabic, and Amazigh Music, created by the Gnawa, an ethnic minority group in North Africa, mainly Morocco.
Traditional Folk Music of the Kabye people of northern Togo, including some of the most singular styles that can be found in West Africa.
Tradition of the Bakongo people from Angola and Congo that has influenced contemporary styles such as Kuduro.
Melodic, chordophone-dominated sound; based on the Austronesian Traditional Music of the first settlers that arrived on the island from Borneo.
Music of the Mbenga and Mbuti people, Pygmy ethnic groups in Central Africa.
Tradition that originated in Seychelles among Creole slaves, similar to Séga, although rawer and played only on large flat drums made from goatskin.
Played in Swahili-speaking African countries; primarily focused on rhythm.
Traditional music from Zanzibar, traditionally played at women's initiation rituals and weddings.
Style from Angola featuring danceable percussion, lyrics often taking the form of a story, and sometimes accompaniment from a guitar.
Traditional Folk Music of southern Africa.
Musical traditions developed by the Afrikaner community in southern Africa.
Encompasses traditions of the Khoisan ethnic family groups.
Traditions of the Nguni ethnic family groups, a southern Bantu ethnicity.
Traditional style of the Shona people from Zimbabwe, based on a simple melodic pattern played on the mbira, from which long instrumental parts are improvised.
Traditional Folk Music of the Sotho-Tswana ethnic family groups from southern Africa.
Tradition from the central region of Benin around Savalou, played with water percussion.
Derived from Traditional Séga, this is the original dance music of La Réunion.
Séga dance music born in the 18th century, before its later adoption of Western pop elements.
Traditional rhythmic chanting and percussion adapted to multiple West African contexts in the 20th century.
African-styled percussion and rhythms.
Music developed in the archipelago of Cape Verde.
Tradition from Cape Verde, unusual among the islands' music due to its lack of polyphonic singing and its usage of polyrhythms.
Originated as a more uptempo and lively form of Morna before bringing in outside influences.
Upbeat Cape Verdean style which developed on the island of Santiago, based around the diatonic accordion and rhythm provided by the ferrinho.
Slow tempo, monotonality, and the use of the violão, the Cape Verdean classical guitar, as the main instrumental accompaniment.

Music of the areas speaking Adamawa-Eastern languages and many Bantu languages, through most of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, all of Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, the islands of São Tomé and Príncipe, Republic of the Congo, most of the Central African Republic, and large parts of Cameroon, Angola, and the northern parts of Zambia.
African Folk Music developed by the Yabassi people of Cameroon.
Music and dance of the Bassa people of southern Cameroon, which features a singer accompanied by a guitarist and improvised percussion.
Music of the Banda people, a Central African ethnic group mostly residing in the Central African Republic and its neighboring countries.

Most closely linked to the Bamileke people of the Western Province of Cameroon; drums and improvised maracas are the sole instrumentation backing up a vocalist who alternates between rapping and singing.
Developed from the Traditional Folk Music of the Ewondo people in Cameroon, with a name translating as "let's beat the earth" that comes from the stomping dance style that often accompanies it.
Originated when Congolese musical acts started to play music influenced by Cuban Music (specifically Son cubano), with it's heyday period being between the 1940s to early 1970s.
Features multiple rumba-like lead guitars and quick steady basslines, while mixing together elements of other percussion-heavy Zambian styles.
Tradition of the Bakongo people from Angola and Congo that has influenced contemporary styles such as Kuduro.
Combines elements of Angolan Semba and French Caribbean Zouk.
Heavy-hitting beats and electronic bass, putting less emphasis on melodies and vocals.
Angolan music combining traditional Kilapanga and Semba with Techno and House.
Initially developed in the late '80s in Luanda, Angola, as a mixture of Soca- and Zouk-based percussion samples.
Similar to Soukous, but makes more use of a horn section and bass rhythm.
Music of the Mbenga and Mbuti people, Pygmy ethnic groups in Central Africa.
Style from Angola featuring danceable percussion, lyrics often taking the form of a story, and sometimes accompaniment from a guitar.
Danceable, guitar-based style from the Congo area.
Faster form of Soukous that was pioneered in the late 1980s and early 1990s, named after a popular dance.
Updates traditional Congolese music with electric instrumentation.
Zambian 1970s Psychedelic Rock found mainly throughout the Copperbelt region.
Traditions which originate from the eastern subregion of the African continent, encompassing a wide variety of cultures and styles.
Kenyan popular music based around the Traditional Folk Music of the Luo people from the area.

Tanzanian genre originating in the mid-1990s in the Dar es Salaam area, combining the influence of Rhythm & Blues, Afrobeat, and Dancehall with native Tanzanian styles like Taarab and Muziki wa dansi.
Music of the Comoros Islands and Mayotte off the eastern coast of Africa, combining influences from other East African Music and Malagasy Music.
Combines elements of Dancehall with various traditions of Kenya.
Music of the Gogo People (Wagogo), who inhabit Central Tanzania.
Influential drumming style originating in Burundi carried out by a percussion ensemble.
Oldest form of mainstream music in Uganda, dating back to the early 1950s, translating to “one little guitar” from the Luganda language.
Includes elements from Hip Hop and Reggae, as well as Kenyan traditions.
Popular form of Ugandan music, originally derived from Kadongo kamu and Soukous.
Centered on two small kidumbak drums, fiddle, and singer; closely related to Taarab.
Fast, guitar driven, urban dance music from Mozambique that originated in Maputo in the 1950s, taking cues from Mozambican folk and a variety of foreign sounds.
Pairs amplified keyboards with hectic, intricate percussion and vocals drawn from earlier Tanzanian styles.
Popular in Tanzania with strong connections to Soukous and often associated with Jazz, whose name means "dance music" in Swahili.
Played in Swahili-speaking African countries; primarily focused on rhythm.
Traditional music from Zanzibar, traditionally played at women's initiation rituals and weddings.
Mid-20th century Kenyan popular music which centres around a fingerpicked acoustic guitar.
Developed in Tanzania in the mid-2000s; fuses incredibly rapid beats, usually between 180-300BPM, with MCing and musical influences from older Tanzanian genres.
Prominent violin, qanun (an Egyptian zither-like instrument), and sung Swahili poetry, often accompanied by African drums and other percussion.
Tradition of the Chopi people of the Inhambane province of Mozambique, named for the mbila, the wooden xylophone-like instrument on which it is played.
Music of Madagascar, including the most distinctive genres of the whole African continent.
A fusion of music from the highlands of Madagascar and western Operetta.
Melodic, chordophone-dominated sound; based on the Austronesian Traditional Music of the first settlers that arrived on the island from Borneo.
Features rich, harmonized vocals and chiming guitar lines.
Very fast and jerky rhythms, guitar duets, and polyharmonic chants.
Music of North Africa.
Arabic Folk Music from rural Morocco with piercing singing, scratchy viola, and rollicking hand drums.
Originates from the capital of Algeria, Algiers and features mournful vocals over an orchestral setting of violins, mandolins, pianos, and percussion.
Music of the Amazigh people, the indigenous people of Northwest Africa (with main hubs in Morocco and Algeria) and certain parts of West Africa.
Associated with the Tashelhit-speaking peoples of southern and central Morocco, and performed in large groups, combining singing, poetry and drumming.
Uses sung poetry with a focus on love themes.
Music of the Kabyle Amazigh people.
Music of the Sahrawi people, an ethnic group who inhabit the westernmost areas of the Sahara Desert.
Amazigh Music by the nomadic Tuareg people who live through the Saharan desert in North Africa, encompassing various types of traditions and popular styles.

Traditionally performed with a singer only accompanied by a guitar named tehardent, handclaps as percussion, and dancers; now usually performed by a band consisting of two tehardents, bass and solo, calabashes, a singer and dancers.
Electric guitar-led North African music emerging from traditional Tuareg Music in the 1980s.
Music of ancient Egyptian civilization.
Found primarily in the Andalusia region in southern Spain, generally thought to have beginnings in the Emirate of Cordoba during the period of Muslim control of the region in the 9th century.
Church music specifically made for worship in the Coptic (Egyptian) Orthodox Church.
Mixture of Sub-Saharan African, Arabic, and Amazigh Music, created by the Gnawa, an ethnic minority group in North Africa, mainly Morocco.
Moroccan sung poetry with instrumental accompaniment.
Music of the Moors, the largest ethnic group in Mauritania.
Upbeat style of Moroccan popular music played in streets, cafés, weddings, and festivals.
Originated in Algeria in the 1930s as a form of Bedoin Traditional Folk Music, blending influences from various rural and urban genres.
Fuses melodic sensibilities into the traditional Raï structure, with increased utilization of synthesizers, guitars, and drum machines.
Original folk of the popular Algerian Raï, combining various rural and cabaret styles with Bedouin rhythms.
Developed in Northern Africa during the early 1970s, typically created by and for the urban working class with witty lyrics that reflect this.
Draws elements from Hip Hop, featuring auto-tuned vocals, rapping, Electronic production, and explicit lyrics.
Combining Trap percussion and rhythms with major influences of Egyptian Shaabi, especially Mahraganat.
Music of Northeastern Africa.
Category for Ethiopic music serves for people who speak Ethiopian Semitic languages.
Ethiopian/Eritrean singer/songwriters or minstrels equivalent to the Western European bard, the West African griot or the Romanian wandering taraf.
Unique blend of traditional Ethiopic Music and Jazz.
Sacred tradition of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, sung in an ancient Semitic language called Ge'ez and credited with assembling the current Ethiopian notation system.
Melodic, devotional music performed by Sufi Islami communities in Ethiopia and neighboring countries
Music of the Tigrinya, an ethnic group mainly found in Eritrea and Northern Ethiopia, the Tigray region more specifically.
Melancholy song popular in Ethiopia and Eritrea, using the qegnet mode and tuning system.
Music of Nubia, a region centered along the Nile River in northern Sudan and southern Egypt.
Music of the Oromo people, a Cushitic ethnolinguistic group, who primarily live in the Oromia region of Ethiopia and Northern Kenya.
Music developed by the Somali people.
Song and dance that originally featured no instruments, but later transformed into a style featuring prominent rhythms and slow grooves.
Dates back to the 1940s and carries regional features such as the use of a pentatonic scale and having the oud as the primary instrument.
Styles from La Réunion, Mauritius, Rodrigues, and Seychelles.
Originated in slave communities on La Réunion; based on a call and response structure and use of traditional instruments.
Prominent in La Réunion island from the 1970s until the 1990s; drew influences from Funk, Psychedelia, and Afrobeat.
Derived from Traditional Séga, this is the original dance music of La Réunion.
Tradition that originated in Seychelles among Creole slaves, similar to Séga, although rawer and played only on large flat drums made from goatskin.
Emerged in Mauritius in the 1970s, blending the popular Séga style with outside influences.
Mascarene Islands and Seychelles genre featuring a distinctive 6/8 rhythm.
Fusion of Séga and Reggae, popular on Mauritius and other Mascarene Islands.
Séga dance music born in the 18th century, before its later adoption of Western pop elements.

Encompasses Southern African Folk Music and more modern genres, consisting in a specific style of a worldwide popular genre mixed with or rooted in a local traditional folk genre, through South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Eswatini, Namibia, southern Angola, and Matabeleland region in southern Zimbabwe.
House from South Africa deriving from previous popular genres including Gqom, Kwaito, and Deep House.
Blends the easy-going, poppy, and melodic Afrobeats sound and rhythms with major Amapiano elements, like lush, jazzy, and laid-back atmospheres often featuring light piano chords.
Emerged from the city of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe in the early 1950s, led by the alto sax and accompanied by ensembles.
Developed parallel to American Jazz in the early 20th century, named for its origin in Cape Town, South Africa.
Popular style from Zimbabwe based on the traditional mbira thumb piano, but with electric instrumentation as well.
Popular and danceable style from Lesotho and the surrounding Sotho-speaking region of South Africa, often featuring the accordion as the lead instrument.
Evolved from South African House, specifically Kwaito; often described as a more minimal and raw version.
A cappella Zulu style, which takes a softer, more melodious approach, in contrast to the powerful, loud sound of the earlier Mbube style.
Guitar-driven electric pop from Zimbabwe that draws influence from Central and East African rumba, South African jive and local music.
Emerged from South Africa in the early 1990s, taking influence from Disco and Hip Hop.
South African Jazz with origins in the 1920s and rooted in traditional South African music.
Influenced by Zulu music, characterized by its happy melodies, played by pennywhistle flutes and accompanied by a banjo or a guitar.
Emerged from the traditional Marabi Jazz and Swing as well as Kwela popular South African genres.
Zulu style of music usually led by a fingerpicked acoustic guitar.
A cappella Zulu genre, performed in a powerful and loud manner by an all-male choir.
South African genre with very fast BPM (around 180) featuring MIDI keyboard sounds and marimba.
Traditional Folk Music of southern Africa.
Musical traditions developed by the Afrikaner community in southern Africa.
Encompasses traditions of the Khoisan ethnic family groups.
Traditions of the Nguni ethnic family groups, a southern Bantu ethnicity.
Traditional style of the Shona people from Zimbabwe, based on a simple melodic pattern played on the mbira, from which long instrumental parts are improvised.
Traditional Folk Music of the Sotho-Tswana ethnic family groups from southern Africa.
Zimbabwean style combining the guitar work of Soukous with the speed and texture of Benga and the strong bass of Township Jive.
Synth-heavy Dance-Pop style popular in the South African townships in the 1980s and early 1990s.
Originating in the townships of South Africa, similar to Mbaqanga but bringing in Western pop elements.
Drum machines, synthesizers, and male vocals backed by a female choir, singing in a call and response style.
Traditional and regional popular music from the Western portion of Sub-Saharan Africa.
Merges West African styles such as traditional Yoruba Music and Highlife with elements of Funk and  Jazz, typically resulting in extended improvisatory jams with call-and-response vocals.
Strongly mixed with traditional and more modern genres in sub-Saharan West Africa.
Incorporates West African influences; initially emerged in the early 1970s.
Music of the Akan people of Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire, including a variety of traditional and neo-traditional styles which are based on some of the oldest traditions in West Africa.
Ivorian dance music combining traditional instruments and synthesizers that emerged in the late 1980s.
Emerged in the late 1990s in Mali; peaks at around 170BPM and prominently features looping, cut-up balafon samples.
Music of the Dagomba people of northern Ghana.
Music of the Ewe people, found in southern Togo, southeastern Ghana and southwestern Benin.
The national dance-drumming tradition of the Ewe people in Ghana.
War dance of the Ewe people utilizing various percussive instruments and polyrhythms.
The traditions of the Fon people, originating in central and southeastern Benin as well as the southwestern region of Nigeria.
Tradition from the central region of Benin around Savalou, played with water percussion.
Urban version of Tchinkoumé featuring traditional tchinkoumé rhythms, derived from zinli, and including contemporary instrumentation from the influence of R&B, Pop and Rock.
Traditional rhythmic chanting and percussion adapted to multiple West African contexts in the 20th century.

Music of the Fula, Fulani, or Fulɓe people, one of the largest ethnic groups in the Sahel region, present from the far West African countries of Senegal and Mauritania to Central African Cameroon with the biggest population located in Nigeria.
A type of hereditary professional caste in West African Music culture that preserves tradition.

Vocal and percussive tradition from Guinea-Bissau developed in the 1970s as a fusion of various traditional genres in the country; sometimes used as a catch-all term for the music of Guinea-Bissau in general.
Hausa are one of the largest ethnic groups in Africa, living mainly in northern Nigeria and southern Niger in west Africa.
Originally began along the Ghanaian coast in the 1920s as a blend of western brass band instrumentation and rhythms with traditional Akan Music and Dagomba Music.
Created by Ghanian immigrants to Germany in the late 1970s, generally employing synthesizers and Western post-production techniques alongside guitar-driven highlife instrumentation.
Fusion of Ghanaian Highlife with Hip Hop.
Music of the Igbo people, who live mainly in a region of southeastern Nigeria often known as "Igboland".
Traditional Folk Music of the Kabye people of northern Togo, including some of the most singular styles that can be found in West Africa.
Music of the Kru peoples indigenous to Liberia and Ivory Coast.
Created by the Bété people of Côte d'Ivoire, featuring a distinctive rhythm that uses polyrhythms and triplets.
Fusion of the African Folk Music of the region with imported Caribbean Calypso.
Ivorian mid-1970s dance music created after the country's independence, influenced by post-colonial trends in African Music.
Encompasses the diverse forms of the Mande peoples, a group of West African ethnic groups who speak any of the Mande languages.
Music of the Mossi people of Burkina Faso.
Music of the Songhai people of Mali, who descend from the ancient Songhai Empire which once ruled most of interior West Africa.
Traditionally sung by women and containing lyrics relating to women's issues such as childbearing and fertility.
Music of the Wolof people of Senegal and The Gambia comprising a wide variety of West African Music traditions influenced by nearby cultures.
Rooted in njuup, a Serer ritual tradition incorporating influences from Cuban, Congolese, and American popular music.
Rhythmic poetry that has been a part of Senegalese culture since ancient times.
Music of the Yoruba people of southwestern Nigeria and Benin, comprising a variety of ancient and modern traditions crucial to West African Music.
Yoruba Music developed by Muslims during the late 1930s and early 1940s in the Ijebu region of Yorubaland, the current Ogun state.
Combines the ajisaari/wéré tradition of improvisational music performed during Ramadan with other Islamic styles like Apala and sakara.
Yoruba Music that emerged during the 1920s in urban settings across Nigeria, especially in Lagos.
Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.
Islamic Yoruba Music originally rooted in Hausa traditions and adopted by the Yoruba in the early 19th century.
Ivorian dance music that began in the early 1990s, with socially conscious lyrics and driving rhythms.
Bass-heavy and minimal style of Ivorian popular dance music, drawing heavily from Zouglou and Congolese rhythms.

Umbrella term encompassing all the genres coming after the Prehistoric Music and before the Medieval music eras from ancient civilizations, roughly before 500 CE, following the Western Classical Music point of view with the date of the Roman Empire fall (476 CE).
Covers a very large era of creation from approximately 2100 BCE to 200 CE.
Music of ancient Egyptian civilization.
Music of ancient Greek civilization.
Reconstruction of Jerusalem temple music.
Music of ancient Roman civilization.
One of the most common and oldest surviving forms of Korean court music.
Music of Mesopotamia, a historical region situated in West Asia within the Tigris–Euphrates river system, comprises the heritage of Sumerians and Akkadians.
Originating with and primarily performed by the Arabic people.
Originates from the capital of Algeria, Algiers and features mournful vocals over an orchestral setting of violins, mandolins, pianos, and percussion.
Arabic Classical Music tradition, whose guidelines for modulation, rhythm, and tuning were set down in treatises in the 8th and 9th centuries, based around Islamic Modal Music.
Found primarily in the Andalusia region in southern Spain, generally thought to have beginnings in the Emirate of Cordoba during the period of Muslim control of the region in the 9th century.
Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific maqam modes.
Poetic vocal form with complex rhythms, emotive singing, and distinctive lute-backed melodies commonly found in the Gulf region and based on a maqam system.
Traditional Folk Music of the Arabic people.
Arabic Folk Music from rural Morocco with piercing singing, scratchy viola, and rollicking hand drums.
Accompaniment to traditional belly dances.
Blending of Arabic Music and Jazz.
Synthesis of Arabic Music with Western Pop melodies, almost always sung in Arabic and typically performed with Arabic instruments, alongside some Western instruments like the guitar.

Popular music of the Arab world from the first half of the 20th century, with little Western influence; melodic lines are taken from Arabic Folk Music and Arabic Classical Music, and strong emphasis is placed on vocal abilities; single works often include long stretches of singing accompanied by large symphonic string ensembles.

Sung free-verse poetry in Sundanese language, usually by a solo vocalist, accompanied by a mellow-sounding Kacapi suling ensemble.
Emerged from the royal courts of Central Thailand around the 13th century, based on a traditional Thai sound-scale of seven tempered notes.
Traditional performance music originating in northern Thailand consist of an ensemble with Piphat instruments and a pair of female choreographers.
Thai Classical Music emphasizing string instruments while also incorporating other kinds of instruments to enrich the sound.
Led by wind and percussion instruments, with ensembles ranging from 6 to 10 instruments.
Meta-genre covering all folk forms from Southeast Asia, like Gondang, Hmong, Iban, Karen, Keroncong, Khmer, Lao, Lun Bawang, Molam, and Orang Ulu.
Folk originating in the Visayas islands of the Philippines; dialogue or debate in which a man and a woman compete at improvising romantic verses.
Traditional Folk Music of the majority ethnic group of Myanmar.
Traditional ensemble in Bataknese traditional music of North Sumatra, taking its name from its leading instrument - a unique set of toned drums.
Traditions of the various tribal ethnic groups residing in the hills of Mainland Southeast Asia and Southwest China, also known as the region of Zomia.
Folk traditions of the Hmong people, an ethnic group localized in Laos, Vietnam, China, and Thailand.
Folk of the Khmer people, who mainly reside in Cambodia.
Accompanies a traditional Javanese dance of the same name, featuring a stripped-back version of a Gamelan ensemble that removes softer instruments.
Traditional Filipino love songs usually sung in Tagalog.
Traditional Folk Music of the Lao people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Malay people, who are native to Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, northern Indonesia, and southern Thailand.
Traditional Folk Music of the Thai people.
Traditional performance music originating in northern Thailand consist of an ensemble with Piphat instruments and a pair of female choreographers.
Burmese Pop Rock genre which emerged in the mid-1960s.
Music of the Thai people.
Ballads influenced by Jazz styles like Swing and Big Band, as well as Hispanic American Music infused with Thai melodic and rhythmic sensibilities.
Unifies the danceable rhythms heard in Chachachá, Salsa, foxtrot and beguine into a Thai context.
Slow tempo and vibrato singing, featuring a fusion of traditional Thai instrumentation, rhythms, and melodies with influences from Japan, Indonesia, Latin America, and the United States.
Modernized form featuring a faster pace and mostly electric instrumentation.
Political Thai Folk Rock born out of the 1973 student uprising, with a name translating to "songs for life".
Emerged from the royal courts of Central Thailand around the 13th century, based on a traditional Thai sound-scale of seven tempered notes.
Traditional performance music originating in northern Thailand consist of an ensemble with Piphat instruments and a pair of female choreographers.
Thai Classical Music emphasizing string instruments while also incorporating other kinds of instruments to enrich the sound.
Led by wind and percussion instruments, with ensembles ranging from 6 to 10 instruments.
Traditional Folk Music of the Thai people.
Traditional performance music originating in northern Thailand consist of an ensemble with Piphat instruments and a pair of female choreographers.
Small, short-lived guitar Pop movement in Thailand in the 1960s, fusing Surf Rock  with local melodies.
Music of the Vietnamese people.
Romantic Vietnamese popular music, originating from standards mixing Latin American Bolero with local music.
Blends classical Vietnamese Opera with southern Vietnamese Folk Music and colonial French spoken melodrama.
Vietnamese revolutionary music, which may contain elements of Western Classical Music, Bolero Việt Nam, and Vietnamese Folk Music, and usually political and war themed-lyrics.
Made largely from the 1950s till the 1970s; introspective and sentimental lyrical themes.
Traditional court music of Vietnam, often performed by a twelve-instrument ensemble (for Dai Nhac music) or a fourteen-instrument ensemble (for Nha Nhac music).
Sung poetry from northern Vietnam, performed by a female vocalist to the accompaniment of a three-stringed lute and percussion.
Classical musical theatre and its associated form of Vietnamese Classical Music, related strongly to Chinese Opera.
Traditional Folk Music of the Vietnamese people, with traditions influenced by both Chinese Music and Austronesian culture through the Cham people.
Northern Vietnamese folk musical theatre, characterized by minimal set design and satirical content.
Tradition of the Northern Vietnamese provinces of Bắc Ninh and Bắc Giang, originally consisting of harmonic, a cappella singing from two competing duos.
Developed in Northern Vietnam, traditionally sung by blind bards accompanied by a đàn bầu or đàn nhị.
Singaporean Mandarin-language style, generally featuring harmonised group vocals and backed mainly by acoustic guitar.
Music of West Asia, a region covering most of what is commonly known as the Middle East but not extending into North Africa.
Music of Armenia.
One of the oldest branches of Christian culture, this is the predominantly vocal music of the Armenian Apostolic Church.
Traditional Folk Music of the Armenians, which is attested in historic Armenia since antiquity, with unique regional dialects unified by general melodic structure.
Dance-oriented Armenian American music with prominent presence of Anatolian instruments and folkloric melodies (often in the 10/8 meter) paired with novel lyrics relating to a variety of topics.
Elements of Armenian folk in its instrumentation, oftentimes incorporating influences from Arabic and other West Asian forms on a background of synthesizer arrangements.
Music of the Azerbaijani people, who inhabit the modern day country of Azerbaijan, along with a significant population in the neighboring country of Iran.
Highly improvisational form of modal music characterized by the singing style and the themes of Azerbaijan’s history.
Azerbaijani folk recitative genre.
Music of the Baloch people.
Music of the region of the Caucasus, a mountainous region bordered by Russia to the north and Turkey/Iran to the south, with the Black and Caspian seas to its sides.
Folk of the Caucasus region, a mountainous area that connects Eastern Europe to Asia.
Traditions of the Republic of Abkhazia, a disputed territory on the Black Sea in northwestern Georgia.
Folk of the Chechens, a Northeast Caucasian ethnic group predominantly living in the Republic of Chechnya, a federal subject of Russia.

Folk of the native Circassian peoples of Northern Caucasus, residing in the Republics of Adygea, Karachay-Cherkessia, and Kabardino-Balkaria respectively, which are federal subjects of the Russian Federation, as well as the territories of the former Ottoman Empire, with a significant diaspora population in modern Turkey.
Traditional Folk Music of the Dagestani people.
Traditional Folk Music of the Avar people.
Traditions of the Georgian people, who mostly live in Georgia.
Folk music of Ossetians, an ethnic group that mainly inhabits a region located on both sides of the Greater Caucasus Mountains.
Elements of Armenian folk in its instrumentation, oftentimes incorporating influences from Arabic and other West Asian forms on a background of synthesizer arrangements.
Fast-paced dance and music style, most commonly performed in the Levant.
The musical traditions of the Druze people.
Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific maqam modes.
Paraliturgical songs of Sephardi Jews who lived in Ottoman Empire.
Music of Mesopotamia, a historical region situated in West Asia within the Tigris–Euphrates river system, comprises the heritage of Sumerians and Akkadians.

Middle Eastern-flavored Israeli popular music, usually performed by Mizrahi Jews, and combining aspects of the music of the North African, Middle Eastern, and Central Asian countries from which they descended.
Music of the Persian people.
Iranian dance music, often festive and energetic and set in 6/8, that traditionally makes primary use of Iranian bagpipes (ney-anbān).
Traditional art music of the Persian civilization.
Traditional Folk Music of the Persian people.
Hybrid of Iranian and Persian-language popular music with Western instruments such as the guitar, drum kit, and synthesizer.
Traditions developed by the Turkish people.
Turkish Rock with elements of Turkish Folk Music.
Arabic-style productions by Turkish musicians, who also draw influence from their native forms, including Turkish Folk Music, Balkan Music, and Byzantine Music.
Incorporates influences from Turkish Classical Music and Turkish Folk Music within a more accessible, commercial, and unorthodox context.
Songs performed at the Tuluat Theaters of İstanbul in the late 19th century.
Considered the oldest military marching band in the world; instruments used are cymbals, trumpet, kös drum, kettle drum, naqareh, bells, and cevgen.
Expansion of Turkish Folk Music with overtones from contemporary genres.
Classical music of Turkey, which uses the makam modal system, with the primary emphasis often being on the singers, who are accompanied by small ensembles.
Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.
Traditional Folk Music of Turkish people combines the distinct cultural heritages and traditions of Anatolian civilisations and former Ottoman territories.

children.nodeName: Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Turkish people who inhabit the northern region by the Black Sea.
Semi-improvisational melodic structure in Turkish Folk Music.
Turkish Folk Music music and dance that originated with the Zeybek people during the Ottoman Empire period, with slow and asymmetrical rhythms.
Started in the late 1950s, when Turkish artists started to write their own lyrics to Western popular tunes.

Traditional Folk Music of West Asia, a region that covers much of what is commonly known in English as the Middle East (alternatively Southwestern Asia), includes the distinct but interconnected traditions of numerous ethnic groups.
Anatolian folk pioneered by Turkish poets and bards, connected to the Alevist heterodox Islamic tradition.
Traditional Folk Music of the Armenians, which is attested in historic Armenia since antiquity, with unique regional dialects unified by general melodic structure.
Dance-oriented Armenian American music with prominent presence of Anatolian instruments and folkloric melodies (often in the 10/8 meter) paired with novel lyrics relating to a variety of topics.

Folk of the Assyrian or Syriac people, who are indigenous to the Upper Mesopotamian region roughly corresponding to ancient Assyria (which includes modern-day northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, northeastern Syria, and southeastern Turkey).
Folk of the Jewish settlers of Eretz Yisra'el.

Traditional Folk Music of the Kurds, an Iranian people who traditionally inhabit the mountainous region of the Middle East comprising southeastern Turkey, northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, and northeastern Syria.
Traditional Folk Music of the Luri people of southwestern Iran.
Azerbaijani folk recitative genre.
Traditional Folk Music of the Persian people.
Traditional Folk Music of Turkish people combines the distinct cultural heritages and traditions of Anatolian civilisations and former Ottoman territories.

children.nodeName: Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Turkish people who inhabit the northern region by the Black Sea.
Semi-improvisational melodic structure in Turkish Folk Music.
Turkish Folk Music music and dance that originated with the Zeybek people during the Ottoman Empire period, with slow and asymmetrical rhythms.
Meta-genre covering all forms with roots in the Caribbean region.
Romantic dance and accompanying music originating in the Dominican Republic, featuring arpeggiated chords in the melody.
Afro-Colombian popular genre which features a strong emphasis on rhythm and improvisation and a call-and-response format.
Genre from Trinidad and Tobago featuring a brass section and percussion.
Genre derived from Trinidadian Calypso, popular in the eastern region of Venezuela and associated with Carnival.
Fusion of Calypso and Ska originating in Barbados during the 1960s and 70s.
Meta-genre that covers the different forms of Traditional Folk Music from the Caribbean.
Drum-based folkdance with a strong Afro-influence, conducted by duos of dancers and accompanied by call-and-response singing, particularly popular in Martinique, Dominica and Trinidad and Tobago.
Traditional music of Antigua & Barbuda, using call-and-response and bawdy lyrics.
Percussive style from Puerto Rico, generally considered to be derived from West Africa.
Traditional Folk Music native to the Virgin Islands, named after a local dish which features a "mixed-up" flavor that can be compared to the style that combines Western instruments with local ones.
Folk of Garifunas, Caribbean people born from escaped African slaves and local Caribbean natives.
Form of rhythmic performance by Haitian Vodou practitioners, played at associated ceremonies.
Traditions of the mountain-dwelling jibaro people that live primarily in Puerto Rico.
Cayman Islands music played during kitchen dance parties, centered around fiddle and percussion (handmade or kitchen grater) playing.
Jamaican folk originating in the late 19th century which brought together African and European elements, going on to influence the rhythm in Reggae.
Haitian genre that dates back to the early 19th century; the roots of Compas.
Folk genre from Puerto Rico played with hand drums called panderetas.
Indigenous style of the Turks and Caicos Islands, featuring a handsaw as the primary instrument.

Trinidadian folk considered to be the precursor of Calypso, led by (mostly female) singers called chantwells, who sing derogatory lyrics to the sound of drums and guitars in a call-and-response manner in order to rebel against slaveowners.
African-style percussion alongside Latin influences and often explicit lyrics.
Folk of the Virgin Islands, sung exclusively by women to the beat of one or two drums.
Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.
Encompasses the wide variety of traditions from the island of Cuba.
Ballroom dance music derived from Danzón.
One of the oldest popular Cuban styles, originating in the 19th century with slaves that worked in sugar refineries near Baracoa who combined elements of Spanish popular songs with Bantu traditions.
Evolved alongside Rumba cubana in the late 19th century, featuring large and heterogenous percussion sections performing simple and syncopated rhythms alongside a small wind section.
Played by traditional Cuban ensembles, influenced by Son cubano but performed on European instruments such as piano, bass, violins, and flutes.
Vocal delivery is often heavily auto-tuned and layered with adlibs, rhythm is syncopated, and Caribbean and African instrumentation is incorporated.

Development on Habanera in 2/4 time, featuring African influence through complex cross-rhythms, that would become the most popular style of dance music in Cuba during the late 19th century and early 20th century.
Cuban genre consisting of improvised jam sessions incorporating elements of Jazz and Afro-Cuban music.
Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of Vocal Jazz.
Originally developed in Cuba between the 18th and 19th Century as a narrative style influenced by Tonada chilena.
Humorous song with short notes and a fast tempo that commonly alternates a short fourth line verse with a repeated fourth line chorus.
Based around the Habanera rhythm, where the most typical instruments used are guitars, lutes, and bandurrias.
Dance-oriented evolution from Danzón during the late 1930s.
Cuban genre featuring energetic, African-influenced percussion.
Combination of Merengue, Conga, Rumba cubana, and Cumbia; fast, festive, and playful.
Featuring rhythms described as mimicking those created while pounding sugarcane with African baton-like tools.
Folkloric manifestation of Afro-Cuban music that encompasses dance, voice, and drums.
Emerged after the abolition of slavery in Cuba in 1886; usually features a lead singer, accompanied by three large drums, known as tumbadoras or congas, and a call-and-response chorus.
Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.
Cuban style popular from the 1920s to the 1950s that combines the structure of Spanish song-oriented styles with African rhythms and percussion.
Blend of Bolero and Son cubano that appeared during the 1920s.
Cuban style originating in the 1970s, combining elements from Rumba cubana and Son cubano with Jazz and Funk.
Combines Salsa with other genres such as Hip Hop, Disco, Funk, Jazz and Rock.
One of the most ancient expressions of Cuban Music, based around lone singer/songwriters who use nothing but a guitar as their preferred accompaniment and place emphasis on lyrics.
Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.
Combination of traditional music from Benin with French ballroom dancing that originates in the Oriente province (formerly Santiago de Cuba Province) in Cuba.
Originated in the Dominican Republic during the early 1990s, featuring rapping indebted to Hip Hop and a style drawing on Dancehall, particularly the "Dem Bow" riddim.
Music from the French Antilles (Martinique, Guadeloupe, Dominica, Saint Lucia) and from Haiti.
Dating back to the 19th century; originating as a fusion of traditional Bele music with Polka.
With a name translating to "broth", this fast-paced genre from Dominica originated as a blend of various traditional and modern Caribbean styles.
Caribbean genre originating in the 1970s, combining elements of Haiti's Cadence rampa and Compas with Trinidad's Calypso.

Developed in Saint Lucia in the early 2010s; heavily influenced by Angolan Kuduro, as well as incorporating elements of Zouk and Lucian drums alongside suggestive lyrics usually sung in Kwéyòl (Saint Lucian Creole).
Developed in the island of Guadeloupe; driven by a group of gwo ka drums.
Encompasses the styles of music developed by the Haitian people.
Developed in parallel with Compas, based on Méringue with a stronger Cuban influence.
Popular genre from Haiti, updating the older Méringue style with influences from Mambo and Jazz.
Form of rhythmic performance by Haitian Vodou practitioners, played at associated ceremonies.
Haitian genre that dates back to the early 19th century; the roots of Compas.
Features a fast-paced rhythm inspired by Rara, with Electronic instrumentation and humorous sexual and political lyrics.
Derived from the Haitian Vodou Drumming tradition, often played at street festivals and carnivals and usually having celebratory or political lyrics.
Blends the highly rhythmic drumming of traditional Haitian Vodou music with Rock-influenced electric instrumentation such as guitar, keyboard, and bass.
Combines Haitian Compas, Soukous and Cuban Guaguancó with the local style of Biguine.
Fast-paced danceable pop that began in early 1980s French Antilles, merging and updating more traditional local genres.
Popular in Cape Verde and the Cape Verdean diaspora in Europe and North America, with a slow and sensuous tempo, and favoring more sophisticated studio productions.
More sentimental form of Zouk which emerged in the mid-1980s.
Bahamian music centered around the drum known as the goombay, a sort of membranophone.
Music of the Indo-Caribbean diaspora.
Indo-Caribbean genre from Suriname, consisting of Bhojpuri Folk Music with local Caribbean influence.
Indo-Caribbean genre developing as a fusion of Bhojpuri Folk Music with traditional Caribbean songs; later influenced by Calypso, Soca and Filmi.
Mixture of Soca rhythms with Chutney's Indo-Caribbean traits and instrumentation.

Regional music of Jamaica ranges from its cultural origins in traditional and religious folk of the late 19th and early 20th centuries to the international popularity of Reggae from the 1970s onwards.
Developed from Reggae in the late 1970s, when Roots Reggae became more stripped-down, with an increased emphasis on pure rhythm.
Originating in the Netherlands in the late 1980s, fusing sped-up Dancehall with Dutch Antillean music and contemporary Dutch rave.
First, pre-Ragga style of Dancehall to popularize Electronic rhythms that arose in the mid-1980s.
Largely instrumental; infused with Electronic Dance Music elements.
Hardcore style with a deejay (equivalent to an MC in Hip Hop) rapping over predominantly Electronic rhythms.
French Caribbean Dancehall subgenre with a focus on sparse percussion, heavy basslines and lyrics revolving around partying and sensuality, often in Creole.

Trinidadian style that originated in the country's slums in the late 2010s, defined by its sexual, violent, and occasionally gang-related lyrics and its influence from Soca, as well as occasional influences from Hip Hop and Funk brasileiro.
Originated in Jamaica with groups who combined Jazz and Rhythm & Blues with rhythms of traditional Caribbean Music like Mento and Calypso.
Jamaican folk originating in the late 19th century which brought together African and European elements, going on to influence the rhythm in Reggae.
Performed at Rastafari religious ceremonies, consisting of tripartite hand-drumming and often accompanied by vocal chants.
4/4 time signature, offbeat rhythms, the organ shuffle or "bubble", and staccato guitar (or piano) chords known as "skank"; developed out of Rocksteady in the late 1960s in Jamaica.
Reggae in which a deejay (similar to an MC in Hip Hop) talks or chants lyrics over a pre-recorded reggae rhythm.
First, pre-Ragga style of Dancehall to popularize Electronic rhythms that arose in the mid-1980s.
Primarily instrumental Reggae which developed from the extensive use of studio techniques and effects like reverb and delay.
Mixes contemporary influences (especially Electronic) with the traditional Dub sound.
Smooth, quiet Reggae beats with lyrics focusing on romance and love.
Developed in Pacific island communities, incorporating elements from local Oceanian Music styles.
Light, commercial form of Reggae designed to crossover and break through to a more mainstream Pop audience.
Primarily defined through the political, spiritual, and socially conscious messages of its lyrics.
Performance of Poetry over Reggae and Dub rhythms, which originated in Jamaica in the 1970s.
Fusion of Séga and Reggae, popular on Mauritius and other Mascarene Islands.
Rough sounding and fast-paced, using brass modestly, with lyrics reflecting views on work, football, beer, and bovver.
Jamaican popular music that blossomed briefly between 1966 and 1968 as an evolution of Ska, being slower, more relaxed, and soulful.
Highly rhythmic Bahamian style which traditionally accompanies the arts festival and street parade of the same name.
Surinamese popular music with roots in Surinamese Creole music, which was influenced by folk traditions of Africa, Europe, and the Americas.
Dominican Republic dance genre that had a commercial boom at the end of the 1980s.
Rhythmically simpler and more eclectic style, absorbing influences from Hip Hop, Reggaetón, and other modern genres, particularly in regards to vocals.
Colombian genre which combines Cumbia with Merengue.
Earliest, most stripped-down form of Merengue.
Popularized by Dominican-American artists of the 1990s, blending modern Merengue with electronic instrumentation and the combination of rapping/singing vocals.
Fuses basic Merengue rhythms with influences from Cumbia and Lambada, being largely synthesized, with live instruments usually limited to percussion and brass.
Latin-Caribbean genre central to Trinidad and Tobago and Venezuela traditionally used for nighttime celebrations in Trinidadian towns.
Lively Hispanic American Music and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.
Garifuna music with influences from other Caribbean genres such as Reggae, Soca, and Zouk, as well as Hispanic American Music.
Upbeat, poppy and danceable style rooted in Calypso and Indo-Caribbean Music; developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s in Trinidad and Tobago.
A highly energetic, Dancehall-influenced form of Soca developed in Barbados featuring dancefloor-oriented lyrics delivered in an aggressive chanting style.
Mixture of Soca rhythms with Chutney's Indo-Caribbean traits and instrumentation.

Developed in Saint Lucia in the early 2010s; heavily influenced by Angolan Kuduro, as well as incorporating elements of Zouk and Lucian drums alongside suggestive lyrics usually sung in Kwéyòl (Saint Lucian Creole).
Often at a tempo of 160 BPM and incorporating hard, frantic rhythms, highly synthesized production, and call-and-response vocals.
Fusion of Soca and Hip Hop unique to Trinidad and Tobago.
Colombian scene born in the early 2000s with the intention of reinventing Colombian coastal music, from a more current and experimental approach.
Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.
Traditionally accompanies church services, as well as extra-liturgical functions such as processionals and sermons.
Simple, harmonized, English-language setting of the Christian liturgy, principally devised by the Anglican Church.
One of the oldest branches of Christian culture, this is the predominantly vocal music of the Armenian Apostolic Church.
Liturgical chant of Christian churches following the Orthodox rite.
Church music specifically made for worship in the Coptic (Egyptian) Orthodox Church.
Sacred tradition of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, sung in an ancient Semitic language called Ge'ez and credited with assembling the current Ethiopian notation system.
Chant form inspired by Znamenny Chant that's characterized by simplified melodic and rhythmic structures.
Composition for choir, with or without instrumental accompaniment, that sets to music text from the liturgy of the Eucharist, principally from the Latin rites of the Roman Catholic Church.
Musical setting commemorating the deceased with text usually derived from the Roman Catholic mass of the dead.
Monophonic chanting in the context of Roman Catholic and modern Anglican liturgy.
Liturgical chant practiced in parts of Italy and Switzerland, characterized by stepped melodic progression.
Extinct plainchant tradition of Southern Italy characterized by lengthy melodies, extensive use of repetition, and a steady, undulating progression.
Iberian form of plainchant that flourished roughly 550-1085 AD.
Liturgical, monophonic chant that accompanied Mass and other rituals in Western Christianity.
Plainchant tradition of Medieval Rome that was closely related to Gregorian Chant, though often more musically ornate.
Tradition of the Russian Orthodox Church, implemented with the Christianization of Kievan Rus' in 988.
Composition for unaccompanied choir, set to sacred texts of Eastern Orthodox tradition.
Prototypical liturgical chant of the Russian Orthodox Church.
Unaccompanied, rhythmically free-flowing psalm singing in Gaelic practiced by Presbyterian churches, which involves a call-and-response between the precentor and the congregation.
Liturgical chant repertoire practiced within Syriac Christianity, comprising the East Syrian and West Syrian liturgical rites.
Regional styles with roots in the European continent and surrounding islands.
Mixes Hard Rock and Blues Rock with traditional Alpine Folk Music elements such as Yodeling and use of the accordion.
Music of ancient Roman civilization.
Simple, harmonized, English-language setting of the Christian liturgy, principally devised by the Anglican Church.
Encompasses the various traditions and genres of the Ashkenazi Jews, an ethnoreligious group that was prominent and influential in Europe throughout most of the Middle Ages and the modern period.
Secular Ashkenazi Music traditionally used in ceremonies such as weddings and bar mitzvahs.
Traditional folk developed in Ashkenazi Jewish communities, particularly those of Yiddish-speaking Eastern and Central Europe.
Meta-genre covering all forms developed in the Balkan Peninsula.
Traditional Folk Music of the Balkan region of Southeastern Europe.
Traditional Folk Music of Albania, including the area's traditions as well as influence from Turkish Music.
One of several genres of iso-polyphonic music performed in southern Albania, with "iso" referring to the distinctive drone voice used.
Tradition in Albania consisting of light, commercial, amplified Albanian Folk Music usually professionally arranged and manufactured in recording studios alongside video clips.
Polyphonic singing in the Toskëri region of southern Albania.
Traditional Folk Music of the Aromanians.
Balkan Folk Music played by brass bands.
Traditional Folk Music of the Bosnians.
Polyphonic vocal music that developed in Bosnia in the 20th century, bearing connections to traditional Bosnian genres.
A melancholic folk song, originating from Bosnia and Herzegovina, typically love-themed and accompanied by instruments like guitar and accordion.
Consists of a variety of traditions and styles, with distinct sounds originating from current and historical regions such as Sofia, Dobrudzha, Macedonia and Thrace.
Traditional Folk Music of the Croats.
Traditional form characteristic of the Dalmatia region of Croatia rooted in littoral church singing.

Folk of the Csango, an ethnic minority group with Hungarian origins living primarily in the Romanian Moldavia region, but who are also found in the Transylvania, Dobruja, Moldova, the Ukrainian Chernivtsi region, and the Tolna region of Hungary.
Gagauz people are a Turkic group living mostly in the southern Gagauzia region of Moldova, but also nearby areas like southwestern Ukraine and southeastern Romania.
Dissonant form of polyphonic singing from the regions of Herzegovina and Dalmatia.
Greek folk traditions.
Music of the Greek Aegean Islands.
Folk of the Greek island Crete.
Some of the oldest and most important types of vocal music on the Cretan island, characterized by its dramatic style of singing.
Traditional Folk Music of the Greek mainland, often using clarinet, guitar, tambourine, and violin as accompaniment, while also incorporating various forms of Greek dance and vocal music.
Traditional Folk Music from the Ionian Islands in Greece.
Greek tradition originating in traditional Mikrasiatiki and Smyrnaiki music with elements of other local traditional Greek genres.
Folk music of Macedonians, a South Slavic ethnic group who are primarily associated with the Republic of Macedonia.
Urban folk from Macedonia very popular in the 19th and 20th centuries performed by ensembles called Čalgii.
Traditional folk music of Montenegro.
Strongly influenced by folk from Turkey, Russia, and Western Europe, and even by Byzantine Church music.
Traditional Folk Music of the Serbian people.
Translated as "old city music", this is the urban traditional music of Macedonia and Serbia.
Urban folk from Macedonia very popular in the 19th and 20th centuries performed by ensembles called Čalgii.
Balkan popular music which blends Pop, Folk, and ethnic music.
Bulgarian blend of Contemporary Folk (Turkish, Bulgarian, Arabic & Romani) with Dance-Pop.
Mixture of Romanian Music with Turkish, Middle Eastern, Balkan, and Romani influences, usually electronic in production.
Laiki music mixed with popular Western music, most notably pop and dance.
Tradition in Albania consisting of light, commercial, amplified Albanian Folk Music usually professionally arranged and manufactured in recording studios alongside video clips.
Appeared in the 1980s, incorporating modern instruments and based on the model of Balkan Pop-Folk in neighboring countries.
Greek popular artists who used more Arabian elements; originally a derogatory term used to refer to a more decadent side of Laika.
Mixture of Romani, Greek, Turkish, Albanian, and Slavic music, which incorporates Dance-Pop elements, and is very popular in Albania and Kosovo.
Originated in Serbia during the 1980s, fusing traditional Western Balkan Folk Music with elements of contemporary popular music.
First appeared in Greece in the late 1950s, featuring orchestrated arrangements with influence from Greek Folk Music and the popular Laika style.
Artistic side of Laika played mainly but not always with the basic instruments of it, the bouzouki, Greek baglama, and the jouras, sometimes with the accompaniment of orchestras.
First appeared in the middle of the 1960s, rooted in Entechna, taking major inspiration from French Chanson.
Greek popular music played with local instruments like the bouzouki, Greek baglama, and the jouras.
Artistic side of Laika played mainly but not always with the basic instruments of it, the bouzouki, Greek baglama, and the jouras, sometimes with the accompaniment of orchestras.
Laiki music mixed with popular Western music, most notably pop and dance.
Greek popular artists who used more Arabian elements; originally a derogatory term used to refer to a more decadent side of Laika.
Expressive and poetic Romanian style, generally sung similar to a Chanson and composed for piano and guitar orchestral arrangements.
Style of popular music from former Yugoslavia that incorporates elements of Mexican Music.
English reaction to the Italian Opera styles with a satirical sense of humor and scores borrowing from Traditional Folk Music and popular music.
Constant rhythmic flow, or a steady motion throughout, generally focusing on a single melodic idea and including some form of counterpoint.
Principally French style of musical drama that combines operatic singing with classical dance, usually with small Orchestral accompaniment.
Earliest form that draws from a broad range of artistic sources, including theater, operatic singing, instrumental music, dance, popular music, poetry, and comedy.
Collection of varied dance pieces, usually in the same key, structured on the music of European courtly dances.
The music of Great Britain, including the music of the English, Welsh and Scottish people.
An ensemble consisting of a standardized range of brass and percussion instruments whose performances are based on the British tradition established in the early 19th century.
Came from the dancehalls of the 1920s and 1930s, combining a British take on Jazz with the Music Hall tradition.
Developed in the late 1960s; influenced by traditional British folk music, particularly English Folk Music.
Musical traditions developed by the Cornish people, mainly found in the county of Cornwall in South West England.
Musical traditions of the English people, primarily divided into dance music and folksongs.
Traditional folk of Northumbria, a region of Northern England consisting of Northumberland and County Durham.
Usually humorous music originating from England's West Country, heavily featuring traditional English folk instruments and often sung in the West Country accent.
British theatrical entertainment popular in the 19th and 20th centuries, featuring light and comedic popular songs.
Traditional Folk Music of the Scottish people.

Flamenco of Andalusia in southern Spain, rooted in traditional music and dances and developed mostly after the 18th century by the Romani people of Andalusia (known locally as gitanos).
Traditional religious praise song that originated in Andalusia, Spain towards the end of the late Middle Ages.
Named after the city of Seville in Spain, typically rhythmic with a 3/4 beat and guitar accompaniment.
Traditional Folk Music of the Aragonese people.
Traditions of the Spanish province of Asturias.
Traditional folk of the Canary Islands.

Spanish variant of schottisch, a slow version of German Polka which developed through the incorporation of regional folk influences and an association with the local castizo culture in Madrid, the capital of Spain.
Evolved from Spanish theatrical styles like Cuplé and has strong links to Flamenco.
Originally developed in the 19th century as a blend of old theatre Spanish styles based in short monologues (jácara and tonadilla) and French Couplet.
Traditional music of the Galician people.
Mainly instrumental Spanish style primarily associated with bullfighting and popular celebrations, believed to originate from a double-time military march from France in the 18th century.
Blend of the themes and singing style of Rumba flamenca with the most commercial forms of House, Techno, and Makina.

French Opera genre developed by Jean-Baptiste Lully and Philippe Quinault in the second half of the 17th century, consisting of alterations made to the coeval Italian format to better fit the French language and please an audience more accustomed to the ballet de cour.
Associated with the tramping lifestyle that emerged in the former Czechoslovakia; inspired by American Country, Western and Bluegrass, albeit with a strong Czech cultural influence.
Developed in Italy around the turn of the 20th century and favored melodramatic realism, a rejection of bel canto standards, and declamatory singing.
Nordic balladry focusing on lyrical content and simple vocal melodies.
Typically in a 3/4 time signature and popular in the 18th century in central Europe, as it accompanied the ballroom dance of the same name.
Brazillian Waltz characterized by its slow rhythms and romantic sound.
Arising from vocal Christian tradition often featuring emotive performances, layered accompaniments, and themes of faith and salvation.
Traditional Country that heavily incorporates Gospel.
Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.
Focused on instrumentals and played on the steel guitar.
Initially sung A cappella by a Vocal Group quartet, sometimes with a pianist or guitar as accompaniment, with lyrics and messages primarily revolving around the teachings found within Christianity.

Born out of Spirituals in the early 20th century with influence from Southern Gospel and Blues, often featuring passionate or energetic vocal performances, motifs of salvation, and testaments of hardship.
Music of Hispanic America and Spain, and the genres shared between them.
Sentimental vocal music sung in Spanish with a focus on the chorus, originally developed in the first half of the 20th century from a variety of traditional Hispanic genres.
Latin American style stemming from both Canción melódica and the British Beat Music.
Chilean offshoot of Canción melódica that expresses a much more melancholic or nostalgic side.
Includes all genres created by Hispanic Americans.
Romantic dance and accompanying music originating in the Dominican Republic, featuring arpeggiated chords in the melody.
Ballad with a 2/4 time signature that appeared in eastern Cuba towards the end of the 19th century.
Blend of Bolero and Son cubano that appeared during the 1920s.
Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of Vocal Jazz.
Upbeat fusion of American Rhythm & Blues and Jazz with Son cubano which originated in the early 1960s in New York City and became popular with both its Black and Latino communities.
Fusion of Uruguayan Candombe with elements of Rock music.
A danceable genre, similar to the Polka, from the city of Santa Cruz, Bolivia, characteristic of the area’s Carnival celebrations and generally composed for brass band musicians.
Mixes native Guaraní music with Paraguayan Polka and European schottische music.
Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.
A vibrant Bolivian genre set in 6/8 meter featuring choral refrains, harmonic progressions, and lyrics exploring the subject of romantic love.

Urban folk ensembles characterized by musical instruments of Andean Indigenous origin or association, and despite its frequent association with Indigenous villages, bearing little resemblance to the Indigenous musical expressions of the Southern Andes.
Originated in the Argentinian province of Córdoba, usually with an upbeat rhythm and originally performed with a four-piece band.
Encompasses the wide variety of traditions from the island of Cuba.
Ballroom dance music derived from Danzón.
