One of the oldest popular Cuban styles, originating in the 19th century with slaves that worked in sugar refineries near Baracoa who combined elements of Spanish popular songs with Bantu traditions.
Evolved alongside Rumba cubana in the late 19th century, featuring large and heterogenous percussion sections performing simple and syncopated rhythms alongside a small wind section.
Played by traditional Cuban ensembles, influenced by Son cubano but performed on European instruments such as piano, bass, violins, and flutes.
Vocal delivery is often heavily auto-tuned and layered with adlibs, rhythm is syncopated, and Caribbean and African instrumentation is incorporated.

Development on Habanera in 2/4 time, featuring African influence through complex cross-rhythms, that would become the most popular style of dance music in Cuba during the late 19th century and early 20th century.
Cuban genre consisting of improvised jam sessions incorporating elements of Jazz and Afro-Cuban music.
Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of Vocal Jazz.
Originally developed in Cuba between the 18th and 19th Century as a narrative style influenced by Tonada chilena.
Humorous song with short notes and a fast tempo that commonly alternates a short fourth line verse with a repeated fourth line chorus.
Based around the Habanera rhythm, where the most typical instruments used are guitars, lutes, and bandurrias.
Dance-oriented evolution from Danzón during the late 1930s.
Cuban genre featuring energetic, African-influenced percussion.
Combination of Merengue, Conga, Rumba cubana, and Cumbia; fast, festive, and playful.
Featuring rhythms described as mimicking those created while pounding sugarcane with African baton-like tools.
Folkloric manifestation of Afro-Cuban music that encompasses dance, voice, and drums.
Emerged after the abolition of slavery in Cuba in 1886; usually features a lead singer, accompanied by three large drums, known as tumbadoras or congas, and a call-and-response chorus.
Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.
Cuban style popular from the 1920s to the 1950s that combines the structure of Spanish song-oriented styles with African rhythms and percussion.
Blend of Bolero and Son cubano that appeared during the 1920s.
Cuban style originating in the 1970s, combining elements from Rumba cubana and Son cubano with Jazz and Funk.
Combines Salsa with other genres such as Hip Hop, Disco, Funk, Jazz and Rock.
One of the most ancient expressions of Cuban Music, based around lone singer/songwriters who use nothing but a guitar as their preferred accompaniment and place emphasis on lyrics.
Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.
Combination of traditional music from Benin with French ballroom dancing that originates in the Oriente province (formerly Santiago de Cuba Province) in Cuba.
Danceable folk genre formed during the 19th century in Colombia and eastern Panama.
Almost always features synthesizer keyboards and electronic percussion with an upbeat rhythm.

Originated in the Argentinian province of Santa Fe, particularly in its capital city Santa Fe de la Vera Cruz, with lyrics that tend to be romantic and relatively clean compared to later Cumbia argentina.
Cumbia argentina heavily influenced by Reggaetón and characterized by hard-hitting bass and heavy use of samples and Auto-Tune.

Developed in the villa miserias (shanty towns) by the lower classes of Argentina in the early 2000s, featuring basic rhythms and low budget productions combined with lyrics that can be openly sexual or touch on sociopolitical issues.
Incorporates Chilean Music into the traditional sound of Cumbia.
Incorporating various instruments and rhythmic components from diverse genres such as Ska, Salsa, Indigenous Andean Music, Reggae, and Bolero.
Style that incorporates elements of Colombian traditional music, which includes and keeps influences from Spanish, African, and Indigenous cultures.

Incorporation of Rock & Roll, Mexican popular music, and Cuban influences, often adopting electric instruments, brass ensembles, accordion, and Cuban timbales, while retaining a beat-driven sound and traditional Colombian features.
Cumbia mexicana from Mexico City that developed in the 1990s as discomóviles (analogous to DJs) experimented with slowing down original cumbia to fit the popular dance tempos.
Peruvian Cumbia with influence from Psychedelic Rock and Surf Rock that emerged in the 1960s, developed by Andean people who had migrated to urban areas.
Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.
Mixes an Electronic sound into traditional Cumbia through influences from House, Dancehall, Hyphy, and Dubstep.
Colombian genre which combines Cumbia with Merengue.
Pacific coast Afro-Colombian music and folk dance performed by a marimba/percussion ensemble with heavy use of call-and-response vocals.
Originated in the Dominican Republic during the early 1990s, featuring rapping indebted to Hip Hop and a style drawing on Dancehall, particularly the "Dem Bow" riddim.
Emerged in the state of Zulia in the 1950s, merging Spanish Folk Music and Venezuelan Christmas carols.
Slow and melancholic rhythms, primarily performed on the Paraguayan harp.
Encompasses many varieties of folk traditions from Hispanic America.
Follows a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature with non-percussive instrumentation, often melancholic in sound with bright guitars and a rich melodic base.
Percussive style from Puerto Rico, generally considered to be derived from West Africa.
Uruguayan popular music originating among Montevideo's Afro-Uruguayan population, based on three differently-sized drums.
Sung poetry traditional to Chile and transmitted orally from one generation to another.
Colombian folk music that originated in Boyacá province, best known for its wordplay and humorous lyrics.
Originated in northwest Argentina and southern Bolivia around 1850, typically in 6/8 and traditionally performed with instruments like the guitar, bombo legüero (traditional drum), and violin.
Traditional genre and dance from the Río de la Plata region (Argentina, Uruguay, and southern Brazil), featuring similar rhythms to Milonga and typically performed with the guitar and accordion.
Popular in Chile, Argentina, and Bolivia, accompanied by a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature and usually structured into 14 verses.
Traditional dance and music genre with Andean roots that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.
One of the most popular genres of Andean music in Bolivia, particularly present in the departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosí.
Fast and lively; mostly played in northwestern Argentina in the provinces of Jujuy, Salta, and Tucumán.
Traditions of the mountain-dwelling jibaro people that live primarily in Puerto Rico.
Incorporates elements of Creole music and the Venezuelan waltz.
Traditional musical accompaniment to the Venezuelan 'velorios de cruz de mayo' celebrations, played with the mandolin (as lead instrument), cuatro and guitar.
Traditional Folk Music of the Mexican people.
Overtly dramatic, and melancholic A cappella performed in the Comarca Lagunera region in northeast Mexico.
Usually dominated by violin with accompaniment mainly provided by guitars and tamboras, occasionally dancers will stomp over a platform.
Bold rhythmic structure, lively violin playing, and extensive use of falsetto.
Developed in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, traditionally played by guitar, requinto, marimba, and bajoquinto, usually played in 3/4 time.
Mexican Folk Music from the Gulf Coast Mexican state of Veracruz, with both Spanish and indigenous influences.
Heavily influenced by Cuban Music, freely embracing Bolero, clave and Bambuco.
Rioplatense genre characterized by a slow rhythm which usually appears with a guitar; generally considered a precursor to Tango.
Mestizo folk genre popular in the central Peruvian Andes, characterized by a pronounced, though sedate, rhythm; traces of Andean melody; and octosyllabic verses.
Combination of African, Spanish, and Andean influences that originated after the time of the arrival of Spanish colonists and African slaves to Peru.
Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

Backing to the fast-paced dance that originated in northern Peru in the region of Piura of the same name; bands consist of a singer, a small chorus, two guitarists, along with the cajón and sometimes a spoon player.

Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.
Folk genre from Puerto Rico played with hand drums called panderetas.
Fast-paced, percussive traditional genre created by the Afro-Bolivian people.
Folk music and dance from Panama dating back to the 17th century.
Developed by the indigenous peoples of eastern Bolivia, bringing in some elements of Hispanic Music, and featuring a syncopated rhythm.
Traditional folk from the Chilean countryside distinguished by its prominent melody.
Peruvian criollo-mestizo songs with recurring themes of sadness and unrequited love, usually in 6/8 meter.
Traditional genre and dance of 19th century Peru, sung in the minor mode and accompanied by a varying combination of guitar, vihuela, harp and cajón.
Folk dance that evolved out of Peruvian Zamacueca during the 19th century.
Incorporates common elements from Hispanic American Music like Cumbia, Tango or Mexican Music into Rock.
Western Classical Music with influences from Hispanic American Music.
Disco that incorporates elements from Hispanic American Music styles.
Combines Electronic with Latin American influences; started at the end of the 1990s.
House style deeply influenced by 1990s Techno and Tribal House, featuring fast tempos, strident synthesizers, hard-thumping percussion lines, plenty of breakbeats.
Mixes an Electronic sound into traditional Cumbia through influences from House, Dancehall, Hyphy, and Dubstep.
Mixes elements of Merengue and Reggaetón with polished production from mainstream House subgenres; often shares traits with Latin Pop, having anthemic melodies and verse-chorus structures.
Combines Tango rhythms and melodies with Electronic music.
Samples and synthesizes Mexican styles like Banda sinaloense and Norteño into a sound related to IDM and House.
Features percussion from Cumbia and Mexican Folk Music with upbeat Electro House-derived production and fast, triplet-oriented rhythmic patterns.
Funk combined with Hispanic American Music styles.
Used originally for Afro-Cuban Jazz but, due to its evolution, is now used for the fusion of jazz with Latin American rhythms, especially genres with African origin.
Combines Jazz with the rhythm of Afro-Cuban music like Habanera.
Characterized by its usage of Latino clichés and frequently influenced by traditional Latin American styles, commonly borrowing from their instrumentation.
Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.
Subgenre of Colombian origin fusing Vallenato instrumentation into a Latin Pop context.
Fusion of Rock, often Psychedelic Rock, with Latin American rhythms, especially Afro-Latin genres.
Soul combined with Hispanic American Music, such as Salsa and Mambo.
Emerged in the early 2010s in Chile, characterized by upbeat rhythms and rapping, usually on topics of parties, dancing, and urban life.
Dominican Republic dance genre that had a commercial boom at the end of the 1980s.
Rhythmically simpler and more eclectic style, absorbing influences from Hip Hop, Reggaetón, and other modern genres, particularly in regards to vocals.
Colombian genre which combines Cumbia with Merengue.
Earliest, most stripped-down form of Merengue.
Popularized by Dominican-American artists of the 1990s, blending modern Merengue with electronic instrumentation and the combination of rapping/singing vocals.
Fuses basic Merengue rhythms with influences from Cumbia and Lambada, being largely synthesized, with live instruments usually limited to percussion and brass.
Music of Mexico and those deeply rooted in Mexican traditions.
Mexican ensemble with many regional variations dating back to the 1860s and 1870s, when locals attempted to imitate the military bands that were present in the country.
Performed with militaristic-type arrangements of traditional Bandas de viento de México, with prominence on the tuba/sousaphone backing and tenor tuned horns.
Arose from Sinaloa in the late 2000s; radicalizes some of the characteristics of Banda sinaloense and Norteño.
Emerged in the mid-1980s from the Banda sinaloense tradition, replacing certain instruments with synthesizers and electric instruments, allowing for faster tempos.
Developed when music from the Costa Chica of Guerrero and Oaxaca in Mexico mixed with Cueca brought by Chilean sailors to the region in the 19th century.
Narrative ballad which arose in the late 18th century and flourished after the Mexican Independence War, originally meant for folk singers to spread news throughout Mexico accompanied by a guitar.

Incorporation of Rock & Roll, Mexican popular music, and Cuban influences, often adopting electric instruments, brass ensembles, accordion, and Cuban timbales, while retaining a beat-driven sound and traditional Colombian features.
Cumbia mexicana from Mexico City that developed in the 1990s as discomóviles (analogous to DJs) experimented with slowing down original cumbia to fit the popular dance tempos.
Combining Reggaetón  with Cumbia mexicana, and less frequently with other forms of traditional Mexican Music.
Mexican style performed in unique costumes by ensembles known as mariachi bands, with a distinctive sound combining high, bright tones with low and rich voicings.
Traditional Folk Music of the Mexican people.
Overtly dramatic, and melancholic A cappella performed in the Comarca Lagunera region in northeast Mexico.
Usually dominated by violin with accompaniment mainly provided by guitars and tamboras, occasionally dancers will stomp over a platform.
Bold rhythmic structure, lively violin playing, and extensive use of falsetto.
Developed in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, traditionally played by guitar, requinto, marimba, and bajoquinto, usually played in 3/4 time.
Mexican Folk Music from the Gulf Coast Mexican state of Veracruz, with both Spanish and indigenous influences.
Heavily influenced by Cuban Music, freely embracing Bolero, clave and Bambuco.
More traditional, rural version of Tejano Music whose name translates to "northern".
Norteño heavily influenced by Cumbia.
Features aspects of banda music, sped up, with the addition of synthesizers.
Arose from Sinaloa in the late 2000s; radicalizes some of the characteristics of Banda sinaloense and Norteño.
Norteño that is mainly played with guitars, as opposed to the traditional bajo sexto used in norteño.
Modern take of regional Mexican music derived from Sierreño with heavy influence from the atmosphere of Trap music, while not engaging in that genre's characteristic sound.
A popular genre of Mexican music developed in the nationalist theater of the post-1910 revolution period in Mexico.
Mexican-American style infusing the conjunto Norteño ensemble with European dances and American popular music.
Variant originated in Montevideo that stands out for its rhythms, nasal vocals and choral arrangements.
Politically-charged messages associated with the rise of leftist social movements; striving for a renewal of traditional Latin and Hispanic American Folk Music expressions.
Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.
Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.
Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "la música popular nativa" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.
Based on Joropo, it incorporates elements of Bossa nova and Jazz.
Traditional dance popular in Ecuador and Colombia; based on European Waltz and often performed with guitar and mandolin.
Popular music originating in Paraguay and the Province of Corrientes (Argentina), derived from the Bohemian polka and traditional music of Hispanic-Jesuit origin.
Lively Hispanic American Music and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.
Rooted in Dancehall and mainly characterized by its heavy emphasis on the "dembow" rhythm; developed in Puerto Rico in the early 1990s under heavy influence from Hip Hop.
Mixes Bachata melodies and instrumentation with Reggaetón rhythms, rapping, and DJing.
Vocal delivery is often heavily auto-tuned and layered with adlibs, rhythm is syncopated, and Caribbean and African instrumentation is incorporated.
Combining Reggaetón  with Cumbia mexicana, and less frequently with other forms of traditional Mexican Music.
Heavy emphasis on rhythm, influence from global trends in club music, and generally progressive lyrics.
Emerged in the early 2010s, characterized by minimalistic, rhythm-centric production heavily influenced by Cumbia villera and other Cumbia argentina styles.
Commercial adaptation of various Latin American genres; developed during the 1930s as the so-called "rhumba craze" unfolded in the United States.
Emerged in the Andean countries in the late 1960s and early 1970s, incorporating traditional instruments and harmonies from Indigenous Andean Music within a Rock format.
Often incorporating congas, timbales and bongos as well as smaller instruments, such as maracas, clave and güiro.
Colombian style that takes heavy influence from Reggaetón, House, Hip Hop, and various Afro-Colombian and Colombian Pacific styles.
Form of earlier Salsa, usually less rigid in structure allowing for extended jam sessions; lyrical themes follow around the "barrio" way of life and Latin American traditions.
Salsa following a stronger influence from Pop, typically sharing shorter, conventional structures and romantic lyricism.
Combines Salsa with other genres such as Hip Hop, Disco, Funk, Jazz and Rock.
Venezuelan-Panamanian popular genre which mixes local Tamborito with Cuban Music rhythms featuring the tambora as the main percussion instrument.
Melancholic sound generally led by a guitar or bandoneon, originating in Buenos Aires by the late 19th century and gaining worldwide popularity from the 1920s to the 1950s.
Melancholic style developed in Finland in the 1930s and 1940s, influenced by traditional minor-key Finnish Folk Music melodies and the rhythms of German marches.
Adds new elements into traditional Argentine Tango, most importantly the incorporation of Jazz and Western Classical Music.
Colombian scene born in the early 2000s with the intention of reinventing Colombian coastal music, from a more current and experimental approach.
Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.
Danceable style from El Salvador developed in the 1940s.
Popular carnival music traditional in some cities of Spain and Hispanic America.
Variant originated in Montevideo that stands out for its rhythms, nasal vocals and choral arrangements.
Latin American (Nueva canción latinoamericana) and Spanish (Nueva canción española) movement during the 1960s and 1970s.
Arose in Spain in the 1960s, inspired in part by Nova cançó's reclaiming of Catalan regional identity, that spread across the country in regional variations.
Politically-charged messages associated with the rise of leftist social movements; striving for a renewal of traditional Latin and Hispanic American Folk Music expressions.
Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.
Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.
Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "la música popular nativa" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.
Music of Spain.
Spanish genre originating in the 18th century, based around moderate tempos in a 3/4 time signature accompanied by a dance of the same name.
Often accompanying the dance of the same name, this traditional Spanish style is based around fiery acoustic guitar rhythms, emotional vocals, and accompaniment from traditional percussion.
Fast flamenco made up of a 12 beat cycle characterized by its vibrant, spontaneous and festive style.
Contemporary style of Flamenco which departs from tradition by incorporating influences from other genres like Jazz, Blues, and Rock.
Combination of Jazz with Flamenco nuevo, the contemporary style of Flamenco, which was pioneered in the late 1960s.
Flamenco subgenre, derived from the exchange of influences between Spain and Latin America.
Originally developed in the mid 1960s, incorporated palos flamencos (Flamenco subgenres) and Copla into the format of feisty and lively Pop (particularly, Yé-yé).
Arose in Spain in the 1960s, inspired in part by Nova cançó's reclaiming of Catalan regional identity, that spread across the country in regional variations.
Emerged during the mid-1970s in Spain; primarily utilizes Flamenco and often Symphonic Prog elements.
Cheerful Catalan genre that takes influences from Rumba cubana, Andalusian Rumba flamenca, and Pop.
Incorporation of Spanish Music within the context of Western Classical Music, particularly characterized by the use of the classical guitar.
Iberian form of plainchant that flourished roughly 550-1085 AD.
Spanish dramatic genre where spoken scenes are mixed with passages sung in operatic or popular styles.
Light, small-scale musical comedy with mild social commentary, populist themes, and catchy melodies.
Earliest form that draws from a broad range of artistic sources, including theater, operatic singing, instrumental music, dance, popular music, poetry, and comedy.
Romantic musical comedy akin to Operetta developed during the mid-19th century.
Traditional Folk Music of Spain, widely diverse due to the distinct culture and traditions of the country's different regions.
Flamenco of Andalusia in southern Spain, rooted in traditional music and dances and developed mostly after the 18th century by the Romani people of Andalusia (known locally as gitanos).
Traditional religious praise song that originated in Andalusia, Spain towards the end of the late Middle Ages.
Named after the city of Seville in Spain, typically rhythmic with a 3/4 beat and guitar accompaniment.
Traditional Folk Music of the Aragonese people.
Traditions of the Spanish province of Asturias.
Traditional folk of the Canary Islands.

Spanish variant of schottisch, a slow version of German Polka which developed through the incorporation of regional folk influences and an association with the local castizo culture in Madrid, the capital of Spain.
Evolved from Spanish theatrical styles like Cuplé and has strong links to Flamenco.
Originally developed in the 19th century as a blend of old theatre Spanish styles based in short monologues (jácara and tonadilla) and French Couplet.
Traditional music of the Galician people.
Mainly instrumental Spanish style primarily associated with bullfighting and popular celebrations, believed to originate from a double-time military march from France in the 18th century.
Blend of the themes and singing style of Rumba flamenca with the most commercial forms of House, Techno, and Makina.
Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of the Americas.
Meta-genre encompassing traditions attributed to the indigenous peoples of the Americas.
Fiddle playing of the Dene or "Athabaskan" people of modern-day Alaska, Yukon and the Northwest Territories.
Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.
Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.
Traditional Folk Music of the Mapuche people of Chile and Argentina.
Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.
Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on charangos and guitarillas, with a catchy, lively rhythm.
Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of the Andes.
Repeating phrases of sung poetry dealing with emotional topics.
Traditional dance and music genre with Andean roots that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.
One of the most popular genres of Andean music in Bolivia, particularly present in the departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosí.
Fast and lively; mostly played in northwestern Argentina in the provinces of Jujuy, Salta, and Tucumán.
Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on charangos and guitarillas, with a catchy, lively rhythm.
Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of present-day Canada, the United States and northwestern Mexico.
Fiddle playing of the Dene or "Athabaskan" people of modern-day Alaska, Yukon and the Northwest Territories.
Traditions of the Inuit people, the aboriginal peoples inhabiting the Arctic regions of Canada, Alaska, and Greenland.
Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.
Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.
Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.
Diverse styles and genres developed by the Indigenous peoples of Mesoamerica, a cultural region extending from central and southern Mexico through parts of Central America.
Common lineage for traditional classical music stretching from Morocco to Central Asia.
Arabic Classical Music tradition, whose guidelines for modulation, rhythm, and tuning were set down in treatises in the 8th and 9th centuries, based around Islamic Modal Music.
Found primarily in the Andalusia region in southern Spain, generally thought to have beginnings in the Emirate of Cordoba during the period of Muslim control of the region in the 9th century.
Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific maqam modes.
Poetic vocal form with complex rhythms, emotive singing, and distinctive lute-backed melodies commonly found in the Gulf region and based on a maqam system.
Highly improvisational form of modal music characterized by the singing style and the themes of Azerbaijan’s history.
Traditional art music of the Persian civilization.
Modal suite that brings together lyrical and instrumental songs, poetry, and dance shared by Tajik Music and Uzbek Music.
Classical music of the Kashmir region, the northernmost part of the Indian subcontinent.
Classical music of Turkey, which uses the makam modal system, with the primary emphasis often being on the singers, who are accompanied by small ensembles.
Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.

Music and melodic recitation involved in the Islamic faith, such as the reading of the Qur'an with its melodic component (qira'ah), the adhan call to prayer, and the elements often used in the practice of dhikr (particularly in Sufism).
Form of musical recitation sacred to Nizari Ismaili Muslims.
Singing for Shia Muslims to mourn in religious death anniversaries.
Vocal songs popular throughout the Islamic world, mostly performed A cappella though sometimes featuring light instrumentation.
Religious music meant to accompany the dabõih ceremony of the Acehnese people.
Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.
Different Jewish forms coming from different regions of the world, influenced by local cultures.
Encompasses the various traditions and genres of the Ashkenazi Jews, an ethnoreligious group that was prominent and influential in Europe throughout most of the Middle Ages and the modern period.
Secular Ashkenazi Music traditionally used in ceremonies such as weddings and bar mitzvahs.
Traditional folk developed in Ashkenazi Jewish communities, particularly those of Yiddish-speaking Eastern and Central Europe.
Covers the music of Hasidic Jews, primarily characterized by spiritual, intense, and devotional, singing and melodies.
Form of spiritual, repetitive and immersive tunes that developed in Hasidic Jewish communities, typically vocal-led.
Employed for different purposes in the practices of Jewish religion, such as the Kriyat haTorah of biblical verses during synagogue services.
Reconstruction of Jerusalem temple music.
Traditions used by the Jewish cantor, the chazzan when reciting and chanting different parts of the Jewish prayer in Jewish Liturgical Music.
Practice of ritual liturgical chanting of the Masoretic text of the Tanakh, often done during synagogue services.
Liturgical Jewish poems that are chanted or recited during religious occasions such as daily prayers and holidays.

Middle Eastern-flavored Israeli popular music, usually performed by Mizrahi Jews, and combining aspects of the music of the North African, Middle Eastern, and Central Asian countries from which they descended.
Comprises the many traditions and styles of the various groups of Jews from the cultural East, loosely covering the Jewish groups of the Middle East, North Africa, and Central Asia.
Combines Orthodox Jewish themes and prayer with Pop songwriting, usually sung in Hebrew.
Encompasses the various musical traditions of Sephardi Jews.
Ladino-language Traditional Folk Music tunes that were written and preserved by Sephardic Jews.
Paraliturgical songs of Sephardi Jews who lived in Ottoman Empire.

Covering the music of Western-derived marching bands, primarily used for entertainment, competition, military, and parade settings, typically involving large-scale orchestras featuring a variety of instruments.
Solely percussion based Marching Band.
Derived from military field music, primarily uses fifes and drums.
Performs at athletic events, and typically performs modified versions of Pop songs.
Tradition originating in the Scottish military; standard instruments consist of 6-25 sets of Great Highland bagpipes, 3-10 military snare drums, 1-6 Scottish tenor drums, and one bass drum.
Regional styles with roots in Northern America, typically drawing from European folk and classical music as well as West African and indigenous American influences.
Ambient music made using traditional Americana and Country instrumentation.
Incorporates a broad swath of American Folk Music and Contemporary Folk influences, evolving alongside Alt-Country.
Traces back through the history of European and West African settlement and migration to North America, including parts of northern Mexico and Canada in addition to the United States.
Folk of the Appalachian Mountains in the Eastern United States.
Pre-Bluegrass North American string band styles, particularly those rooted in Appalachian Folk Music.
Harmonized singing consisting of four vocal elements: the 'lead' (2nd tenor), the 1st tenor, the baritone, and the bass.
Various styles of Blues originating in the rural US South, typically reyling on expressive vocal delivery and featuring simple, usually acoustic instrumentation.
Laid-back swing rhythms and guitar ornamentation, including solos.
One of the earliest forms of Blues, named for the Mississippi Delta region of the United States where it developed, with a highly rhythmic style and a typical 12-bar structure.

Emphasizes a steady hypnotic groove, sparse percussive and highly energetic guitar riffs, and often features meandering structures with unconventional and usually fewer chord changes compared to Delta Blues.
Developed in the early 20th century in the southern Appalachian foothills and characterized by a syncopated but melodic Ragtime-based finger-picking acoustic guitar style.
Work song created by African-American slaves working on cotton plantations, which features an expressive vocal style to no strict rhythm.
Rooted in martial Fife and Drum Corps music, originated among Afro-American communities in Mississippi.
Usually features a jug as the bass instrument as well as other homemade (or easily affordable) instruments, such as kazoos and washboards.
Ritual practiced by African-Americans in the US South, characterized by shouting, chanting and people dancing in a circle while praying and clapping.
Predominantly 19th-century English hymns with tunes derived from old folk melodies.
Predecessor to Gospel that began as unaccompanied singing by American slaves; shares some of the characteristics of Work Songs.
American Folk Music with spoken or nearly spoken vocals.

Born out of Spirituals in the early 20th century with influence from Southern Gospel and Blues, often featuring passionate or energetic vocal performances, motifs of salvation, and testaments of hardship.
Earliest and most "pure" form of Cajun Music, employing basic rhythms and frequent fiddle double stops.
Closely aligned with American Folk Music and Blues roots, from country's inception in Appalachia and the American South until the popularity of Honky Tonk and Country Pop in the 1950s.
Traditional two-part harmony singing performed mostly by brothers.
Also sometimes called "hillbilly boogie", this is Country's version of Boogie Woogie.
Traditional Country that heavily incorporates Gospel.
Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.
Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.
Blends avant-garde and neo-classical compositions with traditional Country Blues fingerpicking techniques.
Early, uptempo Blues featuring the piano as the main instrument, with soloing and improvisation played over the top of a repetitive eight note bassline.
Traditional folk of the European settlers who arrived in Canada.
Traditional folk of Canada's Maritimes (Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and New Brunswick).
Celtic Folk Music that emerged in Cape Breton, an island at the eastern shore of Nova Scotia, through immigrants from Scotland and Ireland.
Distinctive Celtic fiddling originating from the Scottish immigrants who settled in Canada on Cape Breton Island.

Brought by French colonists to their Nouvelle-France settlements, primarily based around French Folk Music with influences from English Folk Music and Celtic Folk Music, typically played during gatherings and holidays.
Traditional Folk Music of Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada's easternmost province.

Lyrical trend popular in the United States from around 1880 to 1920 that presents a racist and highly stereotyped image of African Americans connected with the subject matter and style of minstrel shows, though these songs could be in practically any style.
American genre derived from Southern and Appalachian forms of American Folk Music and later Rock and Pop influences, with a focus on the life and culture of rural America.
Arose in the 1980s and 1990s, performed by artists with roots in Alternative Rock and Indie Rock who were disconnected from the mainstream Country industry.
Evokes the Southern Gothic literary genre through morbid lyrical themes and melancholic sounds that emphasize its American Folk Music and Post-Punk influences.
Born in the Appalachian region of the United States during the late 1930s, characterized by fingerpicked banjo along with other traditional instruments.
Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.
Mixing the sound and aesthetics of pure Bluegrass with a variety of influences outside of its Appalachian origins, including Jazz, Folk, Rock, and other forms of Country.
Emphasizes instrumental jamming and extended performances with many outside influences.
Incorporates both heavily Pop-influenced styles, and the more pop-averse movement of Neo-Traditionalist Country.
Emerged in the late 1980s as a reaction to the increased dominance of Country Pop, moving instead towards a Honky Tonk-rooted sound that centered the Singer-Songwriter.
Developed in Ireland; combines North American Country with Irish Folk Music influences, often in the form of traditional Irish songs that have been adapted into country numbers.
Combination of Country with Pop to appeal to a larger audience.
Originated in the 21st century and takes its cues from Hip Hop, Pop and Contemporary Country.
Emphasizes Pop-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of Country instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.
Melds country and Pop (best described as 70s L.A. soft pop), and sometimes leans towards Disco.

Upbeat style that retains much of the common instrumentation of Traditional Country, as well as featuring prominent guitars (especially the steel guitar), strong backbeats and lyrics commonly about the working-class life.
Country based heavily on electric instrumentation and a defined backbeat.
Derived from Honky Tonk, Country Rock and Bakersfield Sound; aimed at the truck driving community.
Production style characterized by smooth vocals over a relaxed ensemble of guitars and rhythm section, and variously incorporating elements from other styles of Country and Pop.
Emphasizes Pop-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of Country instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.

Blend of traditionalist Country styles with elements of Rock, Contemporary Folk, and other countercultural genres; characterized by realistic, self-reflective lyrics and non-traditional songwriting and production elements.
Rock-influenced reaction to mainstream Country Pop trends, featuring rebellious personas, darker lyrics, and Western-inspired outlaw imagery.
Hails predominantly from Oklahoma and Texas, drawing principally from Outlaw Country and Southern Rock.
Closely aligned with American Folk Music and Blues roots, from country's inception in Appalachia and the American South until the popularity of Honky Tonk and Country Pop in the 1950s.
Traditional two-part harmony singing performed mostly by brothers.
Also sometimes called "hillbilly boogie", this is Country's version of Boogie Woogie.
Traditional Country that heavily incorporates Gospel.
Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.
Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.
Associated with the tramping lifestyle that emerged in the former Czechoslovakia; inspired by American Country, Western and Bluegrass, albeit with a strong Czech cultural influence.
Reflects and portrays the lifestyles of cowboys and other settlers of the Western United States through both Traditional Folk Music and popular song.
Blend of Traditional Country string instrumentation with the driving rhythms of Jazz and regional dance traditions, often prominently featuring fiddle and steel guitar.
Combination of contemporary Rock with more traditional American Country.

Descended from the oral traditions of cowboys and ranchers, written with traditional use of rhyme and meter, using humor and slang, and primarily concerning the cowboy profession, lifestyle, and legacy.
Majorly from Inuit ethnic groups in Greenland, a large island between the Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.
Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of present-day Canada, the United States and northwestern Mexico.
Fiddle playing of the Dene or "Athabaskan" people of modern-day Alaska, Yukon and the Northwest Territories.
Traditions of the Inuit people, the aboriginal peoples inhabiting the Arctic regions of Canada, Alaska, and Greenland.
Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.
Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.
Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.
Regional Music from the US state of Louisiana.
Associated with the Cajun people of Louisiana where the genre was born, commonly regarded as an uptempo, accordion-driven style with a harsh, infectious beat.
Earliest and most "pure" form of Cajun Music, employing basic rhythms and frequent fiddle double stops.
Appeared around New Orleans in the 1940s, drawing influences from Jazz, regional Antillean, Haitian, and Louisiana Creole music, and including strong use of saxophone and piano.
New Orleans' unique combination of European-styled military bands with African folklore.
Increased rhythmic complexity with added focus on piano and horns.
Originated in Baton Rouge, Louisiana in the 1950s, with a laid-back and relaxed sound that takes influence from Zydeco and Cajun Music.
Uniquely Cajun style of Rhythm & Blues distinguished by tripleted pianos and a slow Blues structure.
Uptempo accordion-led dance style mixing Creole and Cajun folk with African American popular music influences.
Adds new elements into contemporary Zydeco, most importantly the incorporation of Funk, Contemporary R&B and Hip Hop characteristics.
Popular song and entertainment tradition from the U.S. engendered in variety shows employing racist caricature and blackface.
Performs at athletic events, and typically performs modified versions of Pop songs.
Emerged in the 1890s; piano-led and characterized by a heavily syncopated rhythm.
Developed alongside Ragtime, typically in 2/4 with a distinctive oompah rhythm, named for a dance created by enslaved black Americans as a mockery of the social dances of white slaveholders.
Nostalgic revival popularised in the 1950s which is more upbeat and whimsical, with a bright and detuned piano sound.
Popular in the 1920s; originated in Chicago and took influence from Jazz.
Early form of Ragtime-derived Jazz with improvisational tendencies; named for the performers' left hand "striding" across the piano keyboard.

Consciously and predominantly incorporates elements of its predecessors and original roots such as Country, Blues, Rhythm & Blues, Rock & Roll, and American Folk Music, but also many other American traditions.
Intermixture of Zydeco, Cajun Music, New Orleans Blues, and Pop under the roof of Rock.
Mixes Rock & Roll, Blues, Country, and several types of Hispanic American Music, particularly Tejano Music.
Focused on instrumentals and played on the steel guitar.
Initially sung A cappella by a Vocal Group quartet, sometimes with a pianist or guitar as accompaniment, with lyrics and messages primarily revolving around the teachings found within Christianity.
Mexican-American style infusing the conjunto Norteño ensemble with European dances and American popular music.
Early era of popular song in the USA, broadly from the 1890s-1930s; influences include Ragtime, Vaudeville and parlour music.
Performed in American musical theaters typically as part of a lowbrow, often comedic variety performance.
Vaudeville incorporating heavy Blues elements.
Rooted in the traditions of the geographic region of Oceania.
Folk traditions of the European colonists and convicts in Australia.
Traditional Folk Music of Aboriginal Australians and Torres Strait Islanders, collectively known as Indigenous Australians.
Sung and composed in the Murrinh-Patha language and consisting of a mixed group of men and women accompanied by bilma and handclaps, typically without didgeridoo.
Music of the Oceanian region of Melanesia.
Music of the Fijian people.
Blends traditional local music with elements of Disco, Country and Rock.
New Caledonian style of popular music that draws influence from traditional Melanesian music.
Created by local, rural artists from Papua New Guinea that incorporate some elements of Papuan Folk Music into Pop.
Traditional Folk Music of the Papuan people of New Guinea.
Fuses the music of the Tolai people of Papua New Guinea with Rock.
Music of the Micronesian peoples.
Improvised verse singing performed in the Chamorro language, traditional of the Marianas islands.
Developed in Pacific island communities, incorporating elements from local Oceanian Music styles.
Music of Polynesia.
Music of the Fijian people.
Blends traditional local music with elements of Disco, Country and Rock.
Includes a variety of syncopated rhythms, percussion and vocal styles, including chanting (mele) and falsetto.
Originated in Hawaii and typically played with one's thumb in an alternating-bass pattern on the lower two or three strings.
Protestant choral songs in Tahiti and other southern Polynesian islands (Cook Is., Society Is., etc.)
Music of the indigenous Māori people of New Zealand.
Music of the Samoan people.
Music of the Tahitian people.
Chanting that combines two or more melodic lines that are harmonically cohesive but differ in rhythm and utilize non-parallel motion.
Period (around 1310-1380) that succeeded Ars antiqua, mixing the sacred with the secular.
Emerged in the final period of late medieval music (around 1380-1420) and continued to use the technique of isorhythms but with added complexity.
Traditional Portuguese Music based on vocal music from the Alentejo region.
Secular Polyphonic Chant from the Mediterranean island of Sardinia.
Dissonant form of polyphonic singing from the regions of Herzegovina and Dalmatia.
Protestant choral songs in Tahiti and other southern Polynesian islands (Cook Is., Society Is., etc.)
Polyphonic vocal music that developed in Bosnia in the 20th century, bearing connections to traditional Bosnian genres.
One of several genres of iso-polyphonic music performed in southern Albania, with "iso" referring to the distinctive drone voice used.
Secular polyphonic music based around poetry and generally performed by unaccompanied vocal ensembles of two to eight persons.
Traditional A cappella Polyphonic Chant from Corsica consisting of three registers of vocalists singing in a semicircle.
Style of polyphonic singing of the Seto people.
Highly unique form of polyphonic vocal folk music originating from a small area of Northeastern Lithuania.
Polyphonic singing in the Toskëri region of southern Albania.
Polyphonic Traditional Folk Music originating in the Ligurian region of Genoa, in northern Italy.

Styles from the first cultural periods of the human species (Homo sapiens, as well as certain Homo neanderthalis), particularly the Paleolithic and Neolithic eras, from its birth to the Ancient Music era beginning around 2000-3000 BC.
Rooted in the traditions of South America.
Indo-Caribbean genre from Suriname, consisting of Bhojpuri Folk Music with local Caribbean influence.
Follows a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature with non-percussive instrumentation, often melancholic in sound with bright guitars and a rich melodic base.
All forms of music with roots in Brazil.
Popular style of music from the Southern region of Brazil. Borrows elements from German Folk Music, Sertanejo romântico and Brega.
Conceived as a new style to perform original Samba, with major American Jazz influences.
Originated in the late 19th century, taking the European music that had been brought to the country by colonists and brought in parts of Brazilian Music.
Brazillian Waltz characterized by its slow rhythms and romantic sound.
Comprises the various traditions of folk music found in Brazil, often resulting from the interplay of Indigenous, African and European folk music.
Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.
Aboio that features rhyming verses.
Lively music played by bands consisting of two fifes and percussion; typical of rural Northeastern Brazil.
Music of the Afro-Brazilian Candomblé religion that influenced the secular Afoxé.
Sung poetry of itinerant cantadores from Northeastern Brazil.
Contest of fully improvised poetry sung in different stanza formats, following the poetic conventions of  Cantoria.

Afro-Brazilian style that accompanies and sets the rhythm and energy of the capoeira martial art, originating in the 19th century with the relocation of African slaves to the states of Bahia and Rio de Janeiro.
Style of fandango born in coastal Southern Brazil amidst the Caiçara people.
Afro-Brazilian cultural manifestation involving music and dance; composed of percussion instruments and chants.
Afro-Brazilian religious ritualistic praise sung by priests to evoke entities; typically accompanied by claps and traditional drums known as atabaque.
Afro-Brazilian musical genre that emerged in the 18th century with influences from African drumming with European Fandango.
Afro-Brazilian genre which accompanies the cultural manifestation of the same name, hailing from the northeastern state of Pernambuco.
Popular during the 18th and 19th centuries in Brazil; characterized by sentimental works with amorous themes, poetic lyrics, acoustic instrumentation and operatic vocals.
Regional dance and its accompanying music from the Brazilian midwest, predominantly the state of Mato Grosso.
Mixed Portuguese culture with African slave traditions, as well as sharing roots and similarities with Batuque and Jongo.

Earliest form of Sertanejo, emerging in pre-World War II rural Brazil during the late 1920s; quickly strummed acoustic guitars, most commonly the 10-string viola caipira and classical guitar, and a highly emotive vocal style.
Style of Sertanejo de raiz predominant in southeast, south, and west-central Brazil.
Overstated, dramatic music with a romantic singing style.
Influenced by Brega's romantic style, with further influence from Axé and Forró, giving it a more sensual and euphoric feel.
Arrocha and Pagodão fusion subgenre, created in mid-2000s in Bahia by the singer and composer Dan Ventura, merge the electronic keyboards of arrocha with the rhythms of pagodão.
Fuses contemporary rhythms from the Brazilian Northeast such as Arrocha, Pagodão and Piseiro, with the electronic beats of Funk brasileiro and its subgenres.
Romantic vocals and lyrics, bubbly and sensual melodies and rhythms, horn sections and lush Caribbean-like guitar riffs over fast tempos.
Rooted in Tecnobrega, features glossy syncopated MIDI pianos and synths, distinct pitched metallic snares and vocal chops over a wonky kick rhythm.
Slower and romantic Kizomba-fused beats.
Fast and electronic-based style that evolved from Brega calypso, particularly associated with peripheral areas of the city of Belém.
Raw and vulgar Tecnobrega and Funk brasileiro fusion developed in the late 2010s by DJs in Belém do Pará.

Brazilian urban genre named after the crying-like harmony generated by the very particular group of instruments used to play it: seven-string acoustic guitar, mandolin, flute, cavaquinho, and pandeiro.
Emerged in the 1930s as the result of a fusion of rhythmic elements and combining Samba with Choro.
Brazilian musical genre, played by military bands with wooden, brass and also percussive instruments.
Hip Hop-influenced dance style originating from the favelas of Rio de Janeiro, originally rooted in Electro and Miami Bass and known primarily as "funk" in Brazil.
Slow and gritty Reggaetón-like drums with an emphasis on brass sections influenced by Arrocha.
Rooted in Tecnobrega, features glossy syncopated MIDI pianos and synths, distinct pitched metallic snares and vocal chops over a wonky kick rhythm.
Slower and romantic Kizomba-fused beats.
Fast tempos, typically reaching 150 bpm and sometimes beyond it, heightened energy and typically faster flows as well.
Atmospheric, mellow and minimalistic production with sparse percussion often featuring sound effects or filtered samples
Simple lyricism, raw and minimalistic production, and distinct drops with bursting bass.
São Paulo-originated Funk brasileiro with aggressive, distorted and high-pitched beats featuring minimalistic percussion and diversified sampling.
Derivative of Funk brasileiro in a Dance-Pop direction, originating in Rio de Janeiro.
Began in the late 2000s in the São Paulo metro area and the Baixada Santista region in São Paulo state, featuring stronger influence from Pop Rap that gives it a more accessible sound.
Raw, aggressive style that developed in the favelas of Rio de Janeiro in the 1990s, with a name translating to "prohibited funk" that hints at its gang origin.
Slow-paced, highly rhythmic with instrumentation derived from Samba and Axé, and Reggaetón-inspired grooves.
Popularized in the late 90s, added Afro-Brazilian elements as the atabaque sound into the Miami Bass kick drums.
Raw and vulgar Tecnobrega and Funk brasileiro fusion developed in the late 2010s by DJs in Belém do Pará.
Appeared in Rio de Janeiro at the end of the 19th century, compared with and influenced by Tango.
Short for música popular brasileira; formed in the mid-1960s as a modernized version of Bossa nova and Samba-canção.

Brazilian counterculture art movement started in 1967 blending Psychedelic Rock, Psychedelic Pop, and Experimental production with contemporary Brazilian pop, with the lyrics being left wing-tinted abstract poetry.
Popular music style of southern Brazil, based on the traditional polka and other European rhythms.
Typical dance style music from Rio Grande do Sul in Brazil, and very present in the states of Paraná and Santa Catarina.

Regional styles that combines elements of indigenous, African and European traditions, historically with a focus on life of the northeastern people, such as drought, migration, the struggle for survival, love and nostalgia, and often danced in intense and accelerated movements.
Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.
Aboio that features rhyming verses.
Afro-Brazilian genre originating in the states of Pernambuco and Bahia, characterized by the ijexá rhythm invented by the Yoruba people.
Influenced by Brega's romantic style, with further influence from Axé and Forró, giving it a more sensual and euphoric feel.
Arrocha and Pagodão fusion subgenre, created in mid-2000s in Bahia by the singer and composer Dan Ventura, merge the electronic keyboards of arrocha with the rhythms of pagodão.
Fuses contemporary rhythms from the Brazilian Northeast such as Arrocha, Pagodão and Piseiro, with the electronic beats of Funk brasileiro and its subgenres.
Developed from a fusion of Frevo, Maracatu, Forró, Reggae and Calypso with roots in the Salvador de Bahia carnival.
Predominance of guitar riffs, atabaques, pandeiros and drums.
Arrocha and Pagodão fusion subgenre, created in mid-2000s in Bahia by the singer and composer Dan Ventura, merge the electronic keyboards of arrocha with the rhythms of pagodão.
Percussion-focused style from Bahia, Brazil, originating in the 1980s and 1990s in the Bahian carnival's afro-blocos.
Commonly performed with accordions and violas caipiras, and often accompanied by agogô and triangle.
Rooted in Tecnobrega, features glossy syncopated MIDI pianos and synths, distinct pitched metallic snares and vocal chops over a wonky kick rhythm.
Slower and romantic Kizomba-fused beats.
Sung poetry of itinerant cantadores from Northeastern Brazil.
Contest of fully improvised poetry sung in different stanza formats, following the poetic conventions of  Cantoria.
Performers usually gather in a circle which rounds the dancers, clapping and spinning according to the rhythm; influenced by cultures originating from Africa, conceived in Northeastern Brazil.
Employs a metrical scheme of quatrains, long verses, and slow pace, with lyrical themes generally limited to love.
Focuses on the prosody of singers, who speak-sing improvised or written stanzas in fast tempos in 2/4 time, accompanied by sparse percussion.
Developed from Baião and the dance rhythms quadrilha and xaxado, along with influences of European Folk Music like chula and schottische (Xote).
Uses electronic elements through the inclusion of keyboards, bass, and electric guitar.

Originated in the interior of northeast Brazil in the 2000s, characterized by the combination of electronic keyboards with vocal harmonization; typically considered a homemade style of Forró eletrônico.
Originated in the 1990s by university students in the Brazilian state of São Paulo; blends the original style with influences from genres like Rock, Reggae, and Funk.
Played in a very fast, binary tempo; originated in 1910 on the streets of the northeastern Brazilian city of Recife.
Counterculture fusion of traditional Northeastern Brazilian Music genres with modern Rock and Hip Hop.
Afro-Brazilian genre which accompanies the cultural manifestation of the same name, hailing from the northeastern state of Pernambuco.
Mixed Portuguese culture with African slave traditions, as well as sharing roots and similarities with Batuque and Jongo.

Regional styles rooted in Northern Brazil, often influenced by Caribbean rhythms and instrumentations, usually with focus on romance, celebrations, the relationship between the man and the Amazon rainforest, and danced in fast and sensual movements.
Romantic vocals and lyrics, bubbly and sensual melodies and rhythms, horn sections and lush Caribbean-like guitar riffs over fast tempos.
Originated in rural areas in the state of Pará, danced frenetically to the beat of syncopated drums, with international recognition after its modernization.
Carimbó, Cumbia and Forró rhythm structures composed the overall form, with Maxixe and Merengue as dance influences.
Melodic and usually instrumental approach, centered around the electric guitar.
Fast and electronic-based style that evolved from Brega calypso, particularly associated with peripheral areas of the city of Belém.
Raw and vulgar Tecnobrega and Funk brasileiro fusion developed in the late 2010s by DJs in Belém do Pará.
Originated in the 19th century from a blend of various rhythmic styles of African Music, forming a new sound, structure, and a dance of the same name.
Heavily percussive and polyrhythmic Samba.
Originating from Portuguese popular street marches (marchas populares), featuring simple, joyful melodies and sometimes malicious lyrics.
Used for samba groups whose music was performed in the suburban Cariocas parties, with romantic lyrical content and improvisation.
Predominance of guitar riffs, atabaques, pandeiros and drums.
Arrocha and Pagodão fusion subgenre, created in mid-2000s in Bahia by the singer and composer Dan Ventura, merge the electronic keyboards of arrocha with the rhythms of pagodão.

Overly romantic lyrics and Pop overtones, with the addition of mainstream instruments like the prominent employment of bass, synths and drumkit alongside the traditional tantã, repique de mão and banjo.
Originating from the early roots of Samba primarily in Rio de Janeiro in the beginning of the 20th century, initially as a more danceable style with little or no vocals.
Romantic, commercial form of Samba that was popular in Brazil between the 1930s and the 1950s.
Emerged in the 1930s as the result of a fusion of rhythmic elements and combining Samba with Choro.
Development of Samba-choro characterized by sudden pauses in its syncopated rhythms.
Emerged in the 1930s, with the influence of Choro, Maxixe, Lundu, and Big Band from the the United States.
Mixed Portuguese culture with African slave traditions, as well as sharing roots and similarities with Batuque and Jongo.
Urban Samba from the samba schools of Rio de Janeiro, with short songs about everyday topics and love.
Developed in the 1930s in Brazilian samba schools (escola de samba) to be presented and performed at carnivals.
Developed in the early forties, with lyrics mainly exalting the culture of Brazil.
Emerged in the 1970s, featuring a strong influence from Bolero along with overly romantic lyrics.
Popular genre in Brazil during the 1950s and 1960s, with influence of Samba and Jazz.
Blends the rhythmic sound of Samba with Rock, as well as additional influences from Jazz and Soul.
Brazilian genre developed in late 1960s and very successful in early 1970s with the popularization of Soul and Funk in Brazil plus a mixing of Samba-rock elements.
Jazz genre from Brazil that incorporates Samba and/or Bossa nova elements.
Acoustic guitar-based and originated from the rural parts of Brazilian Center-South region.
Regional dance and its accompanying music from the Brazilian midwest, predominantly the state of Mato Grosso.

Earliest form of Sertanejo, emerging in pre-World War II rural Brazil during the late 1920s; quickly strummed acoustic guitars, most commonly the 10-string viola caipira and classical guitar, and a highly emotive vocal style.
Style of Sertanejo de raiz predominant in southeast, south, and west-central Brazil.
Hybrid of Brazilian Sertanejo with Pop production and aesthetics, made popular nationwide during the mid-to-late 1980s.
Third evolution of Sertanejo, sharing close sensibilities with national Brazilian Pop music and other regional styles.
Merged the Arrocha style with the younger audience creating a more energetic and more danceable rhythm.
Incorporates the rhythms, production, and idioms of Funk brasileiro into the universitário genre.

Brazilian cultural movement that began in the city of São Paulo and lasted from 1979 to 1985; united a variety of artists who had no access to major labels due to their experimental, avant-garde approach.
Slow and danceable Brazilian rhythm.
Afro-Colombian popular genre which features a strong emphasis on rhythm and improvisation and a call-and-response format.
Genre derived from Trinidadian Calypso, popular in the eastern region of Venezuela and associated with Carnival.
Uruguayan popular music originating among Montevideo's Afro-Uruguayan population, based on three differently-sized drums.
Fusion of Uruguayan Candombe with elements of Rock music.
A danceable genre, similar to the Polka, from the city of Santa Cruz, Bolivia, characteristic of the area’s Carnival celebrations and generally composed for brass band musicians.
Colombian folk music that originated in Boyacá province, best known for its wordplay and humorous lyrics.
Originated in northwest Argentina and southern Bolivia around 1850, typically in 6/8 and traditionally performed with instruments like the guitar, bombo legüero (traditional drum), and violin.
Mixes native Guaraní music with Paraguayan Polka and European schottische music.
Traditional genre and dance from the Río de la Plata region (Argentina, Uruguay, and southern Brazil), featuring similar rhythms to Milonga and typically performed with the guitar and accordion.
Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.
Music developed by the Chilean people.
Sung poetry traditional to Chile and transmitted orally from one generation to another.
Music of the Chiloé Archipelago.
Incorporates Chilean Music into the traditional sound of Cumbia.
Incorporating various instruments and rhythmic components from diverse genres such as Ska, Salsa, Indigenous Andean Music, Reggae, and Bolero.
Encompasses Jazz influences with Hispanic American Music styles such as Cueca, Bolero, Tango and Corrido.
Chilean offshoot of Canción melódica that expresses a much more melancholic or nostalgic side.
Short-lived movement that reincorporated traditional Chilean folklore into modern production and styling inspired by foreign musicians.
Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.
Traditional folk from the Chilean countryside distinguished by its prominent melody.
A vibrant Bolivian genre set in 6/8 meter featuring choral refrains, harmonic progressions, and lyrics exploring the subject of romantic love.

Urban folk ensembles characterized by musical instruments of Andean Indigenous origin or association, and despite its frequent association with Indigenous villages, bearing little resemblance to the Indigenous musical expressions of the Southern Andes.
Originated in the Argentinian province of Córdoba, usually with an upbeat rhythm and originally performed with a four-piece band.
Popular in Chile, Argentina, and Bolivia, accompanied by a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature and usually structured into 14 verses.
Almost always features synthesizer keyboards and electronic percussion with an upbeat rhythm.

Originated in the Argentinian province of Santa Fe, particularly in its capital city Santa Fe de la Vera Cruz, with lyrics that tend to be romantic and relatively clean compared to later Cumbia argentina.
Cumbia argentina heavily influenced by Reggaetón and characterized by hard-hitting bass and heavy use of samples and Auto-Tune.

Developed in the villa miserias (shanty towns) by the lower classes of Argentina in the early 2000s, featuring basic rhythms and low budget productions combined with lyrics that can be openly sexual or touch on sociopolitical issues.
Style that incorporates elements of Colombian traditional music, which includes and keeps influences from Spanish, African, and Indigenous cultures.
Peruvian Cumbia with influence from Psychedelic Rock and Surf Rock that emerged in the 1960s, developed by Andean people who had migrated to urban areas.
Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.
Pacific coast Afro-Colombian music and folk dance performed by a marimba/percussion ensemble with heavy use of call-and-response vocals.
Combines Tango rhythms and melodies with Electronic music.
Emerged in the state of Zulia in the 1950s, merging Spanish Folk Music and Venezuelan Christmas carols.
Slow and melancholic rhythms, primarily performed on the Paraguayan harp.
Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of the Andes.
Repeating phrases of sung poetry dealing with emotional topics.
Traditional dance and music genre with Andean roots that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.
One of the most popular genres of Andean music in Bolivia, particularly present in the departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosí.
Fast and lively; mostly played in northwestern Argentina in the provinces of Jujuy, Salta, and Tucumán.
Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on charangos and guitarillas, with a catchy, lively rhythm.
Incorporates elements of Creole music and the Venezuelan waltz.
Surinamese popular music with roots in Surinamese Creole music, which was influenced by folk traditions of Africa, Europe, and the Americas.
Traditional musical accompaniment to the Venezuelan 'velorios de cruz de mayo' celebrations, played with the mandolin (as lead instrument), cuatro and guitar.
Emerged in the early 2010s in Chile, characterized by upbeat rhythms and rapping, usually on topics of parties, dancing, and urban life.
Traditional Folk Music of the Mapuche people of Chile and Argentina.
Rioplatense genre characterized by a slow rhythm which usually appears with a guitar; generally considered a precursor to Tango.
Mestizo folk genre popular in the central Peruvian Andes, characterized by a pronounced, though sedate, rhythm; traces of Andean melody; and octosyllabic verses.
Variant originated in Montevideo that stands out for its rhythms, nasal vocals and choral arrangements.
Combination of African, Spanish, and Andean influences that originated after the time of the arrival of Spanish colonists and African slaves to Peru.
Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

Backing to the fast-paced dance that originated in northern Peru in the region of Piura of the same name; bands consist of a singer, a small chorus, two guitarists, along with the cajón and sometimes a spoon player.

Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.
Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "la música popular nativa" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.
Based on Joropo, it incorporates elements of Bossa nova and Jazz.
Traditional dance popular in Ecuador and Colombia; based on European Waltz and often performed with guitar and mandolin.
Improvised poetry accompanied by a guitar that is tied to gaucho culture.
Popular music originating in Paraguay and the Province of Corrientes (Argentina), derived from the Bohemian polka and traditional music of Hispanic-Jesuit origin.
Lively Hispanic American Music and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.
Emerged in the early 2010s, characterized by minimalistic, rhythm-centric production heavily influenced by Cumbia villera and other Cumbia argentina styles.
Emerged in the Andean countries in the late 1960s and early 1970s, incorporating traditional instruments and harmonies from Indigenous Andean Music within a Rock format.
Colombian style that takes heavy influence from Reggaetón, House, Hip Hop, and various Afro-Colombian and Colombian Pacific styles.
Fast-paced, percussive traditional genre created by the Afro-Bolivian people.
Melancholic sound generally led by a guitar or bandoneon, originating in Buenos Aires by the late 19th century and gaining worldwide popularity from the 1920s to the 1950s.
Melancholic style developed in Finland in the 1930s and 1940s, influenced by traditional minor-key Finnish Folk Music melodies and the rhythms of German marches.
Adds new elements into traditional Argentine Tango, most importantly the incorporation of Jazz and Western Classical Music.
Developed by the indigenous peoples of eastern Bolivia, bringing in some elements of Hispanic Music, and featuring a syncopated rhythm.
Fuses basic Merengue rhythms with influences from Cumbia and Lambada, being largely synthesized, with live instruments usually limited to percussion and brass.
Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.
Peruvian criollo-mestizo songs with recurring themes of sadness and unrequited love, usually in 6/8 meter.
Traditional genre and dance of 19th century Peru, sung in the minor mode and accompanied by a varying combination of guitar, vihuela, harp and cajón.
Folk dance that evolved out of Peruvian Zamacueca during the 19th century.
Covering the various musical traditions of Sufis.
Sufi vocal style popular in Pakistan, differentiated from Qawwali by its small ensemble size and simple arrangements.
Melodic, devotional music performed by Sufi Islami communities in Ethiopia and neighboring countries
Sufi Music in India and Pakistan using the raga and tala templates of Hindustani Classical Music.
Religious music meant to accompany the dabõih ceremony of the Acehnese people.
Classical music of the Kashmir region, the northernmost part of the Indian subcontinent.
Pakistani subgenre rooted in Sufi tradition, featuring South Asian instruments like the dhol, tabla, and sitar within a Rock band format with lyrics and imagery inspired by traditional Sufi poets.
Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.
Informed by a long history of tradition in a specific culture or region, mostly associated with the peasantry and non-aristocratic public.
Indigenous music of Africa that is passed down orally from generation to generation, the authors of the songs are usually unknown.
African Folk Music developed by the Yabassi people of Cameroon.
Yoruba Music developed by Muslims during the late 1930s and early 1940s in the Ijebu region of Yorubaland, the current Ogun state.
Tradition from Cape Verde, unusual among the islands' music due to its lack of polyphonic singing and its usage of polyrhythms.
Music of the Dagomba people of northern Ghana.
Mixture of Sub-Saharan African, Arabic, and Amazigh Music, created by the Gnawa, an ethnic minority group in North Africa, mainly Morocco.
Traditional Folk Music of the Kabye people of northern Togo, including some of the most singular styles that can be found in West Africa.
Tradition of the Bakongo people from Angola and Congo that has influenced contemporary styles such as Kuduro.
Melodic, chordophone-dominated sound; based on the Austronesian Traditional Music of the first settlers that arrived on the island from Borneo.
Music of the Mbenga and Mbuti people, Pygmy ethnic groups in Central Africa.
Tradition that originated in Seychelles among Creole slaves, similar to Séga, although rawer and played only on large flat drums made from goatskin.
Played in Swahili-speaking African countries; primarily focused on rhythm.
Traditional music from Zanzibar, traditionally played at women's initiation rituals and weddings.
Style from Angola featuring danceable percussion, lyrics often taking the form of a story, and sometimes accompaniment from a guitar.
Traditional Folk Music of southern Africa.
Musical traditions developed by the Afrikaner community in southern Africa.
Encompasses traditions of the Khoisan ethnic family groups.
Traditions of the Nguni ethnic family groups, a southern Bantu ethnicity.
Traditional style of the Shona people from Zimbabwe, based on a simple melodic pattern played on the mbira, from which long instrumental parts are improvised.
Traditional Folk Music of the Sotho-Tswana ethnic family groups from southern Africa.
Tradition from the central region of Benin around Savalou, played with water percussion.
Derived from Traditional Séga, this is the original dance music of La Réunion.
Séga dance music born in the 18th century, before its later adoption of Western pop elements.
Traditional rhythmic chanting and percussion adapted to multiple West African contexts in the 20th century.
Traces back through the history of European and West African settlement and migration to North America, including parts of northern Mexico and Canada in addition to the United States.
Folk of the Appalachian Mountains in the Eastern United States.
Pre-Bluegrass North American string band styles, particularly those rooted in Appalachian Folk Music.
Harmonized singing consisting of four vocal elements: the 'lead' (2nd tenor), the 1st tenor, the baritone, and the bass.
Various styles of Blues originating in the rural US South, typically reyling on expressive vocal delivery and featuring simple, usually acoustic instrumentation.
Laid-back swing rhythms and guitar ornamentation, including solos.
One of the earliest forms of Blues, named for the Mississippi Delta region of the United States where it developed, with a highly rhythmic style and a typical 12-bar structure.

Emphasizes a steady hypnotic groove, sparse percussive and highly energetic guitar riffs, and often features meandering structures with unconventional and usually fewer chord changes compared to Delta Blues.
Developed in the early 20th century in the southern Appalachian foothills and characterized by a syncopated but melodic Ragtime-based finger-picking acoustic guitar style.
Work song created by African-American slaves working on cotton plantations, which features an expressive vocal style to no strict rhythm.
Rooted in martial Fife and Drum Corps music, originated among Afro-American communities in Mississippi.
Usually features a jug as the bass instrument as well as other homemade (or easily affordable) instruments, such as kazoos and washboards.
Ritual practiced by African-Americans in the US South, characterized by shouting, chanting and people dancing in a circle while praying and clapping.
Predominantly 19th-century English hymns with tunes derived from old folk melodies.
Predecessor to Gospel that began as unaccompanied singing by American slaves; shares some of the characteristics of Work Songs.
American Folk Music with spoken or nearly spoken vocals.

Born out of Spirituals in the early 20th century with influence from Southern Gospel and Blues, often featuring passionate or energetic vocal performances, motifs of salvation, and testaments of hardship.
Earliest and most "pure" form of Cajun Music, employing basic rhythms and frequent fiddle double stops.
Closely aligned with American Folk Music and Blues roots, from country's inception in Appalachia and the American South until the popularity of Honky Tonk and Country Pop in the 1950s.
Traditional two-part harmony singing performed mostly by brothers.
Also sometimes called "hillbilly boogie", this is Country's version of Boogie Woogie.
Traditional Country that heavily incorporates Gospel.
Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.
Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.
Traditional Folk Music of the Arabic people.
Arabic Folk Music from rural Morocco with piercing singing, scratchy viola, and rollicking hand drums.
Accompaniment to traditional belly dances.
Folk traditions of the European colonists and convicts in Australia.
Traditional styles of music developed by Austronesian nations prior to arrival of foreign influence.
Traditional ensemble in Bataknese traditional music of North Sumatra, taking its name from its leading instrument - a unique set of toned drums.
Traditional Folk Music of the various Austronesian people groups that make up the indigenous population of the island of Taiwan.
Traditional genres of music found among the ethnicities of Indonesian archipelago, particularly on South Sulawesi, Borneo and North Sumatra.
Comprises the various traditions of folk music found in Brazil, often resulting from the interplay of Indigenous, African and European folk music.
Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.
Aboio that features rhyming verses.
Lively music played by bands consisting of two fifes and percussion; typical of rural Northeastern Brazil.
Music of the Afro-Brazilian Candomblé religion that influenced the secular Afoxé.
Sung poetry of itinerant cantadores from Northeastern Brazil.
Contest of fully improvised poetry sung in different stanza formats, following the poetic conventions of  Cantoria.

Afro-Brazilian style that accompanies and sets the rhythm and energy of the capoeira martial art, originating in the 19th century with the relocation of African slaves to the states of Bahia and Rio de Janeiro.
Style of fandango born in coastal Southern Brazil amidst the Caiçara people.
Afro-Brazilian cultural manifestation involving music and dance; composed of percussion instruments and chants.
Afro-Brazilian religious ritualistic praise sung by priests to evoke entities; typically accompanied by claps and traditional drums known as atabaque.
Afro-Brazilian musical genre that emerged in the 18th century with influences from African drumming with European Fandango.
Afro-Brazilian genre which accompanies the cultural manifestation of the same name, hailing from the northeastern state of Pernambuco.
Popular during the 18th and 19th centuries in Brazil; characterized by sentimental works with amorous themes, poetic lyrics, acoustic instrumentation and operatic vocals.
Regional dance and its accompanying music from the Brazilian midwest, predominantly the state of Mato Grosso.
