Originating in the Soviet Union taking cues from forms of Russian Romance and Russian poetry with the main focus on lyrics.
Mixes Rock music and styles with Avtorskaya pesnya.
Music of the Italian Singer-Songwriters that emerged in the 1960s and early 1970s, initially influenced by French Chanson with the addition of uniquely Italian sensibilities.
French-language songs emphasising sophisticated and poetic lyricism.
Basque genre born during the 1960s inspired by Nova cançó and Chanson.
Dutch-language genre from the Netherlands and Flanders with influences from Cabaret, protest songs, Chanson, and folk.
German style having its origins in literature and theatre rather than American forms like Blues or Rock.
Wave of Portuguese singer-songwriters in the 1960s and 1970s who agitated against the Estado Novo regime and the colonial war waged by Portugal against national liberation fronts.
Arose in Catalonia during the Franco dictatorship, sung in Catalan as a way to resist restrictions placed on regional languages in Spain and retain a regional identity.
Arose in the Occitania region of southern France, sung in the Occitan language as a way to preserve their culture and resist forced usage of French.
Latin American (Nueva canción latinoamericana) and Spanish (Nueva canción española) movement during the 1960s and 1970s.
Arose in Spain in the 1960s, inspired in part by Nova cançó's reclaiming of Catalan regional identity, that spread across the country in regional variations.
Politically-charged messages associated with the rise of leftist social movements; striving for a renewal of traditional Latin and Hispanic American Folk Music expressions.
Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.
Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.
Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "la música popular nativa" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.
Polish sung poetry; the poem is the centerpiece of a song, often with sparse instrumental accompaniment.
Originated in Jamaica in the late 1950s, developing out of Jazz and Rhythm & Blues combined with local Mento and Calypso.
Originated in England in the late 1970s as a revival of the first wave Jamaican Ska movement of the 1960s.
Originated in Jamaica with groups who combined Jazz and Rhythm & Blues with rhythms of traditional Caribbean Music like Mento and Calypso.
Fusion of Calypso and Ska originating in Barbados during the 1960s and 70s.
Expanded on the 2 Tone period, adding further Rock elements resulting in a heavier sound.
Combines Ska with the speed and aggression of Punk Rock.
Fuses skank rhythms and frantic blasts of horns with hardcore intensity.
Fuses Skacore with elements of Crust Punk and sometimes Metal; coupled with anti-establishment lyrics.
Non-musical audio works, including recorded sounds and sounds recreated synthetically or by other means, which are either sounds of known objects or abstract noise manifestations.
Recordings intended to induce a pleasurable tingling sensation in the listener.
Compilations of sounds, samples, and beats pressed on vinyl records for use in DJ performances.
Auditory illusions created when two different frequencies are played simultaneously in separate ears.
Usually unaccompanied vocal readings.
Recorded for children with or without background music.
Traditional stories passed down throughout many generations.
Practice wherein an instructor guides the listener through the process of meditation throughout a session.

Recording of a specific person/s during a formal conversation arranged for historical archiving or media broadcast, often in a question and answer format in which the interviewee shares their views and personal anecdotes with the audience.
Oral presentation with the intention to educate the audience on a specific topic.
Encompasses many forms of literature that use style and rhythm to evoke ideas and emotions further than the prosaic meaning of the literature itself.
Stream-of-consciousness Poetry originating with the Beats in the 1950s.

Descended from the oral traditions of cowboys and ranchers, written with traditional use of rhyme and meter, using humor and slang, and primarily concerning the cowboy profession, lifestyle, and legacy.
Performance of Poetry over Reggae and Dub rhythms, which originated in Jamaica in the 1970s.
Emerged in the 1920s, incorporating the style and rhythms of Jazz as both art forms spread throughout African-American communities in the United States.
Developed in the US during the late 1980s and early 1990s with the growing popularity of poetry slams, a form of poetry competition in which competing performers recite poems in front of a crowd.
Emphasis is placed upon phonetics and the sounds of syllables rather than the meaning of the words themselves.
Narrative storytelling performed by voice actors and produced for radio broadcasting or published on audio media such as tapes or CDs.
Rhetorical acts performed publicly wherein a speaker typically monologues around a particular topic.
Comedy where the performer speaks directly to their intended audience, with origins beginning in the late 19th century.
